headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relatio
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Robert, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the fou
componenttext:
Thank you, Robert, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the fourth quarter.
We also have other members of our executive management team who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; Clarke Starnes, our Chief Risk Officer; and Ricky Brown, our Community Banking President.
We will be referencing a slide presentation during our comments. A copy of the presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on the BB&T website.
Before we begin, let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings predictions or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations. BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Please refer to the forward-looking statements in our presentation and our SEC filings.
In addition, please note that our presentation includes certain non-GAAP disclosures. Please refer to Page 2 and the Appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP. And now I'll turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for your interest in BB&T. And as always, thanks for joining our call. So I think the fourth quarter overall for us was a very solid quarter. Particularly given the challenging environment we have out ther
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for your interest in BB&T. And as always, thanks for joining our call. So I think the fourth quarter overall for us was a very solid quarter. Particularly given the challenging environment we have out there, we had really steady organic performance and really was a great year from a strategic point of view. 
So our core loan and deposit growth number is a bit better than we expected. GAAP growth numbers included the impact of the acquisition, as you'll note. We grew revenues and held the net interest margin stable, which was a very comforting trend. Also, we have a very strong level of capital and liquidity. And so overall, we continue to be a very strong company. 
If you focus on the quarter in terms of earnings, we made $502 million with diluted EPS of $0.64, which was flat with last quarter, and we did have $50 million in pretax merger-related and restructuring charges. So if you ex that, we had what I'd call operating core earnings of $0.68 per share, excluding the merger charges. 
If you look at GAAP ROA of 1.03%, return on tangible common was 13.37%. But if you adjust for the merger and restructuring charges, ROA was 1.09% and return on tangible was 14.19%. 
Revenues totaled $2.6 billion, up $164 million versus the fourth quarter. That's primarily due to Susquehanna. And revenue was up annualized, 10.8%, compared to the third. So we did have strong revenue growth. Now that did include acquisitions, but that's part of our business, so that's real revenue increase. 
For the full year, we totaled $9.8 billion, including acquisitions, which is up 4.1%, and we did have record fee income for the year. Our net interest margin, as I indicated, was stable at 3.35%, which is an important consideration. Our efficiency did improve to 58.8% as we achieved positive operating leverage. I would point out to you that we are really focused on expense management. We're working through the Susquehanna and will be working through the National Penn conversions, which really gives us an excellent opportunity to become more efficient, which we're absolutely committed to do. 
Average loans and leases held for investment totaled $134.8 billion fourth quarter versus $130.5 billion in the third quarter. Excluding acquisitions, our average loans are a little better than we expected, growing approximately 2% annualized versus the third. Now if you take out residential mortgage, which, if you recall, we are intentionally running down and continue to do that, it's up 4.5%. So pretty good loan growth quarter. Organic growth was very strong in C&I, direct retail and equipment finance. 
From a strategic point of view, we're very happy that we did receive full approval from all the regulators for National Penn. We now expect to move that closing up to April 1, and we still plan to do the conversion about mid-July. And so the cost saves on National Penn will still be back -- second half-loaded because you don't really get the cost saves until the conversion. You could argue why we don't move the conversion up. But as you know, we've done a lot of mergers for a long time, and it's best to take your time and do it right rather than get in a hurry and do it wrong. So we'll get all -- get the site in by the end of the year, but we'll take our time doing it. 
Susquehanna is doing great. We did that conversion in mid-November. I will point out, this is the largest conversion ever based on loan and deposit accounts. So we had 144,000 loan accounts, 790,000 deposit accounts, so it was big deal. It's going extraordinarily well. All the regions are running really, really smoothly. And an early look by Rick and his people, the combination of National Penn and Susquehanna looks really great. I mean, it's frankly better than we anticipated when we announced the combination. 
So if you're following along on the slides, if you look at Slide 5, I'll give you a little more detail with regard to our loan growth, which, as I said, was 4.5% ex acquisitions and ex residential mortgage. C&I loan growth was strong. Estimated core C&I loan growth for us was up $848 million or 7.8% annualized. That was largely led by corporate lending and production in the branching network. Our C&I lending was mostly large participations as it was in previous quarters, so it's very competitive. Spreads are tight, but the spreads are flattening out. So that's a good sign. End-of-period balances increased $335 million, again, led by large corporate. So right now, looking forward for next quarter, we expect C&I to continue to grow. It could be a little slower depending on strength and manufacturing. 
I want to particularly point out to you that our oil and gas portfolio is not large for our company. It's $1.4 billion outstanding, which is about 1% of our portfolio. It's a very conservative portfolio. 67% is upstream, 30% is midstream, and we only have about 3 percentage for services. At the end of the fourth quarter, we have no delinquency, no losses. We have no energy loans on nonaccruals. So I noticed there are a lot written and talked about, about energy, but energy is just not a negative story for us. It's a good, solid story, and we don't anticipate any major problems in that area. 
Obviously, if all goes to extreme lows, we'll have some challenges. But because the absolute size has been so small, we just do not anticipate that to be a big issue for BB&T. In the dealer floor plan area, we had a very strong quarter, up $108 million, about 40% annualized. That's really being driven by new markets that we're entering, some new lands we're offering. And we expect it to continue to grow, although probably not at quite that pace. 
In CRE construction and development, we increased 1.6% annualized in the quarter, excluding acquisitions. End-of-period balances did decline a bit, so we expect C&D growth to be kind of seasonally solid until the spring. CRE income producing increased 2.5% annualized, excluding acquisitions. That was mostly broad-based office, hospitality, industrial. The market fundamentals in those spaces continues to improve, although spreads continue to tighten. And so looking at next quarter, we expect core IPP to slow and to really be about flat mostly because of the competitive pricing, and we're just not -- we just not try to book loan just to book loans. If the prices are not acceptable, we just rather not have them. 
Average direct retail lending is a really good story for us, increasing $237 million, almost 11% annualized, due to our HELOC portfolio, direct lending, auto lending in the branches. Our wealth division is doing great, producing about 30% of our retail volume. It's just a really good story. We have really good momentum heading into the first quarter. It might be a little bit slow, just probably seasonal, but the underlying strategic direction in the portfolio has strong momentum as we look forward. 
Let's look at sales finance. On the other hand, it did decline $406 million or 17.5%. That was very consistent with our strategies. We simply aren't willing to participate in the tighter-spread market that exists in that space. With the increased capital that is required today, it just simply does not make sense to book loans where there's not a reasonable risk-adjusted return on capital. So we've been very careful and judicious at looking at the kind of assets we're willing to book. And right now, sales finance is just not a particularly profitable area. That doesn't mean we're getting out of the business. We are restructuring the business, however. You heard us say it recently. We've now implemented a flat-rate compensation program for our dealers, and we're watching the spreads carefully. I would point out that we did pick up a portfolio called the Hann leasing -- auto leasing business from Susquehanna, which we are exiting because we don't choose to do auto leasing, and so that'll be winding down. That'll be a little bit of a negative impact, but it won't affect our fundamental strategies. 
Average residential mortgage, kind of like you've been hearing from everybody, was down 5.9% linked quarter annualized. We are selling all of our conforming production, and originations were 30% lower than the third quarter. Of course, that was largely seasonal. So we expect to see applications continuing to be soft as we hit through the winter months. Gain on sales was down about 5%. Our correspondent channel made -- shifted to 55%, so there's a lot of moving parts in the mortgage business today. The whole TRID disclosure program is definitely slowing down production and booking of transactions. It's hard to know what the underlying issues are in terms of consumer preferences in terms of millennials, et cetera, choosing to own homes or not. Of course, we think it's a little bit early to call all of that. What we do know right now, though, is that mortgage production is down, and part of that is substantially because of the mortgage disclosures that takes just a long, long time. 
I would point out on a very positive note that, overall, the Community Bank loan production is really accelerating. This is the best it's been in years. Our commercial production is up 16.7%. Retail is up 44% compared to the last fourth quarter, and that momentum will continue as we head into the first and second quarters. Our other lending subsidiaries grew $227 million or 7.3%. That's a good number. It's actually a little seasonally weaker, though, because of seasonality for this nature of business. The strongest ones in this area was Grandbridge, equipment finance and Regional Acceptance. So we can expect for the first quarter, this, again, to be seasonally slower, but good in terms of the long-term strategies in the portfolio. 
So to sum up, we expect average loans held for investment to be up modestly about 1% in the first quarter with continued pressure, given the seasonality in our seasonal portfolios. 
Just to comment with regard to the overall economy because that obviously impacts the loan production. There's been a lot written and said over the last few weeks about the issues in the stock market. We believe there's a lot of overreaction going on. It like you woke up January 2, all of a sudden, everybody decided the world's falling apart, and we reject that. We don't see any fundamental structural changes between the first part of December to first part of January. The world just doesn't happen that fast. Obviously, a lot of huge confluence of negative psychology going on, but we're trying to look past that. So what we focus on is the fact that, yes, the world is down, and that is the fact in terms of the oil space, but oil is overall really diminutive. It's diminutive to consumer loans, it's diminutive to businesses, it's diminutive to the airlines. Oil is diminutive. The strong dollar has other implications. But in terms of consumer purchases, it's diminutive because, obviously, imports are a lot cheaper. And so what we would say is that it's not a bullish environment. It's no different from what we talked about the last 2, 3 quarters. The economy is growing at 2%, 2.25% kind of growth rate, which is not great, but it's not falling. So I would say that for all of those pundits that are saying the sky is falling, we would respectfully disagree with that. 
So if you look at our Slide 6, just a comment or 2 on deposits. It continues to be a good story for us. Our noninterest deposits increased $1.7 billion or 15% annualized, but that does include acquisitions. If you take out acquisitions, our total deposits were about flat by design. But noninterest-bearing deposits grew 7.5%, which was very good. So we're doing a really good job in improving our mix and reducing our cost. Ex Susquehanna, our noninterest-bearing deposits were 32.3% of deposits, and our costs remain low at 24 basis points. 
I'd point out on a very bright note that we introduced in the fourth quarter our new U digital mobile online platform. It is doing extraordinarily well. We now have over 650,000 users, and it is gaining momentum as we go forward. We believe it is the best integrated platform in the business today, and it's certainly a big driver of our new account production today. So overall, we feel really great about our deposit performance. We feel really good about our digital strategy. And while there's plenty to do, we believe we'll stand out as a real positive performer in the whole digital space as we go forward. 
So now with that, I'll ask Daryl to give you some more detail, and then I'll summarize after that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Our credit quality remains very strong. Loans 90 days
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Our credit quality remains very strong. Loans 90 days or more past due declined $69 million, mostly driven by loans acquired from the FDIC and impaired loans. Loans 30 to 89 past due increased 13% mostly because we conformed Susquehanna's delinquencies to our more conservative methodology. 
We also had some seasonal growth, which is typical for the fourth quarter. NPAs declined 4.3% mostly because of the sale of nonperforming residential mortgage loans. This was offset by a more conservative approach for determining nonaccrual status for mortgage loans and HELOCs. Excluding the loan sale, NPAs were essentially flat compared to last quarter. 
Net charge-offs increased slightly to 38 basis points in the quarter led by higher charge-offs at Regional Acceptance. The increase at regional was due to seasonality, declining small car values and the regional Texas exposure. Regional accounted for about half of the total charge-offs. Overall, we are very pleased with credit quality. Looking forward, we expect NPAs to remain in a similar range in the first quarter next year. We expect charge-offs to be in the range of 35 to 45 basis points. 
Continuing on Slide 8. Our allowance coverage ratios remained strong at 2.83x for charge-offs and 2.53x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loan ratio was 1.07% compared to 1.08% last quarter. Remember, all of our acquired loans have a combined mark of about $750 million from all of our acquisitions, so the effective allowance coverage is significantly higher. 
We recorded a provision of $129 million for the quarter compared to net charge-offs of $130 million. As Kelly mentioned earlier, we have a very clean and conservative energy portfolio. That's about 1% of our loan portfolio or $1.4 billion. The allowance coverage for these loans is approximately 5%, given the stress in the sector. 
Turning to Slide 9. Net interest margin was 3.35%, flat compared to third quarter and in line with our guidance. Core margin was 3.12%, down 3 basis points. Both GAAP and core margin were impacted by larger balances at the Fed for a majority of the quarter and lower loan yields. 
We expect GAAP and core margin to increase modestly in the first quarter due to higher rates on earning assets, driven by a recent rate increase, lower Fed balances and the ability to lag deposit rates. We became slightly less asset-sensitive this quarter mostly due to investment and funding mix changes. As you can see, we will continue to benefit from additional rate hikes. 
Continuing on Slide 10. Fee income for the year was a new record. Our fee income ratio was 41.8% for the quarter. Looking at a few components of fee income. Insurance income increased $26 million or 29% annualized mostly due to seasonal factors. Investment banking and brokerage experienced a decline of $14 million mostly due to higher capital markets activity last quarter. Mortgage banking income decreased $7 million mostly due to lower gain on sale of loans and lower salable production offset by better commercial mortgage income. 
Other income increased $15 million due to $25 million higher income related to assets of certain post-employment benefits and $12 million in the client derivative income offset by a $20 million decrease in partnership and other investment income. Noninterest income should increase modestly next quarter. This will be led by stronger insurance and investment banking revenues with lower mortgage and service charge income. 
Turning to Slide 11. Noninterest expenses totaled $1.6 billion, essentially flat from last quarter. Personnel expense increased $11 million, driven by higher salary expenses from Susquehanna. In addition, we had some offsetting expenses with higher post-employment benefit expense and lower medical and retirement costs. 
Average FTEs were up just a bit over 1,000 due to Susquehanna. Excluding acquisitions, FTEs remained flat. 
Occupancy and equipment expense increased $9 million mostly due to acquisitions. Merger-related and restructuring charges totaled $50 million. We do not expect a material amount of merger-related cost next quarter. 
Our effective tax rate was 31.7%, and we expect a similar rate next quarter. Noninterest expense should be flat on a GAAP basis next quarter as the lower merger-related charges will be offset by seasonally higher FICA and employee benefit-related expenses. We are confident we will achieve the cost saves from our acquisitions. We also expect to improve efficiency throughout 2016 with fourth quarter efficiency ratio around 56% to 57%. 
Turning to Slide 12. Capital ratios remained very strong, with common equity Tier 1 of 10.2%. Fully phased in common equity Tier 1 increased to 10%. Our LCR decreased to 130%, and our asset liquid buffer at the end of the quarter was very strong at 13.5%. 
Let's look at some segment results, beginning on Slide 13. Community Bank's net income was up $9 million from last quarter and up $22 million from the fourth quarter of last year. This was driven by commercial lending, retail lending and deposits as well as higher funding spreads on deposits, partially offset by lower rates on new commercial loans. Net interest income increased $87 million, with about half of that driven by Susquehanna. 
Finally, with all the regulatory approvals we received for the planned acquisition of National Penn, we expect to close on April 1 with the third quarter systems conversion. 
Turning to Slide 14. Residential Mortgage Banking net income totaled $49 million, down $10 million from last quarter, driven by a lower gain on mortgage loan production, partially offset by an increase in net servicing income. Gain on sale spreads dropped slightly to 103 [ph], and 58% of our production mix was purchased. 
Looking at Slide 15. Dealer Financial Services income totaled $42 million, down $2 million from last quarter. The provision was up due to higher charge-offs in Dealer Finance and Regional Acceptance. 
Turning to Slide 16. Specialized Lending net income totaled $71 million, up $2 million from last quarter, driven by higher commercial mortgage income and leasing income. 
Looking at Slide 17. Insurance Services net income totaled $36 million, up $15 million from last quarter, mostly driven by a seasonal increase in commercial property and casualty insurance and higher live commissions due to seasonality and improved production. Year-to-date same-store sales achieved about a 1% growth as the market for insurance pricing is softer. 
Turning to Slide 18. Financial Services segment had $103 million in net income, up $21 million from last quarter. Corporate Banking generated significant loan growth of 30%. Wealth experienced 16% loan growth and 21% growth in transaction deposits. Noninterest income decreased $10 million linked quarter due to lower SBIC partnership income and investment advisory fees. 
In summary, we achieved broad-based loan growth and revenue growth due to Susquehanna, continued excellent credit quality and positive operating leverage. We look forward to executing on the opportunities for merger partners in the coming quarters. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing remarks and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Daryl. So in summarizing, again, we did have a solid quarter; good loan and deposit growth; real momentum in the Community Bank; stable margin, as Daryl described; excellent credit quality; strong capital; strong liquidity. Acquisitions give us
componenttext:
Thank you, Daryl. So in summarizing, again, we did have a solid quarter; good loan and deposit growth; real momentum in the Community Bank; stable margin, as Daryl described; excellent credit quality; strong capital; strong liquidity. Acquisitions give us a real opportunity in terms of cost saves and revenue enhancements as we go forward. And while we don't think the economy is tanking, we don't think it's going to be super robust either. It's kind of a slow steady as you go activity. But even so, we have huge opportunities in new markets and new product penetrations. So overall, a good quarter, and we think we have decent momentum as we head forward into the first. 
So with that, we'll turn it over to Alan for Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Kelly. Robert, if you would come back on the line now and explain how our listeners may participate in the Q&A session.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Kelly. Robert, if you would come back on the line now and explain how our listeners may participate in the Q&A session.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on loan growth and on reserves. On loan growth, I saw your commentary on the outlook for 1Q, but maybe if you could give us a sense as to how you're thinking about the loan book over the course of the year, given the fact that you just ma
componenttext: I had a question on loan growth and on reserves. On loan growth, I saw your commentary on the outlook for 1Q, but maybe if you could give us a sense as to how you're thinking about the loan book over the course of the year, given the fact that you just made one acquisition or about to make another one. Wanted to get your sense of how you're planning on driving loan growth at the core level as well as through the acquisitions.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Betsy, I'll give you a [indiscernible] comment on this. I feel -- relative to the economy, I feel pretty good. This combination of Susquehanna and National Penn, giving us #4 market share in Pennsylvania, is a real opportunity for us. We ar
componenttext: Well, I think, Betsy, I'll give you a [indiscernible] comment on this. I feel -- relative to the economy, I feel pretty good. This combination of Susquehanna and National Penn, giving us #4 market share in Pennsylvania, is a real opportunity for us. We are further along in those 2 mergers than we've been in any mergers we've ever done that I can recall. And Pennsylvania is a really good market, a nice diversified market between Philadelphia the Lancaster area. So it's our kind of area, so we feel good about that. Florida is doing really, really well now. Texas is having a little bit of a dampening effect because of energy, but energy is only about 10% of the overall empire. That's what I tell people. So Texas was increasing about 1,000 people a day, so now it made us down to 850. So Texas is doing really well. And we have such tiny share, we'll do well. So I think it's, relative to the economy, a pretty good loan year for us. So Rick, would you comment on that?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kelly. I would say that we are pretty well positioned in Pennsylvania. We think that will be an opportunity. Obviously, in new markets, you've got to stabilize, build your brand, get your sales culture in place. We feel very positive about that. From
componenttext: Yes, Kelly. I would say that we are pretty well positioned in Pennsylvania. We think that will be an opportunity. Obviously, in new markets, you've got to stabilize, build your brand, get your sales culture in place. We feel very positive about that. From a core perspective, we're seeing really strong growth in Texas. I would support that Texas is not just all oil, big, to be sure, but there's a lot of other things. We've been pleased with our loan growth in the Texas market. Florida, across the whole state, has rebounded, and we've seen really solid growth in the State of Florida. We've got opportunities to grow our ABL business. We're looking really closely at how we make that more effective. We've been pleased with growth in small commercial and small business with the strategies that we did employ. We're going to be careful with CRE. You heard Kelly talk about that. We got to be careful with pricing. We got to be careful with risk. But the last 2 quarters, in the third and the fourth, Community Bank growth on a linked basis has been the best it's been in probably 5, 6 or 7 years. Production, as Kelly said, is up. Our activity levels are good. I would not say that means that we think the economy is doing outstandingly well. We just are grinding it out, finding opportunities. Our guys are working really, really hard, and I feel good about where we are. And as we go into '16, I feel as good about making our loan growth goals in the Community Bank in terms of where we've been over the last several years than any of those years. So I feel really good about where we are.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just wanted to have the follow-up on the allowance. Daryl, in the past, I think you've mentioned wanting to make sure that the ALLL ratio doesn't go below 1%, and I know you called out the marks that you've got. So are you thinking about the ALLL as
componenttext: Okay. Just wanted to have the follow-up on the allowance. Daryl, in the past, I think you've mentioned wanting to make sure that the ALLL ratio doesn't go below 1%, and I know you called out the marks that you've got. So are you thinking about the ALLL as the 107 print? Or are you embedding in your thoughts the marks that you've got?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really includes both. When we go through the model, Betsy, every quarter, we go through an analysis that look at how the loans are graded and how they're going to perform and what the embedded losses are. And the marks are part of the embedded losses o
componenttext: It really includes both. When we go through the model, Betsy, every quarter, we go through an analysis that look at how the loans are graded and how they're going to perform and what the embedded losses are. And the marks are part of the embedded losses on balance sheet. So I think we feel very good about our current allowance level. As we said in the last couple of quarters, as we grow our balance sheet, we want to continue to have to provide for loan growth, which means we're going to have to get paid for incremental growth from that perspective. So I would expect the provision, unless something changes materially, to be basically charge-offs plus also coverage for loan growth going forward.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so some reserve build related to loan growth?
componenttext: Okay, so some reserve build related to loan growth?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Coming back to the commercial real estate comments that you guys just made, can you share with us some of the underwriting concerns that you have? And can you relate that at all to what the regulators came out with recently about their concerns about unde
componenttext: Coming back to the commercial real estate comments that you guys just made, can you share with us some of the underwriting concerns that you have? And can you relate that at all to what the regulators came out with recently about their concerns about underwriting standards in commercial real estate?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make a comment, Gerard, and then let Clarke give you much more color. But we've said for several quarters, as you know, that the competition in the old -- at the CRE space has been very difficult. And there's been really low cap rates being used and
componenttext: I'll make a comment, Gerard, and then let Clarke give you much more color. But we've said for several quarters, as you know, that the competition in the old -- at the CRE space has been very difficult. And there's been really low cap rates being used and high advanced rates, and so we've maintained our steady conservative underwriting. For example, everybody is underwriting when there's low cap rates. We underwrite on long-term expected normal cap rates, and so it makes a big difference in how much you advance. And so we look at a lot of deals, we don't get them, but we're fine with that. We're just not going to violate our risk appetite to get volume in that space. But Clarke, maybe you can add some color to that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Gerard, the -- you've seen recently the regulators set back out all the historical interagency guidance around CRE, which is clearly a signal that they think that it's moving a little too fast right now. We see and hear most about multifamily concern
componenttext: Yes. Gerard, the -- you've seen recently the regulators set back out all the historical interagency guidance around CRE, which is clearly a signal that they think that it's moving a little too fast right now. We see and hear most about multifamily concern about just the sheer number of continued starts or units in pipeline at some point that's going to outstrip certainly the [indiscernible] the markets in balance today, and the fundamentals look really good. We are seeing certain markets where rents are higher -- as high as homeownership. You're seeing some of that again. But we're seeing underwriting things like lenders underwriting off these low cap rates looking at pro forma trended rents that are above market, really low vacancy, et cetera, et cetera. And certainly, the regulators are just asking everyone to go back to the fundamentals and -- which Kelly described well for us, which we look very much at the cash flow and not so much just the low cap rate environment that we've been in, in the last few years.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you guys give us a flavor on the cap rates that you both addressed? What you're using versus what you're seeing in the marketplace?
componenttext: Can you guys give us a flavor on the cap rates that you both addressed? What you're using versus what you're seeing in the marketplace?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So for example, probably the most aggressive, you're seeing cap rates in the multifamily space in the 4% to 5.5% range, great properties, all fits within the 5.75% to 7.75%. Retail, down as low as 6%. Industrial, as low as 5.50%, hospitality down to
componenttext: Yes. So for example, probably the most aggressive, you're seeing cap rates in the multifamily space in the 4% to 5.5% range, great properties, all fits within the 5.75% to 7.75%. Retail, down as low as 6%. Industrial, as low as 5.50%, hospitality down to 6%. And so again, we don't underwrite merely on the cap rate. We're going to look at a stressed cash flow coverage, and we're going to look at existing market rents. And we're not going to look at those pro forma escalations, and we're going to look at stress exits. So a lot of lenders are lending against that really low cap rate. So it looks like you've got a lot of equity in the deal, but it's really probably overfinanced. And so our loans would typically have less proceeds, given our approach.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then -- and Kelly, to come back to your comments about your digital channel, U, that you guys rolled out successfully, can you give us some color on if you look at it over the next 2 or 3 years, is this going to impact the number of branches th
componenttext: Great. And then -- and Kelly, to come back to your comments about your digital channel, U, that you guys rolled out successfully, can you give us some color on if you look at it over the next 2 or 3 years, is this going to impact the number of branches that you need? Do you see your branch count maybe falling or shrinking in size, the individual branches? And then, second, do you have any metrics on the cost savings? That if you introduce somebody into this digital channel rather than using a teller for a transaction, what kind of cost savings you are guys are seeing?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can give you an overview, Gerard, and then Ricky can give you more details. He's really been driving the whole U platform. What we've said, U is extremely successful, and it -- and that will be true for the industry. We're clearly seeing transacti
componenttext: Maybe I can give you an overview, Gerard, and then Ricky can give you more details. He's really been driving the whole U platform. What we've said, U is extremely successful, and it -- and that will be true for the industry. We're clearly seeing transactions slowly methodically reducing in the branches. And at the same time, though, when you talk to Xers and Yers and millennials, they will still tell you that one of the top 2 preference items in terms of selecting a bank is the convenience of a branch. Fact is, people still want to be able to go into a branch and see somebody to have a complex product if they have a problem, and there's a little bit of dispute psychology that were eyed by the branch and say, "Well, that's what I mean, is it makes me feel good." So you're not going to see a dramatic change in a number of branches, but you will see an increasing focus on the size of the branches, the structure of the staffing in the branches, and all of that will help to relatively reduce our cost as we shift more into the digital platform. But Rick, you could give a bit more color on that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me just talk about the branches just a little bit. We've been on a very methodical long-term pruning of our branch system. We've not had any real major branch reductions other than onetime several years ago, but we constantly look at our branc
componenttext: Yes, so let me just talk about the branches just a little bit. We've been on a very methodical long-term pruning of our branch system. We've not had any real major branch reductions other than onetime several years ago, but we constantly look at our branches. We look at underperforming branches. We look at opportunities to consolidate branches. So we're all over that. Secondly, we've been on a pretty steady path of reducing headcount in our branches in response to less transactions in the branch. So we are already running pretty elbow lean in our branches today. We're also believing that the folks in the branches need to know more, do more. So this would need a universal concept something we're embracing and moving forward on, so that lesser people, better people, better and able people can do more for our clients, and what we're finding is our associates like it because they feel better armed to take care of client needs, and it also creates savings for us. So this is an evolution and a process. I don't view it as a revolutionary process. We've got to continue to be on top of it. We are seeing clearly reduction of branch transactions steady. It continues to be. It's not going over a cliff. Branches still are important. They're part of our branding. They're part of the convenience that we have to have. They're part of the omnichannel development. So it's about having new, but it's also about having good branches. It's about having great ATMs. It's about having great call center. It's about having a great experience 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and that's what we're trying to put together at BB&T, a lot of focus on digital and the new platform is we think unique and different, and it's got lots of accolades. Kelly mentioned over 650,000 used. The last number that just came out yesterday was over 700,000 users, and the positive impact from our associates, feedback from our clients is all very, very good. Now to give you the cost of transactions, we have not really done that to say what if a transaction [indiscernible] there's no question, self-service would save money, no doubt about that, but overall, what we find is we can get somebody to do U, we think they're going to do more at the branch, they're going to do more call center, they're going to do more across all of our platforms. And so at the end of the day, that gives us a better chance to have a bigger share of wallet, better referral from them and ultimately drives the revenue, while overall aspects around cost reduction ultimately leads to positive operating revenue in the branches. That's what we're trying to achieve.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not trying to [indiscernible] really important question for us. So if you take a portfolio of clients, as those clients move to more mobile digital technology, and as Ricky continues to downsize the size and the number of staff in the branches, the
componenttext: So I'm not trying to [indiscernible] really important question for us. So if you take a portfolio of clients, as those clients move to more mobile digital technology, and as Ricky continues to downsize the size and the number of staff in the branches, there's no question in my mind that the aggregate net cost of that portfolio of clients goes down. That's a big deal for the industry, and that would still take 10 to 15 years for it to phase out, but it is a big positive trend for our industry.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from Paul Miller with FBR Capital.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from Paul Miller with FBR Capital.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the insurance line, I know you sold some. It looks like we were a little bit overestimating that insurance. I don't think we were completely saturated in some of the insurance sales. How should we look at that going forward? Is this a good run rate on
componenttext: On the insurance line, I know you sold some. It looks like we were a little bit overestimating that insurance. I don't think we were completely saturated in some of the insurance sales. How should we look at that going forward? Is this a good run rate on a seasonality basis of what you guys did in the third and fourth quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Chris. We were a little lighter in the fourth quarter primarily because we've got really declined. We had a soft market that really [indiscernible] in the fall. So average P&C prices today are down about 4%. We might be a little heavy on tha
componenttext: Well, this is Chris. We were a little lighter in the fourth quarter primarily because we've got really declined. We had a soft market that really [indiscernible] in the fall. So average P&C prices today are down about 4%. We might be a little heavy on that because we're heavier in property, but our new business growth has been given the market really good up north of, say, 3% to 4%. So on average, if you kind of look at same-store sales and you pull all acquisitions, it's -- we're up about 1.5% or so. We think this next year was sort of run rate and growth we think potential acquisitions we think we could be up in say the 3% to 4% kind of range. Next quarter, probably, up in the 10% sort of range, and there's less volatility. We still have volatility from quarter-to-quarter because this is becoming less volatility. We think first quarter has certainly become one of our stronger quarters, first and second. Second could be a little stronger than the first quarter, but pretty much similar run rates I would say.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you add real quick color on why pricing was soft in the second half of the year.
componenttext: And can you add real quick color on why pricing was soft in the second half of the year.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: :Yes. I mean, what you've got in the 0 market is a lot of overcapacity. We just have not had huge catastrophes the sort of eat out the capital. So you've got retailers, which is the standard are just sort of beating each other up for price. So they're t
componenttext:
:
Yes. I mean, what you've got in the 0 market is a lot of overcapacity. We just have not had huge catastrophes the sort of eat out the capital. So you've got retailers, which is the standard are just sort of beating each other up for price. So they're trying to take deals from the next guy. So you've got pricing on the retail side following those substantially. We're one of the second largest wholesaler. We try to keep about half of our business in retail and half at wholesale for [indiscernible] when retail is struggling, wholesale is a bit better. We're seeing pricing actually holed up in wholesale P&C pretty well today. And we, as you know, being the second largest, we've got pretty good efficiencies. On the AmRisc side, which is more of an MGA specific sort of Wincare [ph] underwriter. We got a big discount in price that we haven't been able to make it up with [indiscernible] in terms of bottom line. So it's really all about overcapacity in the market and each other just really kind of compete heavy on pricing, that all rectifies when you have a catastrophe, so let's see other way now .

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But keep in mind one of the really positives about our insurance strategy is as you grow your client base better than the market, which we're doing, as you have a high retention rate better than the market which we're doing, the building in basically [ind
componenttext: But keep in mind one of the really positives about our insurance strategy is as you grow your client base better than the market, which we're doing, as you have a high retention rate better than the market which we're doing, the building in basically [indiscernible] about it is a really positive annuity story. Because this I can tell, catastrophes will probably continue to outflow since the creation of [indiscernible], so I think probably will continue. And so when they occur, premiums will go up and premiums go up, approximations go up with virtually no increase in our cost structure in part. It's not there today, but it will be there.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: :Kelly is right. I mean, I think our retention, which is the amount of existing business you retain at renewal is about 93%. We think the peers are probably in the upper 80s -- mid- to upper 80s. So we think we're clearly are advantaged there. The other
componenttext:
:
Kelly is right. I mean, I think our retention, which is the amount of existing business you retain at renewal is about 93%. We think the peers are probably in the upper 80s -- mid- to upper 80s. So we think we're clearly are advantaged there. The other thing with the pricing market is early 2000s, it used to have huge volatility. You have up 30%, and now down in the mid-teens. Today, you see much less volatility. It might be up and down 6% or 7% because they have much better forecasting models [indiscernible] so it's within a much tighter range.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from John Pancari with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from John Pancari with Evercore ISI.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the loan growth side, I know you mentioned that you saw some impact from manufacturing sluggishness there. So I guess, can you give us a little bit of color about what you're seeing in manufacturing and how that's impacting growth? If you can just give
componenttext: On the loan growth side, I know you mentioned that you saw some impact from manufacturing sluggishness there. So I guess, can you give us a little bit of color about what you're seeing in manufacturing and how that's impacting growth? If you can just give some more color there.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Clarke. We haven't seen a substantially impact growth yet. I would say the early signals that we've seen out of that's mostly when we look at large company manufacturers or exporters, their sales are softer and their margins are down. Profit
componenttext: John, this is Clarke. We haven't seen a substantially impact growth yet. I would say the early signals that we've seen out of that's mostly when we look at large company manufacturers or exporters, their sales are softer and their margins are down. Profitability's strained a bit, but we've not seen that necessarily translate yet into slower overall demand in the market. So it's been more of just a subtle signal as we continue to analyze the credits.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our comment was really saying that looking forward, if there's a substantial decline in manufacturing, that would impact loan growth.
componenttext: Our comment was really saying that looking forward, if there's a substantial decline in manufacturing, that would impact loan growth.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the pricing side, I wanted to see if the widening spreads at all if that like you're seeing in the market, if that has helped given you any relief on the pricing side at all? And then separately, when we look at your loan growth, and I know you've
componenttext: Yes, on the pricing side, I wanted to see if the widening spreads at all if that like you're seeing in the market, if that has helped given you any relief on the pricing side at all? And then separately, when we look at your loan growth, and I know you've commented on the pricing competition a couple of times being a factor, normally, you're in that 5% to 6% sort of loan growth range. You're running right now a little bit below that. Should we expect that you're looking at more like a 4% annual range as we move through the full year, mainly given these headwinds?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the way we look at it and you heard us say this before, it's probably what GDP is plus 1% or 2%. Our estimate and what our plan has is loan growth in the 3% to 4% range next year. There's a lot of volatility right now, but that's what we have in o
componenttext: I think the way we look at it and you heard us say this before, it's probably what GDP is plus 1% or 2%. Our estimate and what our plan has is loan growth in the 3% to 4% range next year. There's a lot of volatility right now, but that's what we have in our plan. As far as loan spreads linked quarter versus third versus fourth, C&I was pretty much stable, a little bit of deterioration in CRE, but they're pretty stable in C&I. And on the consumer side, we have sales finance. As Kelly mentioned, in his early comments really well about flat, about 1% on prime in direct auto, which is one of the reasons why we're shrinking that portfolio. On the bright spots in Ricky's road, direct retail, we have strong growth from retail, and our spreads are continuing to widen. We're up about 10, 15 basis points in that sector.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then one last one for me going back to Paul's line of questioning around insurance. Just to reconfirm that 7% decline year-over-year in your insurance revenue, would you say that's all attributable to pricing?
componenttext: And then one last one for me going back to Paul's line of questioning around insurance. Just to reconfirm that 7% decline year-over-year in your insurance revenue, would you say that's all attributable to pricing?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Remember, June 1, we sold American Coastal, and so we had that business was worth to us about $145 million in revenue. So we had in -- say, the first 5 months of the year, we had in about $53 million or so. And then from June 1 on, we would ha
componenttext: No, no, no. Remember, June 1, we sold American Coastal, and so we had that business was worth to us about $145 million in revenue. So we had in -- say, the first 5 months of the year, we had in about $53 million or so. And then from June 1 on, we would have lost about $92 million in revenue. So it's really relative to sale. And when you look back at our common quarter comparison for this quarter versus 4 '14, that's pretty much all American Coastal. If you pull out American Coastal, we're, in fact, up a couple of percent. So it has to do with the sale of the American Coastal.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, remember the American Coastal sale was not a net negative. We diversified, we reduced our risk, we reinvested that money in AmRisc and produced more stable, more profitable margin business in that area. So the net positive to us, but it show
componenttext: And remember, remember the American Coastal sale was not a net negative. We diversified, we reduced our risk, we reinvested that money in AmRisc and produced more stable, more profitable margin business in that area. So the net positive to us, but it shows up negative on the revenue line.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In fact, I would even say we invested in a higher margin business, and at the end of the day, it should drive more profitability.
componenttext: In fact, I would even say we invested in a higher margin business, and at the end of the day, it should drive more profitability.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And barring that noise, and barring the pricing pressure, there's nothing structurally about your insurance business that's a drag on the revenue growth [ph]?
componenttext: And barring that noise, and barring the pricing pressure, there's nothing structurally about your insurance business that's a drag on the revenue growth [ph]?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, quite the opposite. We're outrunning the market. The market's down 4%, we're up 1.5% on same-store sales when you pull out acquisitions. What you're seeing is the numbers that are all American Coastal related.
componenttext: I'm sorry, quite the opposite. We're outrunning the market. The market's down 4%, we're up 1.5% on same-store sales when you pull out acquisitions. What you're seeing is the numbers that are all American Coastal related.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, maybe a question for you in terms of capital distribution. With your dividend payout at or maybe slightly above the 30% levels as we calculate it, I know how important dividends are to you relative to your investor base, but I guess, I'm curious ho
componenttext: Kelly, maybe a question for you in terms of capital distribution. With your dividend payout at or maybe slightly above the 30% levels as we calculate it, I know how important dividends are to you relative to your investor base, but I guess, I'm curious how you're thinking about potentially increasing the dividend in 2016 and '17? And any color you can provide on how you and board are thinking about buybacks would be helpful?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Matt, nothing really changed in terms of our capital deployment strategy. As you know, we made it very clear that capital should first be allocated to organic growth, second to our dividends and third to M&A and fourth to buybacks. So nothing's ch
componenttext: Yes. So Matt, nothing really changed in terms of our capital deployment strategy. As you know, we made it very clear that capital should first be allocated to organic growth, second to our dividends and third to M&A and fourth to buybacks. So nothing's changed about that. Nothing likely changed about that. These are all long-term concepts that we run our business back. And so you would expect to see us think about kind of a steady, relatively positive increase in the dividend. You would expect to see us hold on our total capital request for deployment to the low side of what a lot of people do because we are committed to keeping a relatively strong capital position. And keep in mind there's a big issue out there yet to be determined there, it's around kind of cyclical buffer. Not many people are talking about it, but that is the potential increase in capital, and so we're going to be conservative so that we don't end up having to go get capital at a time that is not market friendly. So given all of that, I would say that you'll see our performance in '16 kind of look like '15 whether we do specific buybacks or not is always will be a function of whether or not we have acquisition opportunities that allows us to use that extra capital like we have done in the last couple of years and a function of what our price is. We simply not go out and buy back stock when the price is high, and we're producing negative internal rate of return for our existing shareholders.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks Kelly, that makes sense. And maybe, Clarke, maybe a question, a theoretical question for you relative to energy. I appreciate that BB&T's portfolio is below your peers in terms of your loan exposure. But in terms of how you're thinking about
componenttext: Okay, thanks Kelly, that makes sense. And maybe, Clarke, maybe a question, a theoretical question for you relative to energy. I appreciate that BB&T's portfolio is below your peers in terms of your loan exposure. But in terms of how you're thinking about the trend in nonperforming or criticized assets relative to losses, how do you think about provisioning against a prolonged period of low oil prices? And how does that dovetail with the idea of losses because the collateral you hold against those exposures being a lot lower than potential provision?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Matt. I mean, obviously, just like everyone else, we're monitoring the oil and gas exposure daily, and we're doing our price tags and looking at the sensitivities and stressing accordingly. And we're going down right now to at $20
componenttext: That's a good question, Matt. I mean, obviously, just like everyone else, we're monitoring the oil and gas exposure daily, and we're doing our price tags and looking at the sensitivities and stressing accordingly. And we're going down right now to at $20 or below in our stress case. So my biggest concern is that while we believe even down pretty low, we've got very strong asset coverage and our PV9s [ph] look good. So I don't think even at low rates, we fundamentally have a lot of lost exposure. I'm more concerned about this time around there's a lot of layered bond debt behind the senior secured lenders, and traditionally, that was not the case. And so what could happen this time if it stay down long and low, it could cause a lot of nonaccrual risk. And if you try to work through all that layered debt, and that could cause to have to work through and consider discounts for losses beyond the collateral coverage you normally see. So we're trying to think about all of that and take a conservative view of loss given the fall, even if we've got good collateral coverage for you right now. We're trying to make sure we stay ahead of that. I think our 5% reserve given the quality of our portfolio is very, very prudent, and takes those kinds of things into consideration.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just so we're clear, Clarke, what's your expectation if oil does stay at the $20 level of potential additional losses or if you want to think about it this way, reserving?
componenttext: And just so we're clear, Clarke, what's your expectation if oil does stay at the $20 level of potential additional losses or if you want to think about it this way, reserving?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The true answer is no one really knows, so it's all an estimate, and everybody has different opinions of those. But we have done work in our sensitivity and our allowance process and even down to a $20 level, in aggregate basis, we have asset coverage. An
componenttext: The true answer is no one really knows, so it's all an estimate, and everybody has different opinions of those. But we have done work in our sensitivity and our allowance process and even down to a $20 level, in aggregate basis, we have asset coverage. And even if you look at cash flows discount bag, we think it would not be material. Certainly, if it continues to stay down, we would have to put more on the watch list, potentially move some to nonaccrual and provision accordingly, but even with all that, we don't think it's material number at this time.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And keep in mind when you're doing reserve-based lending, the fact that price goes down, doesn't mean that oil automatically saturated. Oil's still there, gas is still there, and so while you may have an extended period of time at lower prices, the cash f
componenttext: And keep in mind when you're doing reserve-based lending, the fact that price goes down, doesn't mean that oil automatically saturated. Oil's still there, gas is still there, and so while you may have an extended period of time at lower prices, the cash flow and pay off the loan, the odds of losses in that kind of scenario is still extremely low.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from Erika Najarian with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from Erika Najarian with Bank of America.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question dovetails a little bit on the capital planning question. Kelly, clearly, the earnings outlook for the industry, particularly those that don't have your scale, has been ratcheted more, even in these past couple of weeks, and I'm wondering
componenttext: My first question dovetails a little bit on the capital planning question. Kelly, clearly, the earnings outlook for the industry, particularly those that don't have your scale, has been ratcheted more, even in these past couple of weeks, and I'm wondering what your appetite is in terms of taking advantage of that lower earnings outlook and the decline in stock prices, as you think about more acquisitions in 2016.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Erika, I think your question is insightful. I think the longer the challenging environment persists, particularly in some spaces, maybe, like in the energy space, it's certainly putting this proportion amount of pressure on certain companies and to
componenttext: Well, Erika, I think your question is insightful. I think the longer the challenging environment persists, particularly in some spaces, maybe, like in the energy space, it's certainly putting this proportion amount of pressure on certain companies and to the extent that it lasts a while, it would certainly it could cause them to reevaluate their strategic thinking going forward. So we remain from a long-term point of view committed to our acquisition strategy. I'd recall that it is to grow on the average basis 5% to 10% of our assets. In that scenario, you could see the probability increase of potential partners that might be interested. So it always comes down to 2 things, well, 3 things. It comes down to a cultural shift, but we talk to people about our cultural fit, and then it comes down to their willingness to combine and then it's just the mathematics. So to the extent that they are more challenged and that changes their appetite to consider a strategic combination and to the extent there are performances [ph] done better and our price does better that would enhance possibility of [indiscernible] to do combinations.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and just my second question is for Daryl. I just wanted to make sure I understood the 56% to 57% efficiency ratio guide was for 1Q, and I guess, follow-up to that is a lot of investors are now starting to strip further interest rate increases out
componenttext: Got it, and just my second question is for Daryl. I just wanted to make sure I understood the 56% to 57% efficiency ratio guide was for 1Q, and I guess, follow-up to that is a lot of investors are now starting to strip further interest rate increases out of their model. You don't seem to be as pessimistic. But could you deliver continued improvement in your core efficiency if the set is indeed won and done?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Erika, in my opening comments, we said that our efficiency ratio throughout '16 would continue to grow and by the fourth quarter 2016, we would have an efficiency in the range of 56% to 57%. When we put together our operating plan for 2016 a couple mo
componenttext: So, Erika, in my opening comments, we said that our efficiency ratio throughout '16 would continue to grow and by the fourth quarter 2016, we would have an efficiency in the range of 56% to 57%. When we put together our operating plan for 2016 a couple months ago, we were very conservative, and it looks like we were always based upon the future's now on target, but we only embedded the December rate hike that we've got in the plan until we get to the fourth quarter of '16, and then I think in November, December time frame we have another rise. So we basically have interest rates flat for 10 months of the year in '16. We didn't have any more rate increases factored in when we came up with our operating plan and a few deficiency targets.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: And we will take our next question from Michael Rose with Raymond James.

componenttext: This is Amanda Larsen on for Ken. Outlook for NII to grow 12% to 14% year-over-year in '16 factoring in the forward curve, is that one in past given the expedited NPVC closure versus your expectations last year?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So big picture wise, I would tell you that excluding acquisitions, both the benefits we get from Susquehanna and National Penn, we feel very good that we can grow NII year-over-year from '15 and '16. That number is probably in the $150 million to $200 mil
componenttext: So big picture wise, I would tell you that excluding acquisitions, both the benefits we get from Susquehanna and National Penn, we feel very good that we can grow NII year-over-year from '15 and '16. That number is probably in the $150 million to $200 million range. With the acquisitions that the NII grows significantly more than that is because you've a better balance sheet, higher earning assets, but this is a first year in a long time where we basically feel core is stabilized and potentially starting to go up. We're going to grow our loan book, and we're going to grow organic core NII in 2016.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about the positive beta assumptions that you've incorporated into your asset sensitivity estimates.
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the positive beta assumptions that you've incorporated into your asset sensitivity estimates.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. They really haven't changed for a couple of years. So when we show our sensitivities, Marty, up to market scenario, we have all of our deposit beta is averaging around 60%. What we have seen to date, so we've had a rate rise increase in December. We
componenttext: Okay. They really haven't changed for a couple of years. So when we show our sensitivities, Marty, up to market scenario, we have all of our deposit beta is averaging around 60%. What we have seen to date, so we've had a rate rise increase in December. We had, and we're projecting an outlook of positive margin in the first quarter of a couple of basis points. It's really dependent on how successful we are on and what the market does on how deposit rates change. I think we feel very good, up 2 to 3 basis points within margins, and we'll see if it's any better than that depending on the deposit light.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given your 60%, the actual performance so far hasn't been anywhere close to that. So when you're looking at this estimate, if you bring that down, how far do these numbers go up if you assume a 10% or 20% deposit beta?
componenttext: Given your 60%, the actual performance so far hasn't been anywhere close to that. So when you're looking at this estimate, if you bring that down, how far do these numbers go up if you assume a 10% or 20% deposit beta?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say -- I can give you a range and kind of bracket it because it's probably in between the range. I would say that a margin 2 to 3 in the lower end and maybe double that, 4 to 6 on the higher end depending on how we have to adjust deposit prices. T
componenttext: I would say -- I can give you a range and kind of bracket it because it's probably in between the range. I would say that a margin 2 to 3 in the lower end and maybe double that, 4 to 6 on the higher end depending on how we have to adjust deposit prices. The retail deposit rates are pretty static. Commercial has been inching up a little bit. But it really depends on how things play out, and it's probably not going to be the same deposit beta for all the rate increases. We're going to have lower deposit betas in the first couple of rate increases, and as rates continue to rise, we're going to have probably faster deposit betas. So it's going to be very fluid and very dynamic going forward.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 2 to 3x better performance if the deposit betas, and this especially on the first couple of rate rises, is much better than what was incorporated here, and then the other thing I was going to ask you as a follow-up is what really matters then is the as
componenttext: So 2 to 3x better performance if the deposit betas, and this especially on the first couple of rate rises, is much better than what was incorporated here, and then the other thing I was going to ask you as a follow-up is what really matters then is the asset yields and how they can go up. I was looking at the what would be prime or LIBOR-based lending that you could see right on the income statement, construction lending or revolving credit, those rates went up like you would expect even with only 2 weeks of the rate rise. The one-line item that you can't really see very well is C&I, which is the one that really matters. How much of those loans are embedded there are tied to LIBOR or prime and what the impact on short-term rates?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have about $70 billion of loans that are tied to LIBOR and prime. I think it's about $50 billion LIBOR and about $20 billion in prime. You are right in that of the majority in LIBOR does move fairly quickly. Some of it immediate, some first of
componenttext: Yes. So we have about $70 billion of loans that are tied to LIBOR and prime. I think it's about $50 billion LIBOR and about $20 billion in prime. You are right in that of the majority in LIBOR does move fairly quickly. Some of it immediate, some first of the month. So prime tends to move first of the month or quarterly. So there is a little bit of lag. So even though rates rose in middle of December, we still have not received the full benefit of all of our assets repricing, and we're in the middle of January. It probably takes a good full 2 months, maybe 3 months before all the assets are going to be positively impacted.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have time for one more question. We will go next to Nancy Bush with NAB Research.
componenttext: And we do have time for one more question. We will go next to Nancy Bush with NAB Research.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a funding question, and it's kind of tags on to Marty's question. In past cycles, you guys have been big issuers of CD. some of your funding has been more CD dependent in past years, and then you sort of backed away from CDs. What's the sort of CD
componenttext: I have a funding question, and it's kind of tags on to Marty's question. In past cycles, you guys have been big issuers of CD. some of your funding has been more CD dependent in past years, and then you sort of backed away from CDs. What's the sort of CD philosophy going into the rate rise cycle? It seems that you are already doing some CD specials in some markets, and I just wanted to see how your CD funding philosophy may have changed.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Nancy, as well as you know, our company, you recall that our company was built with a lot of mergers of small community banks and trust that had a huge portion of their funding from CDs. And so as we layer in these acquisitions, we're constantly in the
componenttext: So Nancy, as well as you know, our company, you recall that our company was built with a lot of mergers of small community banks and trust that had a huge portion of their funding from CDs. And so as we layer in these acquisitions, we're constantly in the process of rationalizing those deposit structures because a good portion of those CD portfolios that we inherent each time are really, really price-sensitive portfolios. And as we bring the pricing more in line with our normal pricing, a fair amount of those CD portfolios tend to exit. So that's why you've seen a kind of relative decline in CD financing over the last few years. You'll see some more of that as we think through, excuse me, just [ph] National Penn, although the price variation for them is not as different as it has been in some of our acquisitions in the past. We think CDs are necessary and important part of our ongoing funding structure. There's a portion of that portfolio that is kind of core bread-and-butter, fully committed clients that we always keep, and we're willing to pay little more to keep those because they're long-term stable users of our services. On the other hand, you always have the ones that are single-service clients, and they're shopping 15 banks and go on to the one that has highest space for CD, and we don't tend to keep those. So I suspect those rates go up, you will see our CD portfolio increase some, but it won't be as dramatic as you may think because we are growing our DDA and all the funding sources at a very fast pace, and so that we intentionally are not as CD dependent as we've been in the past. So I don't -- it depends on the company, but with our variety of funding sources, I don't think CD financing for us in the future will be what it was in the past.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
