headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. And it is now my pleasure to introduce host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. And it is now my pleasure to introduce host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ebony, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Hammond Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the resu
componenttext:
Thank you, Ebony, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. 
We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Hammond Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the first quarter of '16. We have with us other members of the executive management team who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; Clarke Starnes, Chief Risk Officer; and Ricky Brown, Community Banking President. 
We will be referencing a slide presentation during our comments. A copy of the presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on the BB&T website. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings expectations or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations. BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary statements regarding forward-looking information and our presentation and our SEC filings. 
Please also note that our presentation includes certain on GAAP disclosures. Please refer to Page 2 and the appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP. 
And now I'll turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everybody, and thank you very much for taking time to join our call. Overall, we had what I call a solid quarter with nice increase in net income and record net interest income. Net income was $527 million, up 8% versu
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everybody, and thank you very much for taking time to join our call. 
Overall, we had what I call a solid quarter with nice increase in net income and record net interest income. Net income was $527 million, up 8% versus first quarter and 20% annualized versus the fourth, so a solid performance. Diluted EPS was $0.67 which is flat to the first quarter of '15, but was up an annualized 18.9% versus the fourth quarter. 
GAAP ROA was 1.09%. GAAP ROTCE was 13.87%. And if you adjust for mergers or charges only, adjusted ROA was 1.12% and adjusted return on tangible common was 14.2%, so solid returns there. 
In terms of revenues, we had strong revenue growth despite really some challenges in the mortgage banking income and service charges on deposits. So revenues totaled $2.6 billion, which was up 10.2% versus the first quarter and 4.2% annualized versus the fourth. 
We had record net interest income, as I indicated, of $1.6 billion, up 16.4% versus the first and 6.8% annualized versus the fourth. I'm really happy about the fact net interest margin grew 3-point -- to 3.43%, up 8 percent -- up 8 basis points [indiscernible]. Daryl will give more color on that. 
nice, small but nice, improvement in efficiency to 58 3% from 58.8%. Noninterest expenses are very well managed, decreased $52 million or 13.1% annualized, and we did have positive operating leverage. 
Our average loans were down slightly versus fourth quarter, but keep in mind, we continue to adjust our mix by letting our lower spread mortgage balances and sales finance portfolios decline. We are improving our profitability in those areas, so that strategy's working, but it's not just producing loan volume increases. Keep in mind, we also have runoff in our Susquehanna portfolio, and we have a seasonal slower growth in a number of our specialized businesses. So average loans and leases for the quarter were $134.4 billion. if you exclude lower mortgage runoff and sales finance loans, loans held for investment grew 2.2%, which is kind of the number we look at. That was led by a good performance in income-producing properties, direct retail, other lending subsidiaries on our dealer floor plan.
In terms of our strategic highlights, I would point out we did convert Susquehanna in November. We've seen reductions in FTEs, other cost savings. Overall, it is going very well. 
We did complete our acquisition of National Penn on April 1. That -- we'll be converting that most likely in mid-July. That's going very well. Scott , the CEO of National Penn is now the Group President for our northern regions. He's off to a fast start. I feel really good about his leadership and the teams that we have in that area. 
We did complete our acquisition of Swett & Crawford on April 1. This is an outstanding Company, 100-year-old company with a great brand. That's $200 million in revenue. Keep in mind, and this is a little complex, but last year very importantly from a strategic point of view, we sold American [indiscernible] because it was outside of our risk appetite. And now we've effectively completed that process by replacing it with Swett & Crawford. So we've got the revenue back in virtually no-risk basis. So that completes that transition, and we're feeling really good about it. The key now of course in insurance services including Swett & Crawford is to get cost savings and overall improvement in margins.
Before I further address the points here, I just want to make a few important key strategic points. 
So with regard to M&A, as I said, things are going well. After we announced National Penn, we said we would take a pause. All of the deals that we have, we're really excited about. Texas for example where we acquired those branches from Citigroup, Ricky and I were down a couple of weeks ago in Dallas and Houston. And we could not be more pleased in terms of how we've been received and how well things are going. And frankly, overall Texas market is very, very vibrant, notwithstanding questions around energy. It's considered to be an outstanding market with about 29 million people, [indiscernible] 1,000 people a day is. So it's a fantastic market. We're pretty excited about what's going on in northern Kentucky and [indiscernible]. Susquehanna is off to good start. National Penn is just getting started, but it has enormous opportunities on synergies with Susquehanna and the overall revenue opportunities in Pennsylvania. 
So we feel overall really good about our merger strategy, but now is the time for us to focus on the enormous opportunity that we have to improve performance in the areas of investments we have made for the last several years. So I want to be clear, our focus is not on strategic deals, but on improving our profitability through basically 2 areas which we want you to expect: expense management and revenue enhancement. expense management area, we will be focusing on the cost synergies in the community bank, Primarily the Pennsylvania area, we've done a lot of aggressive Community Bank over the last few years, but still small [ph] particularly in Pennsylvania. We have a really good opportunity to rationalize huge investment we've made in the back room in terms of processes and procedures. We spent a fortune in the last several years building all that up. Now is the time to rationalize that. In terms of digital transformation, while we will be increasing our investment in digital transformation, it's also an opportunity to overall become more efficient as you link the front room and the back room. And that's what our recent executive management changes is designed to do. So we think that will be a combination revenue enhancements, expense reduction. Then of course, huge opportunities for insurance integration, particularly in Swett & Crawford.
On the revenue side, we'll continue to get huge revenue enhancements from our Community Bank. The rate of momentum improvement there, particularly our new markets, is exponential. We feel very excited about that. We will continue really, really strong performance in wealth, corporate banking, insurance and others. 
So given our intense focus on realizing new benefits from our previous strategic investments, I'll start [ph] with purchases or buybacks move up in priority as we think about CCAR 16 versus strategic initiatives. I'd be happy to answer questions later with regard to that, but we wanted to assure you know where we are strategically. 
If you turn to Page 4, I'll just mention a couple of items that are unusual this quarter. We did have merger, it was about $23 million or $0.02 negative effect on EPS. We did take securities gains of about $45 million, which is a part of our strategy in terms of matching of security gains and credit issues. So that was a $0.04 positive. And then the energy-related provision in excess of charge-offs was $28 million or $0.02.
Now with regard to energy credits, the provision exceeded charge-offs by $30 million or $0.03 as I indicated. also give a lot of data on this. But I just want to point out that the charge we took does reflect the new regulatory guidelines and the recent results. So while it's possible that we do have some energy negative, we do not expect that. We think we built a significant allowance, and we think we should expect our provision to be lower in the second quarter. So we feel frankly really good. It's a relatively small part of our old portfolio, about 1.3%, but I know that's a big interest area. And Clarke will be glad to give detail on that later, but we feel really good about that.
If you look at the loan area, we feel really good about loan growth relative to the economy. Just a couple of comments about the economy, it is what I would call good, but not great. It's okay. It's rocking along like it's been rocking along, 2% to 2.5%. It vary a little bit quarter-to-quarter, but we -- the United States economy sustained 2% to 2.5% kind of growth pattern. It will stay that way, in my humble opinion, for a good while. 
We see no practical possibilities of recession, notwithstanding the fact that there's been a lot of conversation about that. and the reason is we think there is a very, very strong, solid, pent-up need for continuing investment. When I talk to businesspeople, they are in investing in a way that I call passive investment. That is to say, they're not excited enough about the future to go out and make major expansions and so forth. But they're driving trucks that have 250,000 miles on it. They've got 10-year-old equipment. And so stuff just wears out. so that's why you have to keep investing. 
So that creates kind of a floor on the economy, in my view. It is an upside if we were to get better positive leadership out of D.C. and make some changes in regulation, et cetera. But assuming that's not taking place occasionally, we think there's a solid 2% to 2.5%. 
I would point out that I saw some numbers recently that suggested that most of our markets in the mid-Atlantic Southeast will be growing 1 point to 1.5 points faster than the national average. So being in the mid-Atlantic and Southeast is still good place to be. 
So we are focused on, as I said, profitability in our portfolio. We believe profitable loan growth is more important than absolute loan growth. 
just a little bit more detail with regard to the loan area. C&I loans were down slightly, mostly due to decline in commercial loans in the branch network and mortgage warehouse. On the other hand, end of period loans were better, with C&I up 2.5% annualized. Good news is C&I spreads are stable compared to last quarter. Growth is affected by our strategies position growth and multifamily reach. So we continue to be pretty conservative. kind of expect the C&I to grow at a faster pace in the second quarter probably in the mid-single digits. Daryl will also give you more a lot of color on energy, as I pointed out, but I'd emphasize that we built our reserves and we are confident that our exposures are managed.
CRE growth was essentially flat, with a decline in consortium and a growth in income-producing. So on income-producing, they increased 7% annualized, feel really good about that, fastest growth coming from office and hospitality, and some small decline in retail. And the good news there is market fundamentals generally continued to improve, although spreads are still tight. We expect CRE construction and development to continue to decline somewhat in the second quarter and IPP to grow at a similar pace with the first quarter. 
Dealer floor plan had a very good quarter, up $76 million or 26% annualized. That's been driven by expansion in our new markets and some new lines that we've introduced. That's going very well. So floor plan is expected to continue to grow double digits for this year. 
Average direct retail lending is [indiscernible] for us, increasing $211 million [ph] or almost 8% annualized. A lot of that is HELOC and direct auto from the branches. Ricky and his team had really made a sea change in terms of our credit consumer production of the branches. 
On other hand, wealth division continues to make significant contribution in retail lending, good production as they work closely together. So we expect retail lending to continue to grow in a similar pace. 
Average sales finance, primarily large prime auto, declined $484 million or 18%. That's a continuation of our execution of our flat-rate compensation program. That is going well. It doe s produce less volume, but it produces good [ph] margins. so we feel really good about that. The lines across in terms of the old portfolio running off new portfolio have stabilized. We do have a continued runoff portfolio for a bit longer. And so overall, we think once we get through next quarter, so that will follow, be kind of flattish and then start to grow. 
Residential mortgage loans are down $470 million or 16% linked quarter annualized. So keep in mind, we continue to sell essentially all of our conforming production. And we think again, that's in terms of overall quality management of the balance sheet.  Originations in the quarter were $3.6 billion, about 2% more than the fourth. That was reflected in some seasonal product and application volume. I was glad to see it increase 39% compared to the fourth and totaled $2 billion [ph]. So we're definitely seeing a resurgence in new home purchases. Young people are back buying homes again, and that's a really good thing. Our margins on gain on sale improved about 9%, best level since first quarter of '15.  So looking forward, we believe this portfolio decline will slow and be about flat for the year. 
Other lending subsidiaries continue to do well. They grew $158 million or 5%, but keep in mind, that's a weak quarter and back stronger in the second. they had really good performance in Grandbridge and equipment financing. we would expect a seasonally stronger other lending segment to accelerate in the second quarter because of seasonality. 
So overall, the average loans were -- are expected to be up 1% to 3% on a core basis next quarter. Obviously, with the impact the National Penn, growth will be closer to 20%. And I will point out that is real growth, that's real assets, but we would like to distinguish between organic and core growth. average loans in the second quarter are expected to be about $141 billion.
So if you look at Slide 6, overall deposit program going very well. Deposit mix continues to improve. We continue to do a good job of managing cost of interest-bearing deposits with costs going down -- up only 1 basis points even though we had the rate increase at the end of the year. So average total deposits increased $1.4 billion or 3.7% annualized. And that's a really good growth rate, given our intense focus on managing our costs. 
So let me turn it to Daryl now for a bit more color on some of the numbers.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today I'm going to talk about credit quality, interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Overall credit quality outside the energy portfolio remains stable
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today I'm going to talk about credit quality, interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Overall credit quality outside the energy portfolio remains stable. Net charge-offs totaled $154 million or 46 basis points. Excluding energy-related losses of $30 million, net charge-offs improved from the prior quarter to 37 basis points. 
Loans 90 days or more past due declined $26 million, mostly driven by loans acquired from the FDIC, impaired loans and a decrease in residential mortgage. Loans 30 to 89 days past due decreased $205 million or 20%, mostly due to seasonality in regional acceptance as well as decreases in residential mortgage, finance, C&I and CRE. 
NPAs increased 27% to 42 basis points, driven by $206 million in energy-related credits moved to nonaccrual. If you exclude energy, NPAs totaled 33 basis points, a modest improvement compared to fourth quarter levels. We're about halfway through our spring redetermination period. 
We expect NPAs to remain in a similar range in the second quarter, assuming no unexpected impact from that process. We expect net charge-offs to be in the range of 35 basis points to 45 basis points. 
Continuing on Slide 8. Our energy portfolio consists of 100 clients with $1.6 billion in outstanding, consisting of 65% upstream, 27% midstream and 8% in support services. And the coal portfolio totals $250 million outstanding. 
We take a very conservative approach to energy lending. We do not lend to offshore producers, mezzanine and second lien facilities or take equity positions. 
During the quarter, we fully implemented a regulatory guidance. The allocated reserves totaled 8.5%, and 44% of the energy portfolio was criticized and classified. It's important to know today, all borrowers are paying consistent with their agreements. As a result, we believe our energy portfolio is manageable.
Turning to Slide 9. Our allowance coverage ratios remained strong at 2.4x fora net charge-offs and 1.89x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loans ratio improved to 1.10% compared to 1.07% last quarter. Excluding the acquired portfolios, the allowance-to-loan ratio is 1.17%, so our effective allowance coverage is higher. Remember, our acquired loans have a combined mark of about $636 million. 
recorded a provision of $184 million for the quarter compared to net charge-offs of $154 million. This includes $3 million in net charge-offs related to the energy portfolio and an additional provision of $30 million to build the allowance to 8.5%.  
Looking forward, our provision is expected to match net charge-offs plus loan growth. We believe that the provision will be much lower than this quarter's numbers, assuming no large deterioration in credit quality.
Turning to Slide 10. Compared to last quarter, net interest margin was 3.43%, up 8 basis points. And core margin was 3.18%, up 6 basis points. The margin increase resulted from a seasonal interest income on assets related to postemployment benefits, duration adjustments on acquired securities, tighter repricing of variable-rate assets combined with stable deposit rates. 
Looking at the second quarter, assuming no Fed rate increases, we expect GAAP margin to decline a few basis points, driven by the runoff of TCI loans and the loss of a positive seasonal impact of interest income on benefit plans, offset by National Penn. We expect core margins to remain relatively stable. Asset sensitivity remains relatively unchanged. We continue to forecast only one interest rate hike this year happening in November.
Continue on Slide 11. Noninterest income totaled $1 billion, relatively flat compared to last quarter. The fee-income ratio was 40.6%. Looking at a few of those components, insurance income increased $39 million or 41% annualized, mostly due to seasonal factors, higher employee benefits and property/casualty commissions offset by lower life insurance commissions. Remember, our first quarter of last year included earnings of American Coastal, a business we sold last May. Excluding acquisitions, insurance income grew 1.9% versus last year. 
Mortgage banking income totaled $91 million, down $13 million mostly due to lower commercial mortgage production. Other income decreased $58 million due to a $43 million decrease in income related to assets of certain postemployment benefits and $14 million decline in client derivative income. 
Looking ahead to the second quarter, including both acquisitions, our total noninterest income is expected to increase 9% to 11% versus second quarter GAAP of $1.016 billion.
Turning to Slide 12, noninterest expenses totaled $1.5 billion, down 13% versus last quarter. Personnel expense increased $22 million, driven by a $34 million increase in Social Security and unemployment factors as well as equity-based compensation for retirement of eligible associates and a $10 million increase in higher pension expense, offset by $30 million decrease in postemployment benefits expense. 
Average FTEs declined 311. Merger-related and restructuring charges declined $27 million, mostly due to Susquehanna conversion costs. In addition, other expense decreased $34 million mostly due to lower operating charge-offs and charitable contributions. 
Our effective tax rate was 30%, and we expect second quarter effective tax rate to be about 31%. 
We expect expenses to total $1.75 billion next quarter. This include the initial expense base for National Penn and Swett & Crawford, plus $40 million to $50 million in merger-related costs. We expect cost savings to accelerate after the third quarter systems conversion of National Penn and the first quarter of 2017 conversion of Swett & Crawford. But in the second quarter, we may have a slight uptick in the efficiency ratio due to the timing of our acquisitions and delayed timing of related cost savings and synergies. We remain confident we will achieve cost savings related to both acquisitions. We expect efficiency to improve later in the year.
Turning to Slide 13. Capital ratios remained very health and fully phased-in common equity Tier 1 at 10.2%. Our LCR increased to 135%. And our liquid asset buffer at the end of the quarter was very strong at 14.5%.  We successfully issued $465 million of preferred stock at 5.625%, which strengthens our regulatory capital at a cost-effective way.  Our tangible book increased 2.7% this quarter. 
Finally, a comment on CCAR 2016. As Kelly mentioned, we expect to place greater priority in stock repurchases versus strategic initiatives. 
Now let's look at some segment results, beginning on Slide 14.
Community Bank's net income totaled $310 million, an increase of $38 million from last quarter and up $101 million from the first quarter of last year. Net interest income increased $64 million from the fourth quarter, with about 2/3 of the increase driven by Susquehanna.
Turning to Slide 15. Residential Mortgage net income totaled $39 million, down $10 million from last quarter, driven by seasonally lower production and lower servicing fee income. production mix was 55% purchased and 45% refi. 
Looking to Slide 16. The other Financial Services totaled $42 million, essentially flat as declines in segment net interest income was offset by lower loan processing expense. Regional Acceptance continues to generate stable loan growth with prudent underwriting discipline. This portfolio totals $3.3 billion, and losses have normalized to the 8% range. Net charge-offs for the prime portfolio remain excellent at 16 basis points.
Turning to Slide 17, specialized Lending net income totaled $56 million, down $7 million from last quarter, driven by lower commercial mortgage and leasing income and higher provision.
Turning to Slide 18. Insurance Services net income totaled $53 million, up $17 million from last quarter, mostly driven by a seasonal increase in employee benefits and higher property and casualty commissions, partially offset by seasonally lower life insurance commissions. We expect Swett & Crawford to add revenues of approximately $160 million for the remainder of this year, coupled with $140 million in expenses. In 2017, we will realize synergies from the deal that will drive improved operating margins going forward.
Turning to Slide 19. Financial Services segment had $26 million in net income, down $77 million from last quarter, largely driven by a provision increase of $92 million related to energy portfolio. Corporate Banking generated 15% loan growth, and wealth had 6% loan growth along with 29% transaction deposit growth.
In summary, for the quarter, we achieved improved efficiency, net interest margin expansion, positive operating leverage. we feel that we are set up to have a very strong second half of 2016. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing remarks and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Daryl. So overall, we feel like our M&A strategy is executing very, very well. Loan growth is good, particularly in the environment. Credit quality is very good x energy. And energy relative to the marketplace is extremely good. And so we feel
componenttext:
Thank you, Daryl. So overall, we feel like our M&A strategy is executing very, very well. Loan growth is good, particularly in the environment. Credit quality is very good x energy. And energy relative to the marketplace is extremely good. And so we feel that now we have a really wonderful opportunity to focus on realizing the advantages that we invested in for a number of years now. So we feel really good about our opportunity to improve efficiencies and our operating profit as we go forward. So we continue to believe our best days are ahead. 
So we will turn it over to Alan.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Matt O'Connor.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so starting on the cost saves. Can you just remind us how is still come from all the deals that have closed? And then will these fall to the bottom line? Or are there some offsets as we think about, call it, core BB&T or legacy BB&T?
componenttext: Okay, so starting on the cost saves. Can you just remind us how is still come from all the deals that have closed? And then will these fall to the bottom line? Or are there some offsets as we think about, call it, core BB&T or legacy BB&T?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, if you go back a year or plus ago, the Citi branches and Bank of Kentucky, all those are basically come in both cost savings and revenues and all that. From Susquehanna's perspective, we are probably 85% to 90% through the cost saves from that. S
componenttext: So Matt, if you go back a year or plus ago, the Citi branches and Bank of Kentucky, all those are basically come in both cost savings and revenues and all that. From Susquehanna's perspective, we are probably 85% to 90% through the cost saves from that. So the rest of the cost saves will probably bleed into our run rate over the next couple of quarters or as Canadian banking area. That's where we stand there. As far as the 2 deals that just closed April 1, there's really no cost saves in those transactions. We expect National Penn have a systems conversion third quarter. So you might see a little bit in the third quarter, but more of that in the fourth quarter and first quarter. And Swett & Crawford, maybe a little bit of revenue synergies this year, but their systems conversion is the first part of '17. And their cost saves and efficiencies will come in from probably the first half of '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the revenue side, I mean bigger picture like how should we think about what areas you're trying to cross-sell just broader mid-Atlantic franchise? I see there's a scale benefit. what are products that do you think co
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the revenue side, I mean bigger picture like how should we think about what areas you're trying to cross-sell just broader mid-Atlantic franchise? componenttext: So Matt, we think that the number is kind of pervasive, but the standout ones are continuing to expand the benefits from our Corporate Banking relationships. And recall over the last several years, we've been starting those relationships on the credit side. And the follow-on residual benefits in terms of deposits and other fees services coming. So that will be a big one. Wealth Management continues to integrate very, very well in terms of loan balances and other fee balances are coming in. Retail banking, retail lending is coming on very, very strong. And then the key benefit from the insurance area as we Swett & Crawford and continue to integrate Swett & Crawford and continue to use cross-sell abilities throughout entire Community Bank in terms of selling life insurance. All of those are some of the ones that are really big standouts.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we will end up this year with improvement. It may be in the 57-ish kind of range. We feel pretty confident about that. we think over the next 2 to 3 years, we'll get to mid-50s. I know some people talk about the low 50s. That's not going to h
componenttext: Yes, I think we will end up this year with improvement. It may be in the 57-ish kind of range. We feel pretty confident about that. we think over the next 2 to 3 years, we'll get to mid-50s. I know some people talk about the low 50s. That's not going to happen unless you get a substantial ramp-up in the yield curve. Remember, this is a numerator, denominator problem. So we're assuming that the economy will grow at 2% to 2.5%. There be slow ramp-up in the yield curve, not dramatic. Therefore, it makes it harder to grind out efficiency improvements. Still though, the opportunities we have to generate additional revenues out of our investment we've made an to be able to generate additional efficiencies from investment we've made, we think be able to hit those targets.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our strategy is, in terms of capital employment, remain the same. we've always said they are adjusting from time to time. The ones who don't change, you always use capital to get the nice organic growth you can get. Number two has been and will remain
componenttext: So our strategy is, in terms of capital employment, remain the same. we've always said they are adjusting from time to time. The ones who don't change, you always use capital to get the nice organic growth you can get. Number two has been and will remain dividends. It swings between buybacks and M&A. So what I was leading to is the flip there going forward for a while in terms of buybacks and in terms of M&A as we focus in realizing these opportunities. Now with regard to the dividends, we hope, I mean, our CCAR application is in June. as you know, we never can say for sure what's going to happen, but we would expect to have a dividend increase. Because even though our dividend payout's somewhat high, it's not high by traditional standards and it's not high relative to the stable revenues that we have. So we're very comfortable with the dividend increase this year.

componenttext: Yes, Mike, this is Clarke Starnes. I will tell you that we have been methodically reducing our exposure in the coal space for a long time. We opportunistically exited one of our larger legacy watch list coal credits and get it out completely. So we feel that what's left, we can manage through. Although the watch list could go up, we feel like the exposure's manageable.

componenttextpreview: So we made a decision, Betsy, sometime ago to be a long-term player in the energy market. We're not willing to change that long-term strategy. Energy is an important business for the country, for the world and for us. We have entered into relationships in
componenttext: So we made a decision, Betsy, sometime ago to be a long-term player in the energy market. We're not willing to change that long-term strategy. Energy is an important business for the country, for the world and for us. We have entered into relationships in a very conservative selection basis and a conservative underwriting basis. Obviously, everybody's really energized about -- no pun intended -- about concerns about energy now, but -- and we're taking a very serious and we've marketing aggressively and all that. Look, I think there's a much higher chance of oil to be at 50 by the end of this year than 30. And I think over the long term, the energy business will really be a good business and we will stick with it. And we will stick with our clients, and we'll continue to be supportive to them.

componenttext: And so do I have that correct that if oil were to be at 30 for a while that, you've already done all the reserving that you need to do? componenttext: Absolutely, Betsy. We believe that produce [indiscernible] once we get something totally unforeseen would be much lower than last quarter. remind , we kind of said our NCO guidance was 35 to 45. We would assume that we'll be able to mid-range of that if we don't have an energy surprise. If we have more energy deterioration, it might be mid- to high. So we, as Daryl said, we're expecting to fund charge-offs and keep our reserve for growth. So that would -- we've not expect a larger build for the second quarter. So in that 8.5%, we've assumed I think prudently, conservatively, to all assumptions. And we fully implemented the guidance, so we would not anticipate from here a significant increase in the provision. I would mention, too, we've been through about 60% of our spring redeterminations already. Our average line reductions were about 20%, and about 2/3 of those redeterminations we've done structural enhancement with provisions are more collateral. So I think to your -- to Kelly's point, we're working with these borrowers. And we certainly have the reserve what we know today.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at National Penn and Swett & Crawford, those 2 add in approximately $100 million to 110 million in expenses in the second quarter off of our base. And if add maybe an additional $30 million more in expense saves, then that leaves about $60 million left approximately. And I would say though second quarter usually we have higher revenue, so you pay out higher commissions, that's a percentage there. And then probably the next biggest increase we have is probably technology and IT. We continue to invest in those areas, and those areas continue to increase some. But I feel that we're very focused on expenses. I think we have a check and maybe exceeding what we're saying, beating it. But right now, we're just putting out conservative numbers from an expense base. But as Kelly said, will focus on improving efficiency throughout the year. But with all these acquisitions closing first in this quarter, it's just going to be really messy trying to put it all together.

componenttextpreview: This question maybe is more for Clarke. Clearly, BB&T has done a very good job in improving its credit quality post the financial crisis. And BB&T, along with many of the other banks, all have built up the reserves this quarter for the energy SNC exam tha
componenttext: This question maybe is more for Clarke. Clearly, BB&T has done a very good job in improving its credit quality post the financial crisis. And BB&T, along with many of the other banks, all have built up the reserves this quarter for the energy SNC exam that took place very recently. And so the question is, what do the regulators do that was so different that none of the banks have anticipated back in the fourth quarter? I know energy prices fell to below $30 in February. But were they doing stuff that's just unusual and we had not seen before, which forced everybody to build up these reserves?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Gerard, what I think with the fundamentals, in my opinion, the fundamental change in the guidance historically is surveys lending asset classifications, status, impairment view was based more from a senior secured collateral asset base coverage st
componenttext: I think Gerard, what I think with the fundamentals, in my opinion, the fundamental change in the guidance historically is surveys lending asset classifications, status, impairment view was based more from a senior secured collateral asset base coverage standpoint against that primary bank debt. What's happened with this boom in the shale production with this cycle is you have a lot more secondary bond financing behind the bank route. And then the regulatory guidance is very explicit around you have to make sure that you have sufficient cash flow coverage and asset coverage for the total debt, including the secondary debt. obviously with the plunge in prices that nobody could have predicted, it puts enormous pressure on those ratios. So that's really the big sea change. We still believe given all that, with enough time and with some recovery of the crisis, that we'll have a good shot at getting having better recoveries, but we have to reserve in the meantime.

componenttext: Okay. And then Kelly, looking at your Slide 11 in the presentation you focused on the fee-income ratio, it's dropped down quite a bit. And one of the hallmarks of your company has always been 45% or so fee revenue to total revenue. Is this a new change that we're going to be seeing it close to 40%? Or is this a temporary change?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Gerard. this is more temporary. I think that we've had a range of 41%, 42%. 45% is kind of high frankly, but we think in terms of 42%, 43% is kind of normal. We don't like it too far out of balance one way or the other, so -- And it depends on again,
componenttext: No, Gerard. this is more temporary. I think that we've had a range of 41%, 42%. 45% is kind of high frankly, but we think in terms of 42%, 43% is kind of normal. We don't like it too far out of balance one way or the other, so -- And it depends on again, the interest rate environment. So if your interest rates go down, then your [indiscernible] goes up as a percentage. On a normalized basis, I'm comfortable with our noninterest income, meaning we're on the 41%, 42%, 43% kind of level right now. So you've got rates that you and net interest income being down, which would drive ratio up. On the other hand, insurance is not at the level that it would be relatively because of the pace of business, and so that would affect it. and the temporary impact have been the removal of American Coastal last year, which we come right back now when we had Swett & Crawford. so it's not a change from a long-term point at paid. be right where we wanted to be 42%, 43%. And then probably hopefully hanging at that level because hopefully, the net interest income comes back up.

componenttext: Yes, Paul, that's exactly right. We -- I'm not trying to say that wouldn't dare do any do something. But as a practical matter, we do not are not focusing M&A now in insurance or bank, which is our 2 primary areas. The truth is we've got a lot going on in both of them. we've [indiscernible]. And you know there's a time to buy and there's a time to run. And the last 24 months are the time to buy. Times were right. There was a window for us and good opportunities, and we're really happy about what we did. And now is the time to take some time and adjust to we've been done and run it really, really well and get the benefit, for benefit of our shareholders. I mean this is a shareholder-driven strategy building our profitability up and reaping some of the benefits of the investment we've made in those insurance and banking and basically everything else.

componenttext: John, this is Daryl. What I would say from a CCAR perspective obviously nothing is approved yet. But last several years, we've focused and we've traditionally been one of the higher ones on payout ratio on dividend. We hope that, that will continue with CCAR 2016. And as far as total payout ratio goes, I would say we like where our capital ratios are today. So as Kelly said, we're going to probably use 25-plus percent out in capital for organic growth. So the remaining percentage would probably be in buyback.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay, all right. And separately, Kelly, I just want to get a little bit more color on the change in tone that front in terms of looking at more of the buyback opportunity with capital deployment versus M&A. Was there anything also prompted the change in terms of either regulatory environment and -- or anything in terms of your the trend in your efficiency that you're trying to get on top of something here?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's really a matter of looking at the number of deals. Ideally, to be honest, we wouldn't have done as many deals in the short period of time as we did. It's just they were available, and you can't -- I wish you could, but you can't ideally lay out
componenttext: John, it's really a matter of looking at the number of deals. Ideally, to be honest, we wouldn't have done as many deals in the short period of time as we did. It's just they were available, and you can't -- I wish you could, but you can't ideally lay out your M&A plans on a linear basis and project them whenever you want to have them  They come when they come, and you take advantage of them -- when  they're there. So we -- we took a bit more in the last 1.5 years at one time [indiscernible]. And so when you combine that with all of the other activities we have [ph] 1 which investment in the back room in terms of systems and processes and so forth. And it's just my very strong intuitive judgment, collective team judgment, that it's time to focus on taking advantage of that we have. So sometimes, people think about M&A and all this as a kind of a linear sloping line. it's not. It's more like a stair step. You ramp up in terms of acquisitions. And that you take a period of time and you rationalize. And then you ramp up again. So we're in a latter part of the stair step where we're going to be focusing on rationalizing what we've invested. we think that's shareholder-friendly because if you just continually grow all of the time, you don't get any real payback until you stop growing and doing for a while, and that's not fair to the shareholders. So this is more about taking advantage of what we did in the last 1.5 years. We'll get that done, we'll be interested in M&A again. But for right now, we're focused on getting the advantages of what we've already done.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Well, what I would say is right now, we would be forecasting margin probably be in the low 3 40s probably for -- throughout 2016. a rate hike that we have in November, helps us but it's not a huge impact in the fourth quarter, so it's -- we're not assuming real rate rise all . we feel about our mix. the mix is going in our favor, loan mix, mix. spreads are coming in nicely. core margin stabilized. So I feel GAAP margin in the 3 40s, low 3 40s is about right.

componenttext: We'll move next to Kevin Parker with Piper Jaffray.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding net interest income and your expectations going forward, you're modeling a rate hike. How are you looking at the long end of the yield curve at same time?
componenttext: Regarding net interest income and your expectations going forward, you're modeling a rate hike. How are you looking at the long end of the yield curve at same time?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Kevin. So the rate hike is in November, so really doesn't have a huge impact net interest income. If you look at the yield curve, we would keep our yield curve relatively constant to where it is today. We don't really think it's going to st
componenttext: Good question, Kevin. So the rate hike is in November, so really doesn't have a huge impact net interest income. If you look at the yield curve, we would keep our yield curve relatively constant to where it is today. We don't really think it's going to steepen up much in our forecast that we have. If you look at our balance sheet, our balance sheet is pretty balanced. About half of our assets are floating, right, half are fixed. So when the curve actually came down some in the early part of 2016, the fixed portion [indiscernible] a little bit [indiscernible] from net interest income perspective because those up the yield curve. But we did a great job with our funding costs, keeping that very stable. All that's very sticky. We're having huge growth in funding and wider margins deposit franchise right now.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned that Regional Acceptance had charge-off rate of 7.9%. the prime book is roughly 19 basis points, which is very good. How does that compare to the year-over-year numbers and the quarter-over-quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned that Regional Acceptance had charge-off rate of 7.9%. the prime book is roughly 19 basis points, which is very good. How does that compare to the year-over-year numbers and the quarter-over-quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, this is Clarke. Regional Acceptance losses are up year-over-year, so they're probably 50 to 75 basis points or so. Our prime portfolio today is about 16 basis points, not 19 and is relatively stable quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So while i
componenttext: Kevin, this is Clarke. Regional Acceptance losses are up year-over-year, so they're probably 50 to 75 basis points or so. Our prime portfolio today is about 16 basis points, not 19 and is relatively stable quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So while it's very manageable, Regional Acceptance had experienced some higher loss severities, lower , primarily front end economy cars. If you look at Mannheim over the last year or 18 months, that class of vehicles has been hit a little harder. We've adjusted for that over the last year or so. And we are actually forecasting, notwithstanding the view of car prices over the next -- remainder of the year, we expect losses to be down more in the 7% range or so by the end of the year at Regional.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What Would cause that decline in charge-offs, given we're continuing to see pressure in the used car prices?
componenttext: What Would cause that decline in charge-offs, given we're continuing to see pressure in the used car prices?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, absolutely, it's the adjustments we made, what we made 12 to 18 months ago on our advance rates. And as those burned through, we believe would be in a much better severity position, even with the decline of prices. We've been waiting in to turn a lowe
componenttext: No, absolutely, it's the adjustments we made, what we made 12 to 18 months ago on our advance rates. And as those burned through, we believe would be in a much better severity position, even with the decline of prices. We've been waiting in to turn a lower advance rate, so we feel like we'll be -- older credits and would be in a better position.

componenttext: On a year-over-year basis, Amanda, I think I feel very comfortable that we'll have 12-plus percent growth of NII year-over-year basis, 16 to 15.

componenttext: Okay, yes. So purchase accounting, so what I could tell you is that on the Susquehanna accounting, it is starting to come off a little bit. But we have National Penn that have the first time for -- go on for this quarter. So purchase accounting is going to be pretty robust for most of this year. It will trend down over time. But '16, I feel very comfortable that GAAP margin will be in the low 3 40s, second, third, fourth quarters. And core margin, we feel is stabilized, starting to improve some. So that could actually get into the low 3 20s.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. And it is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. And it is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ebony, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for
componenttext:
Thank you, Ebony, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. 
We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the first quarter of '16. We also have with us other members of executive management who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; Clarke Starnes, Chief Risk Officer; and Ricky Brown, Community Banking President. 
We will be referencing a slide presentation during our comments. A copy of the presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on the BB&T website. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings predictions or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations. BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary statements regarding forward-looking information in our presentation and our SEC filings. 
Please also note that our presentation includes certain non-GAAP disclosures. Please refer to Page 2 and the Appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP. And now I will turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everybody, and thank you very much for taking time to join our call. Overall, we had what I call a solid quarter with nice increase in net income and record net interest income. Net income was $527 million, up 8% versu
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everybody, and thank you very much for taking time to join our call. 
Overall, we had what I call a solid quarter with nice increase in net income and record net interest income. Net income was $527 million, up 8% versus the first quarter and 20% annualized versus the fourth, so a solid performance. Diluted EPS was $0.67, which was flat to the first quarter '15, but was up an annualized 18.9% versus the fourth quarter. 
GAAP ROA was 1.09%. GAAP ROTCE was 13.87%. And if you adjust for mergers charges only, adjusted ROA was 1.12% and adjusted return on tangible common was 14.2%. So solid returns there. 
In terms of revenues, we had strong revenue growth despite really some challenges in our mortgage banking income and service charges on deposits. So revenues totaled $2.6 billion, which was up 10.2% versus the first quarter and 4.2% annualized versus the fourth. 
We did have record net interest income, as I indicated, of $1.6 billion, up 16.4% versus the first and 6.8% annualized versus the fourth. Really happy about the fact net interest margin grew 3-point -- to 3.43%, up 8% or 8 basis points. And Daryl will you give more color on that. 
Had a nice -- small but nice, improvement in efficiency to 58.3% from 58.8%. Noninterest expenses were very well managed, decreased $52 million or 13.1% annualized, and we did have positive operating leverage. 
Our average loans were down slightly versus fourth quarter, but keep in mind, we continued to adjust our mix by letting our lower spread mortgage balances and sales finance portfolios decline. We are improving our profitability in those areas, so that strategy is working, but it's not just producing loan volume increases. Keep in mind, we also have runoff in our Susquehanna Hann portfolio, and we have a seasonal slower growth in a number of our specialized businesses. So average loans and leases for the quarter were $134.4 billion. And if you exclude our mortgage runoff and sales finance loans, our loans held for investment grew 2.2%, which is kind of the number that we look at. And that was led by a good performance in income-producing properties, direct retail, other lending subsidiaries on our dealer floor plan.
In terms of our strategic highlights, I would point out, we did convert Susquehanna in November. We've seen reductions in FTEs, other cost savings. Overall, it is going very well. 
We did complete our acquisition of National Penn on April 1. That -- we'll be converting that most likely in mid-July. That's going very well. Scott Fainor, the CEO of National Penn, is now the -- our Group President for our northern regions. He's off to a fast start. I feel really good about his leadership and the teams that we have in that area. 
We did complete our acquisition of Swett & Crawford on April 1. This is an outstanding company, 100-year-old company with a great brand. That's $200 million in revenue. Keep in mind, and this is a little complex, but last year very importantly from a strategic point of view, we sold American Coastal because it was outside our risk appetite. And now we've effectively completed that process by replacing it with Swett & Crawford. So we got the revenue back in a virtually no-risk basis. So that completes that transition, and we feel really good about it. The key now, of course, in insurance business, in particular, for Swett & Crawford, is to get cost savings and overall improvement in margins.
And now before I go through the rest of the points, I just want to make a few important key strategic points. 
So with regard to M&A, as I said, things are going well. After we announced National Penn, we said that we would take a pause. All of the deals that we have, we're really excited about. Texas, for example, where we acquired those branches from Citigroup, Ricky and I were down there a couple of weeks ago in Dallas and Houston. And we could not be more pleased in terms of how we're being received and how well things are going. And frankly, the overall Texas market is still very, very vibrant, notwithstanding the questions around energy. It's really an outstanding market of about 29 million people. It's growing 1,000 people a day. So it's a fantastic market. Really excited about what's going on in northern Kentucky and Cincinnati. Susquehanna, as I said, is off to a good start. National Penn is just getting started, but it has enormous opportunities of synergies with Susquehanna and in the overall revenue opportunities in Pennsylvania. 
So we feel overall really good about our merger strategy, but now is the time for us to focus on the enormous opportunities that we have to improve performance in the areas of investments that we have made for the last several years. So I want to be clear, our focus is not on strategic deals, but on improving our profitability through basically 2 areas, which is what you would expect, the expense management and revenue enhancement. In the expense management area, we will be focusing on the cost synergies in the Community Bank. Primarily, in the Pennsylvania area, we've done a lot in the rest of the Community Bank over the last few years, but there's still small opportunity, particularly in Pennsylvania. 
We have a really good opportunity to rationalize the huge investments we've made in the back room in terms of processes and procedures. We spent a fortune in the last several years building all that up. Now is the time to rationalize that. In terms of digital transformation, while we will be increasing our investment in digital transformation, there's also an opportunity to overall become more efficient as you link the front room and the back room. And that's what our recent executive management changes is designed to do. So we think that will be a combination revenue enhancement, expense reduction. And then, of course, there's huge opportunities for insurance integration, particularly in Swett & Crawford.
On the revenue side, we'll continue to get huge revenue enhancements from our Community Bank. The rate of momentum improvement there, particularly on our new markets, is exponential, so we feel very excited about that. We will continue really, really a strong performance in wealth, Corporate Banking, insurance and others. 
So given our intense focus on realizing new benefits from our previous strategic investments, our stock repurchases or buybacks move up in priority as we think about CCAR '16 versus strategic initiatives. I'd be happy to answer questions later with regard to that, but we wanted to make sure you are clear about where we are strategically. 
If you turn to Page 4, I'll just mention a couple of items that are unusual this quarter. We did have merger that was about $23 million or $0.02 negative effect on EPS. We did take security gains of about $45 million, which is a part of our strategy in terms of matching all security gains and credit issues. So that was a $0.04 positive. And then the energy-related provision in excess of charge-offs was $28 million or $0.02.
Now with regard to energy credits, the provision exceeded charge-offs by $30 million or $0.03, as I indicated. Daryl will give you a lot of detail on this, but I just want to point out that the charge that we took does reflect the new regulatory guidance and the recent SNC exam result. 
So while it's fairly possible that we do have some more energy negative, we do not expect that. We think we built a significant allowance, and we think we should expect our provision to be lower in the second quarter. So we feel, frankly, really good. It's a relatively small part of our whole portfolio, about 1.2%, but I know that's a big interest area. And Clarke will be glad to give more detail on that later, but we feel really good about that.
If you look at the loan area, we feel really good about loan growth relative to the economy. Just a couple of comments about the economy, it is what I would call good, but not great. It's okay. It's rocking along about like it's been rocking along, 2% to 2.5%. It will vary a little bit quarter-to-quarter, but we -- the United States economy is on a sustained 2% to 2.5% kind of growth pattern. It will stay that way, in my humble opinion, for a good while. 
We see no practical possibilities of recession, notwithstanding the fact there's been a lot of conversation about that. And the reason is because we think there is a very, very strong, solid pent-up need for continuing investment. When I talk to businesspeople, they are in investing in a way that I call a passive investment. That is to say, they're not excited enough about the future to go out and make major expansions and so forth, but they're driving trucks that have 250,000 miles on it. They got 10-year-old equipment, and so stuff just wears out. So that's why you have to keep investing. 
So that creates kind of a floor on the economy, in my view. There's an upside if we were to get better positive leadership out of D.C. and make some changes in taxes and regulation, et cetera. But assuming that's not going to take the place or case, we think there's a solid 2% to 2.5%. I would point out that I saw some numbers recently that suggested that most of our markets in the Mid-Atlantic Southeast will be growing 1 point to 1.5 points faster than the national average. So being in the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast is still a good place to be. 
So we are so focused on, as I said, profitability in our portfolio. We believe profitable loan growth is more important than absolute loan growth. 
So just a little bit more detail with regard to the loan area. C&I loans were down slightly, mostly due to decline in commercial loans in the branch network and mortgage warehouse. On the other hand, end-of-period loans were better, with C&I up 2.5% annualized. Good news is C&I spreads are stable compared to last quarter. Growth is affected, but our strategies on specific growth in multifamily and REITs, so we continue to be pretty conservative. We're kind of expecting C&I to grow at a faster pace in the second quarter, probably in the mid-single digits. Daryl is going to give you a lot more color on energy, as I pointed out, but I'll just emphasize again that we have built our reserves and we're very confident that our exposures are manageable.
CRE growth was essentially flat with a decline in consortium and our growth in income-producing. So in income-producing, net increased 7% annualized. Feel really good about that, fastest growth coming from office, hospitality, and some small decline in retail. The good news is market fundamentals generally continued to improve, although spreads are still tight. We expect CRE construction and development to continue to decline somewhat in the second quarter, and IPP to grow in similar pace within the first quarter. 
Dealer floor plan had a very strong quarter, up $76 million or 26% annualized. That's been driven by expansion in our new markets and some new lines that we've introduced, so that's going very well. So floor plan is expected to continue to grow in the double digits for this year. 
Average direct retail lending is a bright spot for us, increasing $211 million or almost 8% annualized. A lot of that is HELOC and direct auto from the branches. Ricky and his team had really made a sea change in terms of our credit consumer production out of the branches. 
On the other hand, our wealth division continues to make a significant contribution in retail lending, really good production as they work closely together. So we expect the retail lending to continue to grow at a similar pace. 
Our average sales finance, primarily large prime auto, $484 million or 18%. That's a continuation of our execution of our flat-rate compensation program. That is going well. It does produce less volume, but it produces better margins. And so we feel really good about that. The lines will cross in terms of the old portfolio running off new portfolio soon, so that will stabilize. We do have a contingent runoff of the Hann portfolio for a bit longer. And so overall, we think once we get through the next quarter, so that portfolio will be kind of flattish and then it will start to grow. 
Average residential mortgage loans are down $470 million or 16% linked quarter annualized. So keep in mind, we continue to sell essentially all of our conforming production. And we think, again, that's in terms of overall quality management of the balance sheet. Originations in the quarter were $3.6 billion, about 2% more than the fourth. That was reflected in some seasonal improvement. And application volume, I was glad to see, increased 39% compared to the fourth, in total $6.9 billion. So we definitely see a bit of resurgence in new home purchases. Young people are back buying homes again, and that's a really good thing. Our margins on gain of sale improved about 9%, best level since the first quarter of '15. So looking forward, we believe this portfolio decline will slow and be at about flat for the year. 
Our other lending subsidiaries continue to do well. They grew $158 million or 5%, but keep in mind, that's a weak quarter for them. They'll be back stronger in the second. They did really good performance in Grandbridge and equipment financing. So we would expect a seasonally stronger other lending segment to accelerate in the second quarter because of seasonality. 
So overall, the average loans were -- are expected to be up 1% to 3% on a core basis next quarter. Obviously, with the impact of National Penn, growth will be closer to 20%. And I will point out that is real growth. Those are real assets, but we'd like to distinguish between organic and core growth. So average loans in the second quarter are expected to be about $141 billion.
So if you look at Slide 6, overall deposit program is going very well. Our deposit mix continues to improve. We continue to do a really good job managing our cost of interest-bearing deposits with costs going down -- up only 1 basis points even though we had the rate increase at the end of the year. So average total deposits increased $1.4 billion or 3.7% annualized. And that's a really good growth rate given our intense focus on managing our costs. 
So let me turn it to Daryl now for -- give a bit more color on some of the numbers.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margins, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Overall credit quality outside the energy portfolio
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margins, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Overall credit quality outside the energy portfolio remains stable. Net charge-offs totaled $154 million or 46 basis points. Excluding energy-related losses at $30 million, net charge-offs improved from the prior quarter to 37 basis points. 
Loans 90 days or more past due declined $26 million, mostly driven by loans acquired from the FDIC, impaired loans and a decrease in residential mortgage. Loans 30 to 89 days past due decreased $205 million or 20%, mostly due to seasonality in Regional Acceptance as well as decreases in residential mortgage, sales finance, C&I and CRE. 
NPAs increased 27% to 42 basis points, driven by $206 million in energy-related credits moved to nonaccrual. If you exclude energy, NPAs totaled 33 basis points, a modest improvement compared to fourth quarter levels. We are about halfway through our spring redeterminations. We expect NPAs to remain in a similar range in the second quarter, assuming no unexpected impact from that process. We expect net charge-offs to be in the range of 35 basis points to 45 basis points. 
Continuing on Slide 8. Our energy portfolio consists of 100 clients with $1.6 billion in outstanding, consisting of 65% upstream, 27% midstream and 8% in support services. And the coal portfolio totals $215 million in outstandings. 
We take a very conservative approach to energy lending. We do not lend to offshore producers, mezzanine and second-lien facilities or take equity positions. During the quarter, we fully implemented the regulatory guidance from the SNC exam. The allocated reserves totaled 8.5%, and 44% of the energy portfolio was criticized and classified. It's important to note today, all borrowers are paying consistent with their agreements. As a result, we believe our energy portfolio is manageable.
Turning to Slide 9. Our allowance coverage ratios remain strong at 2.4x for net charge-offs and 1.89x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loans ratio improved to 1.10% compared to 1.07% last quarter. Excluding the acquired portfolios, the allowance-to-loan ratio is 1.17%, so our effective allowance coverage is higher. Remember, our acquired loans have a combined mark of about $636 million. 
We recorded a provision of $184 million for the quarter compared to net charge-offs of $154 million. This includes $30 million in net charge-offs related to the energy portfolio and an additional provision of $30 million to build the allowance to 8.5%. Looking forward, our provision is expected to match net charge-offs plus loan growth. We believe that the provision will be much lower than this quarter's numbers, assuming no large deterioration in credit quality.
Turning to Slide 10. Compared to last quarter, net interest margin was 3.43%, up 8 basis points, and core margin was 3.18%, up 6 basis points. The margin increase resulted from a seasonal interest income on assets related to postemployment benefits, duration adjustments on acquired securities, and higher repricing of variable rate assets combined with stable deposit rates. 
Looking at the second quarter, assuming no Fed rate increases, we expect GAAP margin to decline a few basis points driven by the runoff of PCI loans and the loss of a positive seasonal impact of interest income on benefit plans, offset by National Penn. We expect core margin to remain relatively stable. Asset sensitivity remains relatively unchanged. We continue to forecast only one interest rate hike this year happening in November.
Continuing on Slide 11. Noninterest income totaled $1 billion, relatively flat compared to last quarter. The fee income ratio was 40.6%. Looking at a few of those components, insurance income increased $39 million or 41% annualized, mostly due to seasonal factors, higher employee benefit and property/casualty commissions, offset by lower life insurance commissions. Remember, our first quarter of last year included earnings of American Coastal, a business we sold last May. Excluding acquisitions, insurance income grew 1.9% versus last year. 
Mortgage banking income totaled $91 million, down $13 million mostly due to lower commercial mortgage production. Other income decreased $58 million due to a $43 million decrease in income related to assets of certain postemployment benefits and $14 million decline in client derivative income. 
Looking ahead to the second quarter, including both acquisitions, our total noninterest income is expected to increase 9% to 11% versus second quarter GAAP of $1.016 billion.
Turning to Slide 12, noninterest expenses totaled $1.5 billion, down 13% versus last quarter. Personnel expense increased $22 million, driven by a $34 million increase in Social Security and unemployment factors as well as equity-based compensation for retirement-eligible associates and a $10 million increase in higher pension expense, offset by $30 million decrease in post-employment benefits expense. 
Average FTEs declined 311. Merger-related and restructuring charges declined $27 million, mostly due to Susquehanna conversion costs. In addition, other expense decreased $34 million mostly due to lower operating charge-offs and charitable contributions. Our effective tax rate was 30%, and we expect second quarter effective tax rate to be about 31%. 
We expect expenses to total $1.75 billion next quarter. This will include the initial expense base for National Penn and Swett & Crawford, plus $40 million to $50 million in merger-related costs. We expect cost savings to accelerate after the third quarter systems conversion of National Penn and the first quarter 2017 conversion of Swett & Crawford. But in the second quarter, we may have a slight uptick in the efficiency ratio due to the timing of our acquisitions and the delayed timing of related cost savings and synergies. We remain confident we will achieve cost savings related to both acquisitions. We expect efficiency to improve later in the year.
Turning to Slide 13. Capital ratios remain very health and fully phased-in. Common equity Tier 1 at 10.2%. Our LCR increased to 135%. And our liquid asset buffer at the end of the quarter was very strong at 14.5%.  We successfully issued $465 million in preferred stock at 5.625%, which strengthens our regulatory capital in a cost-effective way. Our tangible book increased 2.7% this quarter. 
Finally, a comment on CCAR 2016. As Kelly mentioned, we expect to place greater priority on stock repurchases versus strategic initiatives. 
Now let's look at some segment results, beginning on Slide 14.
Community Bank's net income totaled $310 million, an increase of $38 million from last quarter and up $101 million from the first quarter of last year. Net interest income increased $64 million from the fourth quarter, with about 2/3 of the increase driven by Susquehanna.
Turning to Slide 15. Residential mortgage net income totaled $39 million, down $10 million from last quarter, driven by seasonally lower production and lower servicing fee income. production mix was 55% purchased and 45% refi. 
Looking to Slide 16. Dealer Financial Services income totaled $42 million, essentially flat as declines in segment net interest income were substantially offset by lower loan processing expense. Regional Acceptance continues to generate stable loan growth with prudent underwriting discipline. This portfolio totals $3.3 billion, and losses have normalized to the 8% range. Net charge-offs for the prime portfolio remained excellent at 16 basis points.
Turning to Slide 17, Specialized Lending net income totaled $56 million, down $7 million from last quarter, driven by lower commercial mortgage and leasing income and higher provision.
Turning to Slide 18. Insurance Services net income totaled $53 million, up $17 million from last quarter, mostly driven by a seasonal increase in employee benefits and higher property and casualty commissions, partially offset by seasonally lower life insurance commissions. We expect Swett & Crawford to add revenues of approximately $160 million for the remainder of this year, coupled with $140 million in expenses. In 2017, we will realize synergies from the deal that will drive improved operating margins going forward.
Turning to Slide 19. Financial Services segment had $26 million in net income, down $77 million from last quarter, largely driven by a provision increase of $92 million related to the energy portfolio. Corporate Banking generated 15% loan growth, and wealth had 6% loan growth along with 29% transaction deposit growth.
In summary, for the quarter, we achieved improved efficiency, net interest margin expansion, positive operating leverage. And we feel that we are set up to have a very strong second half of 2016. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing remarks and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Daryl. So overall, we feel like our M&A strategy is executing very, very well. Loan growth is good, particularly in the environment. Credit quality is very good ex energy, and energy relative to the marketplace is extremely good. And so we feel
componenttext:
Thank you, Daryl. So overall, we feel like our M&A strategy is executing very, very well. Loan growth is good, particularly in the environment. Credit quality is very good ex energy, and energy relative to the marketplace is extremely good. And so we feel right now we have just this really wonderful opportunity to focus on realizing the advantages that we've invested in for a number of years now. So we feel really good about our opportunity to improve efficiencies and our operating profit as we go forward. So we continue to believe our best days are ahead. 
So now we will turn it over to Alan.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly. At this time, we will begin our Q&A session. Ebony, if you could please come back on the line and explain how our listeners can participate and ask questions?
componenttext: Thank you, Kelly. At this time, we will begin our Q&A session. Ebony, if you could please come back on the line and explain how our listeners can participate and ask questions?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
