componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Matt O'Connor.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So starting on the cost saves. Can you just remind us how much is still to come from all the deals that have closed? And then, will these fall to the bottom line? Or are there some offsets as we think about, call it, core BB&T or legacy BB&T?
componenttext: Okay. So starting on the cost saves. Can you just remind us how much is still to come from all the deals that have closed? And then, will these fall to the bottom line? Or are there some offsets as we think about, call it, core BB&T or legacy BB&T?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, if you go back a year-plus ago, the Citi branches and Bank of Kentucky, all those have basically come in, both cost saves and revenues and all that. From Susquehanna's perspectives, we are probably 85% to 90% through the cost saves from that. So
componenttext: So Matt, if you go back a year-plus ago, the Citi branches and Bank of Kentucky, all those have basically come in, both cost saves and revenues and all that. From Susquehanna's perspectives, we are probably 85% to 90% through the cost saves from that. So the rest of the cost saves will probably bleed in into our run rate over the next couple of quarters or out of the Community Bank area. But that's where we stand there. As far as the 2 deals that we just closed April 1, there's really no cost saves in those transactions. We expect National Penn had systems conversion third quarter. So you might see a little bit third quarter, but more of that in fourth quarter and first quarter. And Swett & Crawford, maybe a little bit on revenue synergies this year, but their systems conversion is the first part of '17, and their cost saves and efficiencies will come in probably in the first half of '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the revenue side, I mean, bigger picture, like how should we think about what areas you're trying to cross sell into just the broader Mid-Atlantic franchise? Obviously, there's the scale benefit. But what other produ
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the revenue side, I mean, bigger picture, like how should we think about what areas you're trying to cross sell into just the broader Mid-Atlantic franchise? Obviously, there's the scale benefit. But what other product sets do you think can get ramped up in that franchise? And when do we start seeing some of those benefits in a more meaningful manner?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, we think the number is kind of pervasive, but the standout ones are continuing to expand the benefits from our Corporate Banking relationships. Recall that over the last several years, we've been starting those relationships on the credit side, t
componenttext: So Matt, we think the number is kind of pervasive, but the standout ones are continuing to expand the benefits from our Corporate Banking relationships. Recall that over the last several years, we've been starting those relationships on the credit side, then the follow-on residual benefits in terms of deposits and other fee services come. So that will be a big one. Our wealth management continues to integrate very, very well in terms of loan balances and other fee balances that are coming in. Our retail banking, retail lending is coming on very, very strong. And then the huge benefit from the insurance area, as we integrate Swett & Crawford and continue to integrate Crump and continue to use the Crump cross-sell abilities throughout the entire Community Bank in terms of selling life insurance. All of those are some of the ones that are really big standouts.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take our next question from Michael Rose with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll now take our next question from Michael Rose with Raymond James.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I just wanted to touch on the efficiency ratio. You may not hit your target this year, but that's okay. You obviously notched another insurance acquisition. Can just give us your thoughts in light of the environment in terms of what we could expect
componenttext: Kelly, I just wanted to touch on the efficiency ratio. You may not hit your target this year, but that's okay. You obviously notched another insurance acquisition. Can just give us your thoughts in light of the environment in terms of what we could expect for the insurance or for the efficiency ratio, both maybe in the years to come and then longer term because of any changes?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we will end up this year with improvement. It may be in the 57-ish kind of range. We're pretty confident about that. We still think over the next 2 or 3 years, we'll get to mid-50s. And I know some people talk about the low 50s, that's not go
componenttext: Yes, I think we will end up this year with improvement. It may be in the 57-ish kind of range. We're pretty confident about that. We still think over the next 2 or 3 years, we'll get to mid-50s. And I know some people talk about the low 50s, that's not going to happen unless you get a substantial ramp-up in the yield curve. Remember, this is a numerator, denominator problem. So we're assuming that the economy will grow at 2%, 2.5%. There will be a slow ramp-up in the yield curve, but not dramatic. Therefore, it makes it harder to grind out efficiency improvements. Still though, with the opportunities we have to generate additional revenues out of our investments we've made and the ability to generate additional efficiencies from the investments we've made, we think we'll be able to hit those targets.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, how should we think about the dividend payout ratio going forward? You guys are trending a little higher than you have historically. You mentioned in the prepared remarks about CCAR being more focused on
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, how should we think about the dividend payout ratio going forward? You guys are trending a little higher than you have historically. You mentioned in the prepared remarks about CCAR being more focused on buybacks this year, but should we actually expect a dividend increase this year?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our strategy is in terms of capital deployment remain the same. But we've always said they adjust from time to time. The ones that don't change is, you always use capital base to get [indiscernible] some organic growth you can get. Number two has been
componenttext: So our strategy is in terms of capital deployment remain the same. But we've always said they adjust from time to time. The ones that don't change is, you always use capital base to get [indiscernible] some organic growth you can get. Number two has been and will remain dividends. The swing is between buybacks and M&A. So what I was leading to earlier is that the flip there for the -- going forward for a while in terms of buybacks they're more important than M&A as we focus on realizing these opportunities. Now with regard to dividends, we can certainly hope, I mean, our CCAR application is in. As you know, we never can say for sure what's going to happen, but we would certainly expect to have a dividend increase. Because even though our dividend payout is somewhat high, it's not high by traditional standards and it's not the high relative to the stable revenues still trends that we have. So we're very comfortable with the dividend increase this year.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just one final one for me. Just on your -- And I know it's small, but seeing your coal portfolio, I -- it seems like the criticized number of 15% seems a little low from what I would expect. Any sort of trends that give you confidence
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just one final one for me. Just on your -- And I know it's small, but seeing your coal portfolio, I -- it seems like the criticized number of 15% seems a little low from what I would expect. Any sort of trends that give you confidence that, that portfolio will -- the lost [ph] content will -- won't be a lot worse than maybe my expectations?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, this is Clarke Starnes. Fair question. I would tell you that we have been methodically reducing our exposure in the coal space for a long time. And we believe a number of the residual borrowers we have are bankable, although we would continue t
componenttext: Yes, Mike, this is Clarke Starnes. Fair question. I would tell you that we have been methodically reducing our exposure in the coal space for a long time. And we believe a number of the residual borrowers we have are bankable, although we would continue to expect the exposure to go down from here. We also took as part of that $30 million this quarter, we opportunistically exited one of our larger long time legacy watch list coal credits and got it out completely. So we feel like, what's left, we can manage through. Although the watch list could go up, we feel like the exposure is manageable.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: Right. Okay, got it. That's great. And then separately, as you're thinking about how the industry progresses from here, can you give us a sense as to how you work with your clients? Or is it too late for that, and what you have is, what you have?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Betsy, are you talking about primarily the energy area?
componenttext: Betsy, are you talking about primarily the energy area?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we made a decision, Betsy, sometime ago to be a long-term player in the energy market. We are not going to change that long-term strategy. Energy is an important business for the country, for the world and for us. We enter into relationships on a very
componenttext: So we made a decision, Betsy, sometime ago to be a long-term player in the energy market. We are not going to change that long-term strategy. Energy is an important business for the country, for the world and for us. We enter into relationships on a very conservative selection basis and a conservative underwriting basis. Obviously, everybody's really energized about -- no pun intended about -- concerns about energy now, but -- and we're taking it very seriously and we're marketing out a bit really aggressively and all that. But look, I think there's a much higher chance to [indiscernible] 50 by the end of this year and then 30. And I think over the long term, the energy business still will be a really good business. And so we will stick with it. And we will stick with our really good clients, and we'll continue to be supportive to them.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so -- and do I have it correct that if oil were to be at $30 for a while that, you've already done all the reserving that you need to do, or the vast majority of the reserving, never say 100%, but the vast majority of the reserving you need to do, in
componenttext: And so -- and do I have it correct that if oil were to be at $30 for a while that, you've already done all the reserving that you need to do, or the vast majority of the reserving, never say 100%, but the vast majority of the reserving you need to do, in which case, we should expect that provision could come down a bit next quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Betsy. We believe the produce in expense and once we get something totally unforeseen would be much lower than last quarter. Remind  you, we kind of said, our NCO guidance was 35 to 45. We would assume that we'll be able to low to mid-range of
componenttext: Absolutely, Betsy. We believe the produce in expense and once we get something totally unforeseen would be much lower than last quarter. Remind  you, we kind of said, our NCO guidance was 35 to 45. We would assume that we'll be able to low to mid-range of that if we don't have an energy surprise. If we have more energy deterioration, it might be mid- to high. So we, as Daryl said, we're expecting to fund charge-offs and keep our reserve rate for growth. So that wouldn't -- and we would not expect a larger build for the second quarter. So in that 8.5%, we've assumed I think prudently, conservatively, through all assumptions. And we fully implemented the guidance, so we would not anticipate from here a significant increase in the provision. I would mention too, we've been through about 60% of our spring redeterminations already. Our average line reductions were about 20%, and about 2/3 of those redeterminations we've got structural enhancement with any holding provisions are more collateral. So to your -- Kelly's point, we're working with these borrowers and we certainly hope that we reserve from what we know today.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: And we'll move next to Lana Chan with BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: Two follow-up questions. One, on the CCAR asks for 2016 and prioritizing buybacks and dividends. Is that just for the second half of this year? Or does that go -- extend into 2017?

componenttext: Yes, that was really for the entire CCAR period, which could extend into '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Daryl, if you could help me run through how we get from the first quarter expense level to the $1.75 billion in the second quarter. It just seems a little bit higher than what I would have modeled and what the adds on. I know you gave the Swett inclus
componenttext: And Daryl, if you could help me run through how we get from the first quarter expense level to the $1.75 billion in the second quarter. It just seems a little bit higher than what I would have modeled and what the adds on. I know you gave the Swett inclusion. What else is going up in terms of the step-up? And what's coming from National Penn?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you look at National Penn and Swett & Crawford, those 2 add in approximately $100 million to $110 million in expenses into the second quarter off of our base. And if you add in maybe an additional $30 million more in expense saves, then th
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at National Penn and Swett & Crawford, those 2 add in approximately $100 million to $110 million in expenses into the second quarter off of our base. And if you add in maybe an additional $30 million more in expense saves, then that leaves about $60 million left approximately. And I would say, so second quarter usually we have higher revenues, you pay out higher commissions, that's a percentage there. And then probably then the next biggest increase that we have across the board is probably just in technology and IT. If we continue to invest in those areas, and those areas continue to increase some. But I feel that we're very focused on our expenses. I think we have a chance of maybe exceeding what we're saying, beating it. But right now, we're just putting out conservative numbers from an expense base. But as Kelly said, we'll focus on improving efficiency throughout the year. But with all these acquisitions closing first in this quarter, it's just that's going to be really messy trying to put it all together.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then that starts really stepping down starting in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then that starts really stepping down starting in the fourth quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct.
componenttext: Yes, correct.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  We'll move next to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  We'll move next to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question maybe is more for Clarke. Clearly, BB&T has done a very good job in improving its credit quality post the financial crisis. And BB&T, along with many of the other banks, all have built up the reserves this quarter for the energy SNC exam tha
componenttext: This question maybe is more for Clarke. Clearly, BB&T has done a very good job in improving its credit quality post the financial crisis. And BB&T, along with many of the other banks, all have built up the reserves this quarter for the energy SNC exam that took place very recently. And so the question is, what did the regulators do that was so different that none of the banks had anticipated back in the fourth quarter? I know energy prices fell to below $30 in February. But were they doing stuff that just was unusual and we had not seen before, which forced everybody to build up these reserves?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Gerard, what -- I think the fundamental -- in my opinion, the fundamental change in the guidance historically as you know reserve-based lending, asset classifications, accrual status, impairment view was based more from a senior secured collateral
componenttext: I think Gerard, what -- I think the fundamental -- in my opinion, the fundamental change in the guidance historically as you know reserve-based lending, asset classifications, accrual status, impairment view was based more from a senior secured collateral asset-based coverage standpoint against that, that's primary bank debt. What's happened with this boom in the shale production with this cycle is you have a lot more secondary bond financing behind the bank group. And then the regulatory guidance is very explicit around, you have to make sure that you have sufficient cash flow coverage and asset coverage for the total debt, including the secondary debt. And obviously with the plunge in prices that nobody could have predicted, it puts enormous pressure on those ratios. So that's really the big sea change. We still believe given all that, with enough time and with some -- with recovery of the prices that we have a good shot at getting -- having better recoveries, but we have to clearly reserve in the meantime.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then speaking of Shared National Credit exams, obviously, we have the national one going on right now for all loan categories. Clarke, are you hearing of any sea changes there, excluding the energy since you guys all just did that? But is there any ta
componenttext: And then speaking of Shared National Credit exams, obviously, we have the national one going on right now for all loan categories. Clarke, are you hearing of any sea changes there, excluding the energy since you guys all just did that? But is there any talk of looking at different categories of loans quite a bit differently?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are not hearing anything yet, any sort of chatter like that, like we had heard with first exam [ph] around . So at this point, we are not.
componenttext: We are not hearing anything yet, any sort of chatter like that, like we had heard with first exam [ph] around . So at this point, we are not.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Kelly, looking at your Slide 11 in the presentation where you focused on the fee income ratio, it's dropped down quite a bit. And one of the hallmarks of your company has always been 45% or so fee revenue to total revenue. Is this a new cha
componenttext: Okay. And then Kelly, looking at your Slide 11 in the presentation where you focused on the fee income ratio, it's dropped down quite a bit. And one of the hallmarks of your company has always been 45% or so fee revenue to total revenue. Is this a new change that we're going to be seeing now closer to 40%? Or is this a temporary change?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Gerard, I think, this is more temporary. I think that we've had a range of 41%, 42% to [ph] 45% is kind of high frankly, but we think in terms of 42%, 43% is kind of normal. We don't link it too far out of balance one way or the other, so -- and it de
componenttext: No, Gerard, I think, this is more temporary. I think that we've had a range of 41%, 42% to [ph] 45% is kind of high frankly, but we think in terms of 42%, 43% is kind of normal. We don't link it too far out of balance one way or the other, so -- and it depends on, again, the interest rate environment. So if your interest rates go down, then your net interest -- noninterest then goes up as a percentage. But on a normalized basis, I'm pretty comfortable with our noninterest income, meaning we're on the [ph] 40% or 42%, 43% kind of level. Right now -- so you've got rates that you had and net interest income being down, which would drive ratio up. On the other hand, insurance is not at the level that it would be relatively because of the pace of business, and so that would affect it. And the temporary impact have been the removal of American Coastal last year, which of course will come right back now when we had Swett & Crawford. So it's not a change Gerard, from a long-term point of view at all, it will be right back where we wanted to be at 42%, 43%. And then probably hopefully hanging at that level because hopefully, the net interest income comes back up.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will move next to Paul Miller with FBR & Company.
componenttext: And we will move next to Paul Miller with FBR & Company.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, can you -- Kelly, can you talk a bit more -- you mentioned that you're going to focus less on M&A going forward. Does that mean both in the insurance side and the banking side, and you're going to focus more on capital management through buybacks?
componenttext: Hey, can you -- Kelly, can you talk a bit more -- you mentioned that you're going to focus less on M&A going forward. Does that mean both in the insurance side and the banking side, and you're going to focus more on capital management through buybacks?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, that's exactly right. We -- I'm not trying to say that we wouldn't dare to do any tiny [indiscernible] something. But as a practical matter, we're just not focusing on M&A now in insurance or bank, which is our 2 primary areas. The truth is we
componenttext: Yes, Paul, that's exactly right. We -- I'm not trying to say that we wouldn't dare to do any tiny [indiscernible] something. But as a practical matter, we're just not focusing on M&A now in insurance or bank, which is our 2 primary areas. The truth is we just got a lot going on in both of them. We've -- we just sell so much [indiscernible]. And you know there is a time to buy and there is a time to run. And the last 24 months are the time to back. The times are right. There was a [indiscernible] for us and its really good opportunities, and we're really happy about what we did. And now is the time to take some time and to adjust what we've done and run it really, really well and get the benefit, for the benefit of our shareholder. I mean this is a shareholder-driven strategy building our profitability up and reaping some of the benefits [indiscernible] investments we've made and [ph] across the insurance and banking and basically everything else.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So should we be modeling a higher buyback level? Or should we wait to the, the Fed comes out with their task where -- which got approved?
componenttext: So should we be modeling a higher buyback level? Or should we wait to the, the Fed comes out with their task where -- which got approved?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, all of us have to wait and see what the Fed approves. But I mean, as a practical matter, if I were you modeling, I'd be modeling for higher buybacks.
componenttext: Well, I mean, all of us have to wait and see what the Fed approves. But I mean, as a practical matter, if I were you modeling, I'd be modeling for higher buybacks.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will move next to Stephen Scouten with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And we will move next to Stephen Scouten with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I had a question for you on the forward loan growth expectations. I see you put 1% to 3% kind of guidance for 2Q. Is that an expectation of slower kind of resi runoff and sales finance runoff? Or is that just higher overall originations? What's going to drive that delta quarter-over-quarter?

componenttext: Yes, it's lower -- the [ph] Vanderwolf is flaming out, if you will. And then you get the seasonal activity build up in the second.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, it makes sense. And is that kind of what you expect for the full year as well in that 1% to 3% range?
componenttext: Okay, it makes sense. And is that kind of what you expect for the full year as well in that 1% to 3% range?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's going to be -- from an organic basis, I would say, we have a little bit more loan growth from second to third, how we sit now. I mean, visibility out a couple of quarters is not perfect, but if we're 1% to 3%, you might add another 1% or 2% to tha
componenttext: So it's going to be -- from an organic basis, I would say, we have a little bit more loan growth from second to third, how we sit now. I mean, visibility out a couple of quarters is not perfect, but if we're 1% to 3%, you might add another 1% or 2% to that for second to third, but we'll see how the economy plays out.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then one follow-up just on the kind of uses of capital buyback versus M&A, I mean, is that something that you would consider to be a hard and fast kind of decision at this point through the next CCAR request? Or will you still have flexib
componenttext: Okay, great. And then one follow-up just on the kind of uses of capital buyback versus M&A, I mean, is that something that you would consider to be a hard and fast kind of decision at this point through the next CCAR request? Or will you still have flexibility like you had kind of this year to either do repurchases or M&A, depending upon opportunities? Or is your request even submitted as simply buybacks, and we won't see a [indiscernible]

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Our request has the same flexibility that we've always had. But the guidance I've given with regard to our focus on profitability management versus M&A is very hard.
componenttext: No, no. Our request has the same flexibility that we've always had. But the guidance I've given with regard to our focus on profitability management versus M&A is very hard.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: And we will move next to John Pancari with Evercore ISI.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the buyback topic, could you help us how to size it up? And if it is something that's much more of -- we've got a good much greater confidence now, Kelly, how should we think about the magnitude to that? I mean, you're at a 40% payout right now on the
componenttext: On the buyback topic, could you help us how to size it up? And if it is something that's much more of -- we've got a good much greater confidence now, Kelly, how should we think about the magnitude to that? I mean, you're at a 40% payout right now on the dividend. You indicated that could go up a little bit. Where could we go on the buyback? Can we be approaching somewhere in the 80s or 90s in terms of a combined payout when you factor in the buyback activity?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, this is Daryl. What I would say from a CCAR perspective, obviously, nothing is approved yet. But last several years, we've focused and we've traditionally been one of the higher ones on the payout ratio on dividend. We hope that, that will cont
componenttext: Yes, John, this is Daryl. What I would say from a CCAR perspective, obviously, nothing is approved yet. But last several years, we've focused and we've traditionally been one of the higher ones on the payout ratio on dividend. We hope that, that will continue with CCAR 2016. And as far as the total payout ratio goes, I would say we like where our capital ratios are today. So as Kelly said, we're going to probably use 25-plus percent up in capital for organic growth. So the remaining percentage would probably be in buyback.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then separately, Kelly, I just want to get a little bit more color around the change in tone on that front in terms of looking at more of the buyback opportunity with capital deployment versus M&A. Was there anything else that prompte
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then separately, Kelly, I just want to get a little bit more color around the change in tone on that front in terms of looking at more of the buyback opportunity with capital deployment versus M&A. Was there anything else that prompted that change in terms of either regulatory environment and -- or anything in terms of your -- the trend in your efficiency that you're trying to get on top of something here?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's really a matter of looking at the number of deals. Ideally, to be honest, we wouldn't have done as many deals in a short period of time as we did. It's just, they were available, and you can't -- I wish you could, but you can't ideally lay out
componenttext: John, it's really a matter of looking at the number of deals. Ideally, to be honest, we wouldn't have done as many deals in a short period of time as we did. It's just, they were available, and you can't -- I wish you could, but you can't ideally lay out your M&A plans on a linear basis and project them whenever you want to have them. They come when they come, and you take advantage of them, when they're there. So we got -- we took a bit more in the last 1.5 years at one time [indiscernible]. And so -- and you combine that with all of the other activities we have [indiscernible] there's investments in the back room in terms of systems and processes and so forth. And it's just my very strong intuitive judgment, our collective team's judgment that it's just time to focus on taking advantage of what we have. So sometimes, people think about M&A and all this as a kind of a linear sloping line, it's not. It's more like a stair step. You ramp up in terms of acquisitions, then you take a period of time and you rationalize and then you ramp up again. So we're in a -- its latter part of the stair step where we're going to be focusing on rationalizing what we've already invested in. We think that's shareholder-friendly because if you just continually roll that all the time, you never get any real payback until you stop growing for and doing M&A for a little while, and that's not fair to the shareholders. So this is more about taking advantage of what we did in the last 1.5 years. We'll get that done, we'll be interested in M&A again. But for right now, we're focused on getting the advantages of what we've already done.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one last thing, if I could on the margin. I know you indicated you've got one rate hike modeled in, in the back part of the year. If that doesn't materialize, is it fair to assume that the margin see some erosion here if there's no Fed hike this
componenttext: Okay. And one last thing, if I could on the margin. I know you indicated you've got one rate hike modeled in, in the back part of the year. If that doesn't materialize, is it fair to assume that the margin see some erosion here if there's no Fed hike this year?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd like to say is, right now we would be forecasting margin to probably be in the low 3 40s probably for -- throughout 2016. Our rate hike that we have in November, it helps us, but it's not a huge impact in the fourth quarter. So it's -- we'r
componenttext: Well, what I'd like to say is, right now we would be forecasting margin to probably be in the low 3 40s probably for -- throughout 2016. Our rate hike that we have in November, it helps us, but it's not a huge impact in the fourth quarter. So it's -- we're pretty much not assuming on any real rate rise of that. So we feel really good about our -- the mix. The mix is going in our favor, loan mix, funding mix and our spreads are coming in nicely. So our core margin has stabilized. So I feel GAAP margin in the 3 40s, low 3 40s is about right.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And we'll move next to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding net interest income and your expectations going forward, you're modeling a rate hike. But how are you looking at the long end of the yield curve at the same time?
componenttext: Regarding net interest income and your expectations going forward, you're modeling a rate hike. But how are you looking at the long end of the yield curve at the same time?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Kevin. So the rate hike is in November, so it really doesn't have a huge impact on net interest income. If you look at the yield curve, we would keep our yield curve relatively constant to where it is today. We don't really think it's going
componenttext: Good question, Kevin. So the rate hike is in November, so it really doesn't have a huge impact on net interest income. If you look at the yield curve, we would keep our yield curve relatively constant to where it is today. We don't really think it's going to steepen up much in our forecast that we have. If you look at our balance sheet, our balance sheet is pretty balanced. About half of our assets are floating, right, half are fixed. And so when the curve actually came down some in the early part of 2016, the fixed portion got [indiscernible] but from a net interest income perspective because those -- they price up the yield curve. But -- and we did a great job with our funding cost, keeping that very stable. All that's very sticky. We're having huge growth in funding and wider margins in our deposit franchise right now.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned that Regional Acceptance had a net charge-off rate of 7.9% and the prime book is roughly 19 basis points, which is very good. How does that compare to the year-over-year numbers and then quarter-over-quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned that Regional Acceptance had a net charge-off rate of 7.9% and the prime book is roughly 19 basis points, which is very good. How does that compare to the year-over-year numbers and then quarter-over-quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, this is Clarke. Regional Acceptance losses are up year-over-year, so they're probably up 50 to 75 basis points or so. Our prime portfolio today is about 16 basis points, not 19 and is relatively stable quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, this is Clarke. Regional Acceptance losses are up year-over-year, so they're probably up 50 to 75 basis points or so. Our prime portfolio today is about 16 basis points, not 19 and is relatively stable quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So what we -- while it's very manageable, Regional Acceptance had experienced some higher loss severities, lower -- they primarily finance economy cars. If you look at Manheim over the last year or 18 months, that class of vehicles has been hit a little harder. We've adjusted for that over the last year or so. And we are actually forecasting, notwithstanding the view of car prices over the next -- remainder of the year, we expect the losses to be down more in the 7% range or so by the end of the year at Regional.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What would cause that decline in charge-offs, given we're continuing to see pressure in used car prices?
componenttext: What would cause that decline in charge-offs, given we're continuing to see pressure in used car prices?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, absolutely, it's the adjustments we made, what we made 12 to 18 months ago on our advance rates. And as those burned through, we believe we'll be in a much better severity position, even with the decline of prices. We've been waiting in to turn a lowe
componenttext: No, absolutely, it's the adjustments we made, what we made 12 to 18 months ago on our advance rates. And as those burned through, we believe we'll be in a much better severity position, even with the decline of prices. We've been waiting in to turn a lower advance rate, so we feel like we'll be -- we'll work through some of the older credits and we'll be in a better position.

componenttext: And we'll move next to Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

componenttext: This is Amanda on for Ken. Daryl, given your strong first quarter NII results and the NIM dynamic you discussed, the guide range that you guys gave at the end of last year for plus I think 12% to 14% year-over-year for NII growth, is the high side of the range in play now?

componenttext: On a year-over-year basis, Amanda, I think I feel very comfortable that we'll have 12-plus percent growth of NII on a year-over-year basis, from 16 to 15.

componenttext: Okay, yes. So purchase accounting, so what I could tell you is, is that on the Susquehanna purchase accounting is starting to come off a little bit. It will trend down over time. But '16, I feel very comfortable that GAAP margin will be in the low 3 40s, second, third, fourth quarters. And core margin, we feel has stabilized, starting to improve some. So that could actually get into the low 3 20s.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. And it is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. And it is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ebony, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for
componenttext:
Thank you, Ebony, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. 
We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the first quarter of '16. We also have with us other members of executive management who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; Clarke Starnes, Chief Risk Officer; and Ricky Brown, Community Banking President. 
We will be referencing a slide presentation during our comments. A copy of the presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on the BB&T website. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings predictions or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations. BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary statements regarding forward-looking information in our presentation and our SEC filings. 
Please also note that our presentation includes certain non-GAAP disclosures. Please refer to Page 2 and the Appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP. And now I will turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everybody, and thank you very much for taking time to join our call. Overall, we had what I call a solid quarter with nice increase in net income and record net interest income. Net income was $527 million, up 8% versu
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everybody, and thank you very much for taking time to join our call. 
Overall, we had what I call a solid quarter with nice increase in net income and record net interest income. Net income was $527 million, up 8% versus the first quarter and 20% annualized versus the fourth; so a solid performance. Diluted EPS was $0.67, which was flat to the first quarter '15, but was up an annualized 18.9% versus the fourth quarter. 
GAAP ROA was 1.09%. GAAP ROTCE was 13.87%. And if you adjust for mergers charges only, adjusted ROA was 1.12% and adjusted return on tangible common was 14.2%; so solid returns there. 
In terms of revenues, we had strong revenue growth despite really some challenges in mortgage banking income and service charges on deposits. So revenues totaled $2.6 billion, which was up 10.2% versus the first quarter and 4.2% annualized versus the fourth. 
We did have record net interest income, as I indicated, of $1.6 billion, up 16.4% versus the first and 6.8% annualized versus the fourth. Really happy about the fact net interest margin grew 3-point -- to 3.43%, up 8% or 8 basis points. And Daryl will you give more color on that. 
Had a nice -- small but nice, improvement in efficiency to 58.3% from 58.8%. non-interest expenses were very well managed; decreased $52 million or 13.1% annualized. And we did have positive operating leverage. 
Our average loans were down slightly versus fourth quarter. But keep in mind, we continued to adjust our mix by letting our lower spread mortgage balances and sales finance portfolios decline. We are improving our profitability in those areas, so that strategy is working, but it's not just producing loan volume increases. Keep in mind, we also have runoff in our Susquehanna Hann portfolio, and we have a seasonal slower growth in a number of our specialized businesses. So average loans and leases for the quarter were $134.4 billion. And if you exclude mortgage runoff and sales finance runoff, loans held for investment grew 2.2%, which is kind of the number that we look at. And that was led by good performance in income-producing properties, direct retail, other lending subsidiaries and our dealer floor plan.
In terms of our strategic highlights, I would point out, we did convert Susquehanna in November. We've seen reductions in FTEs, other cost savings. Overall, it is going very well. 
We did complete our acquisition of National Penn on April 1. That -- we'll be converting that most likely in mid-July. That's going very well. Scott Fainor, the CEO of National Penn, is now the -- our Group President for our northern regions. He's off to a fast start. I feel really good about his leadership and the teams that we have in that area. 
We did complete our acquisition of Swett & Crawford on April 1. This is an outstanding company, 100-year-old company with a great brand. That's $200 million in revenue. Keep in mind, and this is a little complex, but last year very importantly from a strategic point of view, we sold American Coastal because it was outside our risk appetite. And now we've effectively completed that process by replacing it with Swett & Crawford. So we got the revenue back and in a virtually no-risk basis. So that completes that transition, and we feel really good about it. The key now, of course, in insurance business, in particular, for Swett & Crawford, is to get cost savings and overall improvement in margins.
And now before I go through the rest of the points, I just want to make a few important key strategic points. 
So with regard to M&A, as I said, things are going well. After we announced National Penn, we said that we would take a pause. All of the deals that we have, we're really excited about. Texas, for example, where we acquired those branches from Citigroup; Ricky and I were down there a couple of weeks ago in Dallas and Houston, and we could not be more pleased in terms of how we're being received and how well things are going. And frankly, the overall Texas market is still very, very vibrant, notwithstanding the questions around energy. It's continuing really an outstanding market of about 29 million people. It's growing 1,000 people a day. So it's a fantastic market. Really excited about what's going on in northern Kentucky and Cincinnati. Susquehanna, as I said, is off to a good start. National Penn is just getting started, but it has enormous opportunities of synergies with Susquehanna and in the overall revenue opportunities in Pennsylvania. 
So we feel overall really good about our merger strategy, but now is the time for us to focus on the enormous opportunities that we have to improve performance in the areas of investments that we have made for the last several years. So I want to be clear, our focus is not on strategic deals, but on improving our profitability through basically 2 areas, which is what you would expect, the expense management and revenue enhancement. In the expense management area, we will be focusing on the cost synergies in the Community Bank. Primarily, in the Pennsylvania area, we've done a lot in the rest of the Community Bank over the last few years, but there's still some opportunity, particularly in Pennsylvania. 
We have a really good opportunity to rationalize the huge investments we've made in the back room in terms of processes and procedures. We've spent a fortune in the last several years building all that up. Now is the time to rationalize that. In terms of digital transformation, while we will be increasing our investment in digital transformation, there's also an opportunity to overall become more efficient as you link the front room and the back room. And that's what our recent executive management changes is designed to do. So we think that will be a combination revenue enhancement, expense reduction. And then, of course, there's huge opportunities for insurance integration, particularly in Swett & Crawford.
On the revenue side, we'll continue to get huge revenue enhancements from our Community Bank. The rate of momentum improvement there, particularly on our new markets, is exponential, so we feel very excited about that. We will continue really, really a strong performance in wealth, Corporate Banking, insurance and others. 
So given our intense focus on realizing new benefits from our previous strategic investments, our stock repurchases or buybacks move up in priority as we think about CCAR '16 versus strategic initiatives. I'd be happy to answer questions later with regard to that, but we wanted to be sure you are clear about where we are strategically. 
If you turn to Page 4, I'll just mention a couple of items that are unusual this quarter. We did have mergers [ph]; that was about $23 million or $0.02 negative effect on EPS. We did take security gains of about $45 million; which is a part of our strategy in terms of matching all security gains and credit issues; so that was a $0.04 positive. And then the energy-related provision in excess of charge-offs was $28 million or $0.02.
Now with regard to energy credits, the provision exceeded charge-offs by $30 million or $0.03, as I indicated. Daryl will give you a lot of detail on this, but I just want to point out that the charge that we took does reflect the new regulatory guidance and the recent SNC exam results.
So while it's fairly possible that we do have some more energy negative, we do not expect that. We think we built a significant allowance, and we think we should expect our provision to be lower in the second quarter. So we feel, frankly, really good. It's a relatively small part of our whole portfolio, about 1.2%, but I know that's a big interest area. And Clarke will be glad to give more detail on that later, but we feel really good about that.
If you look at the loan area, we feel really good about loan growth relative to the economy. Just a couple of comments about the economy, it is what I would call good, but not great. It's okay. It's rocking along about like it's been rocking along, 2% to 2.5%. It will vary a little bit quarter-to-quarter, but we -- the United States economy is on a sustained 2% to 2.5% kind of growth pattern. It will stay that way, in my humble opinion, for a good while. 
We see no practical possibilities of recession, notwithstanding the fact there's been a lot of conversation about that. And the reason is because we think there is a very, very strong, solid pent-up need for continuing investment. When I talk to businesspeople, they are in investing in a way that I call passive investment. That is to say, they're not excited enough about the future to go out and make major expansions and so forth, but they're driving trucks that have 250,000 miles on it. They got 10-year-old equipment, and so stuff just wears out. So that's why you have to keep investing. 
So that creates kind of a floor on the economy, in my view. There's an upside if we were to get better positive leadership out of D.C. and make some changes in taxes and regulation, et cetera. But assuming that's not going to take the place -- case, we think there's a solid 2% to 2.5%. I would point out that I saw some numbers recently that suggested that most of our markets in the Mid-Atlantic Southeast will be growing 1 point, 1.5 points faster than the national average. So being in the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast is still a good place to be. 
So we are focusing on, as I said, profitability in our portfolio. We believe profitable loan growth is more important than absolute loan growth. 
So just a little bit more detail with regard to the loan area. C&I loans were down slightly, mostly due to decline in commercial loans in the branch network and mortgage warehouse. On the other hand, end-of-period loans were better, with C&I up 2.5% annualized. Good news is C&I spreads are stable compared to last quarter. Growth is affected by our strategies of restricted growth in multifamily and REITs, so we continue to be pretty conservative. We're kind of expecting C&I to grow at a faster pace in the second quarter, probably in the mid-single digits. Daryl is going to give you a lot more color on energy, as I pointed out, but I'll just emphasize again that we have built our reserves and we're very confident that our exposures are manageable.
CRE growth was essentially flat with a decline in consortium and our growth in income-producing. So in income-producing: It increased 7% annualized; feel really good about that; fastest growth coming from office, hospitality, and some small decline in retail. The good news there: Market fundamentals generally continued to improve, although spreads are still tight. We expect CRE construction and development to continue to decline somewhat in the second quarter, and IPP to grow at a similar pace as in the first quarter. 
Dealer floor plan had a very strong quarter, up $76 million or 26% annualized. That's been driven by expansion in our new markets and some new lines that we've introduced, so that's going very well. So floor plan is expected to continue to grow in the double digits for this year. 
Average direct retail lending is a bright spot for us, increasing $211 million or almost 8% annualized. A lot of that is HELOC and direct auto from the branches. Ricky and his team have really made a sea change in terms of our credit consumer production out of the branches. 
On the other hand, our wealth division continues to make a significant contribution in retail lending, really good production as they work closely together. So we expect the retail lending to continue to grow at a similar pace. 
Our average sales finance, primarily large prime auto declined $484 million or 18%. That's a continuation of our execution of our flat-rate compensation program. That is going well. It does produce less volume, but it produces better margins. And so we feel really good about that. The lines will cross in terms of the old portfolio running off new portfolio soon, so that will stabilize. We do have a contingent runoff of the Hann portfolio for a bit longer. And so overall, we think once we get through the next quarter or so that portfolio will be kind of flattish and then it will start to grow. 
Average residential mortgage loans are down $470 million or 16% linked quarter annualized. So keep in mind, we continue to sell essentially all of our conforming production. And we think, again, that's in terms of overall quality management of the balance sheet. Originations in the quarter were $3.6 billion, about 2% more than the fourth. That was reflected in some seasonal improvement. And application volume, I was glad to see, increased 39% compared to the fourth, in total $6.9 billion. So we're definitely seeing a bit of resurgence in new home purchases. Young people are back buying homes again, and that's a really good thing. Our margins on gain of sale improved about 9%, best level since the first quarter of '15. So looking forward, we believe this portfolio decline will slow and be at about flat for the year. 
Our other lending subsidiaries continue to do well. They grew $158 million or 5%, but keep in mind, that's a weak quarter for them. They'll be back stronger in the second. They did really good performance in Grandbridge and equipment financing. So we would expect a seasonally stronger other lending segment to accelerate in the second quarter because of seasonality. 
So overall, the average loans were -- are expected to be up 1% to 3% on a core basis next quarter. Obviously, with the impact of National Penn, growth will be closer to 20%. And I will point out that is real growth. Those are real assets, but we like to distinguish between organic and core growth. So average loans in the second quarter are expected to be about $141 billion.
So if you look at Slide 6, overall deposit program is going very well. Our deposit mix continues to improve. We continue to do a really good job managing our cost of interest-bearing deposits with costs going on -- up only 1 basis point even though we had the rate increase at the end of the year. So average total deposits increased $1.4 billion or 3.7% annualized. And that's a really good growth rate given our intense focus on managing our costs. 
So let me turn it to Daryl now for -- give a bit more color on some of the numbers.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margins, fee income, non-interest expense, capital and our segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Overall credit quality outside the energy portfolio
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margins, fee income, non-interest expense, capital and our segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Overall credit quality outside the energy portfolio remains stable. Net charge-offs totaled $154 million or 46 basis points. Excluding energy-related losses of $30 million, net charge-offs improved from the prior quarter to 37 basis points. 
Loans 90 days or more past due declined $26 million, mostly driven by loans acquired from the FDIC, impaired loans and a decrease in residential mortgage. Loans 30 to 89 days past due decreased $205 million or 20%, mostly due to seasonality in Regional Acceptance as well as decreases in residential mortgage, sales finance, C&I and CRE. 
NPAs increased 27% to 42 basis points, driven by $206 million in energy-related credits moved to nonaccrual. If you exclude energy, NPAs totaled 33 basis points, a modest improvement compared to fourth quarter levels. We are about halfway through our spring redeterminations. We expect NPAs to remain in a similar range in the second quarter, assuming no unexpected impact from that process. We expect net charge-offs to be in the range of 35 basis points to 45 basis points. 
Continuing on Slide 8. Our energy portfolio consists of 100 clients with $1.6 billion in outstandings, consisting of 65% upstream, 27% midstream and 8% in support services. And the coal portfolio totals $215 million in outstandings. 
We take a very conservative approach to energy lending. We do not lend to offshore producers, mezzanine and second-lien facilities or take equity positions. During the quarter, we fully implemented the regulatory guidance from the SNC exam. The allocated reserves totaled 8.5%, and 44% of the energy portfolio was criticized and classified. It's important to note today, all borrowers are paying consistent with their agreements. As a result, we believe our energy portfolio is manageable.
Turning to Slide 9. Our allowance coverage ratios remain strong at 2.4x for net charge-offs and 1.89x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loans ratio improved to 1.10% compared to 1.07% last quarter. Excluding the acquired portfolios, the allowance-to-loan ratio is 1.17%, so our effective allowance coverage is higher. Remember, our acquired loans have a combined mark of about $636 million. 
We recorded a provision of $184 million for the quarter compared to net charge-offs of $154 million. This includes $30 million in net charge-offs related to the energy portfolio and an additional provision of $30 million to build the allowance to 8.5%. Looking forward, our provision is expected to match net charge-offs plus loan growth. We believe that the provision will be much lower than this quarter's numbers, assuming no large deterioration in credit quality.
Turning to Slide 10. Compared to last quarter, net interest margin was 3.43%, up 8 basis points, and core margin was 3.18%, up 6 basis points. The margin increase resulted from a seasonal interest income on assets related to post-employment benefits, duration adjustments on acquired securities, and higher repricing of variable rate assets combined with stable deposit rates. 
Looking at the second quarter, assuming no Fed rate increases, we expect GAAP margin to decline a few basis points driven by the runoff of PCI loans and the loss of a positive seasonal impact of interest income on benefit plans, offset by National Penn. We expect core margin to remain relatively stable. Asset sensitivity remained relatively unchanged. We continue to forecast only one interest rate hike this year happening in November.
Continuing on Slide 11. Non-interest income totaled $1 billion, relatively flat compared to last quarter. The fee income ratio was 40.6%. Looking at a few of those components, insurance income increased $39 million or 41% annualized, mostly due to seasonal factors, higher employee benefit and property/casualty commissions, offset by lower life insurance commissions. Remember, our first quarter of last year included earnings of American Coastal, a business we sold last May. Excluding acquisitions, insurance income grew 1.9% versus last year. 
Mortgage banking income totaled $91 million, down $13 million mostly due to lower commercial mortgage production. Other income decreased $58 million due to a $43 million decrease in income related to assets of certain post-employment benefits and $14 million decline in client derivative income. 
Looking ahead to the second quarter, including both acquisitions, our total non-interest income is expected to increase 9% to 11% versus second quarter GAAP of $1.016 billion.
Turning to Slide 12, non-interest expenses totaled $1.5 billion, down 13% versus last quarter. Personnel expense increased $22 million, driven by a $34 million increase in Social Security and unemployment factors as well as equity-based compensation for retirement-eligible associates and a $10 million increase in higher pension expense, offset by $30 million decrease in post-employment benefits expense. 
Average FTEs declined 311. Merger-related and restructuring charges declined $27 million, mostly due to Susquehanna conversion costs. In addition, other expense decreased $34 million mostly due to lower operating charge-offs and charitable contributions. Our effective tax rate was 30%, and we expect second quarter effective tax rate to be about 31%. 
We expect expenses to total $1.75 billion next quarter. This will include the initial expense base for National Penn and Swett & Crawford, plus $40 million to $50 million in merger-related costs. We expect cost savings to accelerate after the third quarter systems conversion of National Penn and the first quarter 2017 conversion of Swett & Crawford. But in the second quarter, we may have a slight uptick in the efficiency ratio due to the timing of our acquisitions and the delayed timing of related cost savings and synergies. We remain confident we will achieve cost savings related to both acquisitions. We expect efficiency to improve later in the year.
Turning to Slide 13. Capital ratios remain very healthy and fully phased-in; common equity Tier 1 at 10.2%, our LCR increased to 135%, and our liquid asset buffer at the end of the quarter was very strong at 14.5%.  We successfully issued $465 million in preferred stock at 5.625%, which strengthens our regulatory capital in a cost-effective way. Our tangible book increased 2.7% this quarter. 
Finally, a comment on CCAR 2016. As Kelly mentioned, we expect to place greater priority on stock repurchases versus strategic initiatives. 
Now let's look at some segment results, beginning on Slide 14.
Community Bank's net income totaled $310 million, an increase of $38 million from last quarter and up $101 million from the first quarter of last year. Net interest income increased $64 million from the fourth quarter, with about 2/3 of the increase driven by Susquehanna.
Turning to Slide 15. Residential mortgage net income totaled $39 million, down $10 million from last quarter, driven by seasonally lower production and lower servicing fee income. Production mix was 55% purchased and 45% refi. 
Looking to Slide 16. Dealer Financial Services income totaled $42 million, essentially flat as declines in segment net interest income were substantially offset by lower loan processing expense. Regional Acceptance continues to generate stable loan growth with prudent underwriting discipline. This portfolio totals $3.3 billion, and losses have normalized to the 8% range. Net charge-offs for the prime portfolio remained excellent at 16 basis points.
Turning to Slide 17, Specialized Lending net income totaled $56 million, down $7 million from last quarter, driven by lower commercial mortgage and leasing income and higher provision.
Turning to Slide 18. Insurance Services net income totaled $53 million, up $17 million from last quarter, mostly driven by a seasonal increase in employee benefits and higher property and casualty commissions, partially offset by seasonally lower life insurance commissions. We expect Swett & Crawford to add revenues of approximately $160 million for the remainder of this year, coupled with $140 million in expenses. In 2017, we will realize synergies from the deal that will drive improved operating margins going forward.
Turning to Slide 19. Financial Services segment had $26 million in net income, down $77 million from last quarter, largely driven by a provision increase of $92 million related to the energy portfolio. Corporate Banking generated 15% loan growth, and wealth had 6% loan growth along with 29% transaction deposit growth.
In summary, for the quarter, we achieved improved efficiency, net interest margin expansion, positive operating leverage. And we feel that we are set up to have a very strong second half of 2016. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing remarks and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Daryl. So overall, we feel like our M&A strategy is executing very, very well. Loan growth is good, particularly in the environment. Credit quality is very good ex energy, and energy relative to the marketplace is extremely good. And so we feel
componenttext:
Thank you, Daryl. So overall, we feel like our M&A strategy is executing very, very well. Loan growth is good, particularly in the environment. Credit quality is very good ex energy, and energy relative to the marketplace is extremely good. And so we feel right now we have just this really wonderful opportunity to focus on realizing the advantages that we've invested in for a number of years now. So we feel really good about our opportunity to improve efficiencies and our operating profit as we go forward. So we continue to believe our best days are ahead. 
So now we will turn it over to Alan.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly. At this time, we will begin our Q&A session. Ebony, if you could please come back on the line and explain how our listeners can participate and ask questions?
componenttext: Thank you, Kelly. At this time, we will begin our Q&A session. Ebony, if you could please come back on the line and explain how our listeners can participate and ask questions?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Matt O'Connor.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Matt O'Connor.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So starting on the cost saves. Can you just remind us how much is still to come from all the deals that have closed? And then, will these fall to the bottom line? Or are there some offsets as we think about, call it, core BB&T or legacy BB&T?
componenttext: Okay. So starting on the cost saves. Can you just remind us how much is still to come from all the deals that have closed? And then, will these fall to the bottom line? Or are there some offsets as we think about, call it, core BB&T or legacy BB&T?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, if you go back a year-plus ago, the Citi branches and Bank of Kentucky, all those have basically come in, both cost saves and revenues and all that. From Susquehanna's perspectives, we are probably 85% to 90% through the cost saves from that. So
componenttext: So Matt, if you go back a year-plus ago, the Citi branches and Bank of Kentucky, all those have basically come in, both cost saves and revenues and all that. From Susquehanna's perspectives, we are probably 85% to 90% through the cost saves from that. So the rest of the cost saves will probably bleed in into our run rate over the next couple of quarters or as a Community Bank area. But that's where we stand there. As far as the 2 deals that we just closed April 1, there's really no cost saves in those transactions. We expect National Penn had systems conversion third quarter. So you might see a little bit third quarter, but more of that in fourth quarter and first quarter. And Swett & Crawford, maybe a little bit on revenue synergies this year, but their systems conversion is the first part of '17, and their cost saves and efficiencies will come in probably in the first half of '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the revenue side, I mean, bigger picture, like how should we think about what areas you're trying to cross sell into just the broader Mid-Atlantic franchise? Obviously, there's the scale benefit. But what other produ
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the revenue side, I mean, bigger picture, like how should we think about what areas you're trying to cross sell into just the broader Mid-Atlantic franchise? Obviously, there's the scale benefit. But what other product sets do you think can get ramped up in that franchise? And when do we start seeing some of those benefits in a more meaningful manner?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, we think the number is kind of pervasive, but the standout ones are continuing to expand the benefits from our Corporate Banking relationships. Recall that over the last several years, we've been starting those relationships on the credit side, a
componenttext: So Matt, we think the number is kind of pervasive, but the standout ones are continuing to expand the benefits from our Corporate Banking relationships. Recall that over the last several years, we've been starting those relationships on the credit side, and then the follow-on residual benefits in terms of deposits and other fee services come. So that will be a big one. Our wealth management continues to integrate very, very well in terms of loan balances and other fee balances that are coming in. Our retail banking, retail lending is coming on very, very strong. And then the huge benefit from the insurance area, as we integrate Swett & Crawford and continue to integrate Crump and continue to use the Crump cross-sell abilities throughout the entire Community Bank in terms of selling life insurance. All of those are some of the ones that are really big standouts.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take our next question from Michael Rose with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll now take our next question from Michael Rose with Raymond James.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I just wanted to touch on the efficiency ratio. You may not hit your target this year, but that's okay. You obviously notched another insurance acquisition. Can just give us your thoughts in light of the environment in terms of what we could expect
componenttext: Kelly, I just wanted to touch on the efficiency ratio. You may not hit your target this year, but that's okay. You obviously notched another insurance acquisition. Can just give us your thoughts in light of the environment in terms of what we could expect for the insurance or for the efficiency ratio, both maybe in the years to come and then longer term because of any changes?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we will -- end of this year, with improvement, it may be in the 57-ish kind of range. We're pretty confident about that. We still think over the next 2 or 3 years, we'll get to mid-50s. And I know some people talk about the low 50s, that's no
componenttext: Yes, I think we will -- end of this year, with improvement, it may be in the 57-ish kind of range. We're pretty confident about that. We still think over the next 2 or 3 years, we'll get to mid-50s. And I know some people talk about the low 50s, that's not going to happen unless you get a substantial ramp-up in the yield curve. Remember, this is a numerator/denominator problem. So we're assuming that the economy will grow at 2%, 2.5%. There will be a slow ramp-up in the yield curve, but not dramatic. Therefore, it makes it harder to grind out efficiency improvements. Still though, with the opportunities we have to generate additional revenues out of our investments we've made and the ability to generate additional efficiencies from the investments we've made, we think we'll be able to hit those targets.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, how should we think about the dividend payout ratio going forward? You guys are trending a little higher than you have historically. You mentioned in the prepared remarks about CCAR being more focused on
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, how should we think about the dividend payout ratio going forward? You guys are trending a little higher than you have historically. You mentioned in the prepared remarks about CCAR being more focused on buybacks this year, but should we actually expect a dividend increase this year?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our strategy is -- in terms of capital deployment remain the same. But we've always said they adjust from time to time. The ones that don't change is, you always use capital base to get the maximum organic growth you can get. Number two has been and wi
componenttext: So our strategy is -- in terms of capital deployment remain the same. But we've always said they adjust from time to time. The ones that don't change is, you always use capital base to get the maximum organic growth you can get. Number two has been and will remain dividends. The swing is between buybacks and M&A. So what I was leading to earlier is that there's a flip there for the -- going forward for a while in terms of buybacks being more important than M&A as we focus on realizing these opportunities. Now with regard to dividends, we can certainly hope, I mean, our CCAR application is in. As you know, we never can say for sure what's going to happen, but we would certainly expect to have a dividend increase. Because even though our dividend payout is somewhat high, it's not high by traditional standards and it's not that high relative to the stable revenues still trends that we have. So we're very comfortable with a dividend increase this year.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just one final one for me. Just on your -- And I know it's small, but seeing your coal portfolio, I -- it seems like the criticized number of 15% seems a little low from what I would expect. Any sort of trends that give you confidence
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just one final one for me. Just on your -- And I know it's small, but seeing your coal portfolio, I -- it seems like the criticized number of 15% seems a little low from what I would expect. Any sort of trends that give you confidence that, that portfolio will -- the loss content will -- won't be a lot worse than maybe my expectations?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, this is Clarke Starnes. Fair question. I would tell you that we have been methodically reducing our exposure in the coal space for a long time. And we believe a number of the residual borrowers we have are bankable, although we would continue t
componenttext: Yes, Mike, this is Clarke Starnes. Fair question. I would tell you that we have been methodically reducing our exposure in the coal space for a long time. And we believe a number of the residual borrowers we have are bankable, although we would continue to expect exposure to go down from here. We also took as part of that $30 million this quarter, we opportunistically exited one of our larger long time legacy watch list coal credits and got it out completely. So we feel like, what's left, we can manage through. Although the watch list could go up, we feel like the exposure is manageable.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: So a question, just one follow-up to the question on energy. As you did indicate, and I appreciate the color around the percentage of the portfolio that's criticized and classified, that's against a denominator that is both funded and unfunded? Or is that just denominator that is funded?
