componenttext: So a question, just one follow-up to the question on energy. As you did indicate, and I appreciate the color around the percentage of the portfolio that's criticized and classified, that's against a denominator that is both funded and unfunded? Or is that just denominator that is funded?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Betsy, that's based on funded balances.
componenttext: Betsy, that's based on funded balances.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay, got it. That's great. And then separately, as you're thinking about how the industry progresses from here, can you give us a sense as to how you work with your clients? And how you're making the decisions to either continue to reinvest with t
componenttext: Right. Okay, got it. That's great. And then separately, as you're thinking about how the industry progresses from here, can you give us a sense as to how you work with your clients? And how you're making the decisions to either continue to reinvest with them or to potentially help them shrink or sell or exit or reduce your exposure to them? Or is it too late for that, and what you have is, what you have?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Betsy, are you talking about primarily the energy area?
componenttext: Betsy, are you talking about primarily the energy area?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we made a decision, Betsy, sometime ago to be a long-term player in the energy market. We are not going to change that long-term strategy. Energy is an important business for the country, for the world and for us. We enter into relationships on a very
componenttext: So we made a decision, Betsy, sometime ago to be a long-term player in the energy market. We are not going to change that long-term strategy. Energy is an important business for the country, for the world and for us. We enter into relationships on a very conservative selection basis and a conservative underwriting basis. Obviously, everybody's really energized about -- no pun intended about -- concerns about energy now, but -- and we're taking it very seriously and we're marking our book really aggressively and all that. But look, I think there's a much higher chance that oil will be at $50 by the end of this year and than $30. And I think over the long term, the energy business still will be a really good business. And so we will stick with it. And we will stick with our really good clients, and we'll continue to be supportive to the industry.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so -- and do I have it correct that if oil were to be at $30 for a while that, you've already done all the reserving that you need to do, or the vast majority of the reserving -- never say 100% -- but the vast majority of the reserving you need to do,
componenttext: And so -- and do I have it correct that if oil were to be at $30 for a while that, you've already done all the reserving that you need to do, or the vast majority of the reserving -- never say 100% -- but the vast majority of the reserving you need to do, in which case, we should expect that provision could come down a bit next quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Betsy. We believe the provision expense, unless we get something totally unforeseen would be much lower than last quarter. To remind you, we kind of said, our NCO guidance is 35 to 45. We would assume that we'll be able to low to mid-range of
componenttext: Absolutely, Betsy. We believe the provision expense, unless we get something totally unforeseen would be much lower than last quarter. To remind you, we kind of said, our NCO guidance is 35 to 45. We would assume that we'll be able to low to mid-range of that if we don't have an energy surprise. If we have more energy deterioration, it might be mid- to high. So we, as Daryl said, we're expecting to fund charge-offs and keep our reserve rate for growth. So that would -- we would not expect a larger build for the second quarter. So in that 8.5%, we've assumed I think prudently, and conservatively, draw assumptions. And we fully implemented the guidance, so we would not anticipate from here a significant increase in the provision. I would mention too, we've been through about 60% of our spring redeterminations already. Our average line reductions are about 20%, and in about 2/3 of those redeterminations we've gotten structural enhancement, with anti-hording provisions or more collateral. So to your -- Kelly's point, we're working with these borrowers and we certainly hope that we reserve from what we know today.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to Lana Chan with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll move next to Lana Chan with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two follow-up questions. One, on the CCAR asks for 2016 and prioritizing buybacks and dividends. Is that just for the second half of this year? Or does that go -- extend into 2017?
componenttext: Two follow-up questions. One, on the CCAR asks for 2016 and prioritizing buybacks and dividends. Is that just for the second half of this year? Or does that go -- extend into 2017?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was really for the entire CCAR period, which would extend into '17.
componenttext: Yes, that was really for the entire CCAR period, which would extend into '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Daryl, if you could help me run through how we get from the first quarter expense level to the $1.75 billion in the second quarter. It just seems a little bit higher than what I would have modeled and what the adds on -- I know you gave the Swett incl
componenttext: And Daryl, if you could help me run through how we get from the first quarter expense level to the $1.75 billion in the second quarter. It just seems a little bit higher than what I would have modeled and what the adds on -- I know you gave the Swett inclusion -- what else is going up in terms of the step-up? And what's coming from Nat Penn?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you look at National Penn and Swett & Crawford, those 2 add in approximately $100 million to $110 million in expenses into the second quarter off of their base. And if you add in maybe an additional $30 million more in expense saves, then
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at National Penn and Swett & Crawford, those 2 add in approximately $100 million to $110 million in expenses into the second quarter off of their base. And if you add in maybe an additional $30 million more in expense saves, then that leaves about $60 million left, approximately. And I would say, so second quarter usually we have higher revenues, so you pay out higher commissions, that's a percentage there. And then probably then the next biggest increase that we have across the board is probably just in technology and IT. We continue to invest in those areas, and those areas continue to increase some. But I feel that we're very focused on our expenses. I think we have a chance of maybe exceeding what we're saying, beating it. But right now, we're just putting out conservative numbers from expense base. But as Kelly said, we'll focus on improving efficiency throughout the year. But with all these acquisitions closing first of this quarter, it's just -- that's going to be really messy trying to put it all together.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then that starts really stepping down starting in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then that starts really stepping down starting in the fourth quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct.
componenttext: Yes, correct.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  We'll move next to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  We'll move next to Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question maybe is more for Clarke. Clearly, BB&T has done a very good job in improving its credit quality, post the financial crisis. And BB&T, along with many of the other banks, all have built up their reserves this quarter for the energy SNC exam
componenttext: This question maybe is more for Clarke. Clearly, BB&T has done a very good job in improving its credit quality, post the financial crisis. And BB&T, along with many of the other banks, all have built up their reserves this quarter for the energy SNC exam that took place very recently. And so the question is, what did the regulators do that was so different that none of the banks had anticipated back in the fourth quarter? I know energy prices fell to below $30 in February. But were they doing stuff that just was unusual and we had not seen before, which forced everybody to build up these reserves?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Gerard, what -- I think the -- in my opinion, the fundamental change in the guidance historically as you know reserve-based lending, asset classifications, accrual status, impairment view was based more from a senior secured collateral asset-based
componenttext: I think Gerard, what -- I think the -- in my opinion, the fundamental change in the guidance historically as you know reserve-based lending, asset classifications, accrual status, impairment view was based more from a senior secured collateral asset-based coverage standpoint against that primary bank debt. What's happened with this boom in the shale production with this cycle is you have a lot more secondary bond financing behind the bank group. And then the regulatory guidance is very explicit around -- you have to make sure that you have sufficient cash flow coverage and asset coverage for the total debt, including the secondary debt. And obviously with the plunge in prices that nobody could have predicted, it puts enormous pressure on those ratios. So that's really the big sea change. We still believe given all that, with enough time and with some -- with recovery of the prices that we have a good shot at getting -- having better recoveries, but we have to prudently reserve in the meantime.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then speaking of Shared National Credit exams, obviously, we have the national one going on right now for all loan categories. Clarke, are you hearing of any sea changes there, excluding the energy since you guys all just did that? But is there any ta
componenttext: And then speaking of Shared National Credit exams, obviously, we have the national one going on right now for all loan categories. Clarke, are you hearing of any sea changes there, excluding the energy since you guys all just did that? But is there any talk of their looking at different categories of loans quite a bit differently?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are not hearing anything yet, any sort of chatter like that, like we had heard with first exam around the energy. So at this point, we are not.
componenttext: We are not hearing anything yet, any sort of chatter like that, like we had heard with first exam around the energy. So at this point, we are not.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Kelly, looking at your Slide 11 in the presentation where you focused on the fee income ratio, it's dropped down quite a bit. And one of the hallmarks of your company has always been a 45% or so fee revenue to total revenue. Is this a new c
componenttext: Okay. And then Kelly, looking at your Slide 11 in the presentation where you focused on the fee income ratio, it's dropped down quite a bit. And one of the hallmarks of your company has always been a 45% or so fee revenue to total revenue. Is this a new change that we're going to be seeing now -- it closer to 40%? Or is this a temporary change?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Gerard, I think, this is more temporary. I think that we've had a range of 41%, 42% to 45% is kind of high frankly, but we think in terms of 42%, 43% is kind of normal. We don't want to get too far out of balance one way or the other, so -- and it dep
componenttext: No, Gerard, I think, this is more temporary. I think that we've had a range of 41%, 42% to 45% is kind of high frankly, but we think in terms of 42%, 43% is kind of normal. We don't want to get too far out of balance one way or the other, so -- and it depends on, again, the interest rate environment. So if your interest rates go down, then your net interest -- noninterest rate then goes up as a percentage. But on a normalized basis, I'm pretty comfortable with our noninterest income anywhere in the 40% or 42%, 43% kind of level. Right now -- so you've got -- recently you had the net interest income being down, which would drive ratio up. On the other hand, insurance is not at the level that it would be relatively because of the pace of business, and so that would affect it. And the temporary impact has been the removal of American Coastal last year, which of course will come right back now when we add Swett & Crawford. So it's not a change Gerard, from a long-term point of view at all, it will be right back where we want it to be at 42%, 43%. And then probably hopefully hang at that level because hopefully, the net interest income comes back up.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will move next to Paul Miller with FBR & Company.
componenttext: And we will move next to Paul Miller with FBR & Company.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, can you -- Kelly, can you talk a bit more -- you mentioned that you're going to focus less on M&A going forward. Does that mean both in the insurance side and the banking side, and you're going to focus more on capital management through buybacks?
componenttext: Hey, can you -- Kelly, can you talk a bit more -- you mentioned that you're going to focus less on M&A going forward. Does that mean both in the insurance side and the banking side, and you're going to focus more on capital management through buybacks?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, that's exactly right. We -- I'm not trying to say that we wouldn't dare to do any tiny, little bitty something. But as a practical matter, we're just not focusing on M&A now in insurance or bank, which is our 2 primary areas. The truth is we ju
componenttext: Yes, Paul, that's exactly right. We -- I'm not trying to say that we wouldn't dare to do any tiny, little bitty something. But as a practical matter, we're just not focusing on M&A now in insurance or bank, which is our 2 primary areas. The truth is we just got a lot going on in both of them. We've -- we just saw so much opportunity, and you know there is a time to buy and there is a time to run. And the last 24 months were a time to buy. The times are right. There was a window for us and some really good opportunities, and we're really happy about what we did. And now is the time to take some time -- and to adjust what we've done and run it really, really well and get the benefit, for the benefit of our shareholder. I mean this is a shareholder-driven strategy, building our profitability up and reaping some of the benefits of the fruits of the investments we've made and that applies across the insurance and banking and basically everything else.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So should we be modeling a higher buyback level? Or should we wait until the Fed comes out with their test where -- which got approved?
componenttext: So should we be modeling a higher buyback level? Or should we wait until the Fed comes out with their test where -- which got approved?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, all of us have to wait to see what the Fed approves. But I mean, as a practical matter, if I were you modeling, I'd be modeling for higher buybacks.
componenttext: Well, I mean, all of us have to wait to see what the Fed approves. But I mean, as a practical matter, if I were you modeling, I'd be modeling for higher buybacks.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will move next to Stephen Scouten with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And we will move next to Stephen Scouten with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question for you on the forward loan growth expectations. I see you put 1% to 3% kind of guidance for 2Q. Is that an expectation of slower kind of resi runoff and sales finance runoff? Or is that just higher overall originations? What's going to d
componenttext: I had a question for you on the forward loan growth expectations. I see you put 1% to 3% kind of guidance for 2Q. Is that an expectation of slower kind of resi runoff and sales finance runoff? Or is that just higher overall originations? What's going to drive that delta quarter-over-quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's lower -- the resi valve is flaming out, if you will. And then you get the seasonal activity build up in the second.
componenttext: Yes, it's lower -- the resi valve is flaming out, if you will. And then you get the seasonal activity build up in the second.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, it makes sense. And is that kind of what you expect for the full year as well in that 1% to 3% range?
componenttext: Okay, it makes sense. And is that kind of what you expect for the full year as well in that 1% to 3% range?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's going to be -- from an organic basis, I would say, we have a little bit more loan growth from second to third, how we sit now. I mean, visibility out a couple of quarters is not perfect, but if we're 1% to 3%, you might add another 1% or 2% to tha
componenttext: So it's going to be -- from an organic basis, I would say, we have a little bit more loan growth from second to third, how we sit now. I mean, visibility out a couple of quarters is not perfect, but if we're 1% to 3%, you might add another 1% or 2% to that for second to third, but we'll see how the economy plays out.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then one follow-up just on the kind of uses of capital buyback versus M&A, I mean, is that something that you would consider to be a hard and fast kind of decision at this point through the next CCAR request? Or will you still have flexib
componenttext: Okay, great. And then one follow-up just on the kind of uses of capital buyback versus M&A, I mean, is that something that you would consider to be a hard and fast kind of decision at this point through the next CCAR request? Or will you still have flexibility like you had kind of this year to either do repurchases or M&A, depending upon opportunities? Or is your request even submitted as simply buybacks, and we won't see M&A?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Our request has the same flexibility in it that we've always had. But the guidance I'm given with regard to our focus on profitability management versus M&A is very hard.
componenttext: No, no. Our request has the same flexibility in it that we've always had. But the guidance I'm given with regard to our focus on profitability management versus M&A is very hard.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will move next to John Pancari with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we will move next to John Pancari with Evercore ISI.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the buyback topic, could you help us how to size it up? And if it is something that's much more of -- that we could have much greater confidence now, Kelly, how should we think about the magnitude of that? I mean, you're at a 40% payout right now on th
componenttext: On the buyback topic, could you help us how to size it up? And if it is something that's much more of -- that we could have much greater confidence now, Kelly, how should we think about the magnitude of that? I mean, you're at a 40% payout right now on the dividend. You indicated that could go up a little bit. Where could we go on the buyback? Can we be approaching somewhere in the 80s or 90s in terms of a combined payout when you factor in the buyback activity?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, this is Daryl. What I would say from a CCAR perspective, obviously, nothing is approved yet. But last several years, we've focused and we've traditionally been one of the higher ones on the payout ratio on dividend. We hope that, that will cont
componenttext: Yes, John, this is Daryl. What I would say from a CCAR perspective, obviously, nothing is approved yet. But last several years, we've focused and we've traditionally been one of the higher ones on the payout ratio on dividend. We hope that, that will continue with CCAR 2016. As far as the total payout ratio goes, I would say we like where our capital ratios are today. So as Kelly said, we're going to probably use 25-plus percent up in capital for organic growth. So the remaining percentage would probably be in buyback.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then separately, Kelly, I just want to get a little bit more color around the change in tone on that front in terms of looking at more of the buyback opportunity with capital deployment versus M&A. Was there anything else that prompte
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then separately, Kelly, I just want to get a little bit more color around the change in tone on that front in terms of looking at more of the buyback opportunity with capital deployment versus M&A. Was there anything else that prompted that change in terms of either regulatory environment and -- or anything in terms of your -- the trend in your efficiency that you're trying to get on top of something here?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's really a matter of looking at the number of deals. Ideally, to be honest, we wouldn't have done as many deals in a short period of time as we did. It's just, they were available, and you can't -- I wish you could, but you can't ideally lay out
componenttext: John, it's really a matter of looking at the number of deals. Ideally, to be honest, we wouldn't have done as many deals in a short period of time as we did. It's just, they were available, and you can't -- I wish you could, but you can't ideally lay out your M&A plans on a linear basis and project them whenever you want to have them. They come when they come, and you take advantage of them when they're there. So we got -- we took a bit more in the last 1.5 years at one time than I personally would like to have. And so -- and you combine that with all of the other activities we have going on which is huge investments in the back room in terms of systems and processes and so forth. And it's just my very strong intuitive judgment, our collective team's judgment that it's just time to focus on taking advantage of what we have. So sometimes, people think about M&A and all this as a kind of a linear upward sloping line, it's not. It's more like a stair step. You ramp up in terms of acquisitions, then you take a period of time and you rationalize them and then you ramp up again. So we're in a -- its latter part of the stair step where we're going to be focusing on rationalizing what we've already invested in. We think that's shareholder-friendly because if you just continually roll that all the time, you never get any real payback until you stop growing -- doing M&A for a little while, and that's not fair to the shareholders. So this is more about taking advantage of what we did in the last 1.5 years. When we get that done, we'll be interested in M&A again. But for right now, we're focused on getting the advantages of what we've already done.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then one last thing, if I could on the margin. I know you indicated you've got one rate hike modeled in, in the back part of the year. If that doesn't materialize, is it fair to assume that the margin sees some erosion here if there's no Fed hike th
componenttext: Okay. Then one last thing, if I could on the margin. I know you indicated you've got one rate hike modeled in, in the back part of the year. If that doesn't materialize, is it fair to assume that the margin sees some erosion here if there's no Fed hike this year?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd like to say is, right now we would be forecasting margin to probably be in the low 3.40s probably for -- throughout 2016. Our rate hike that we have in November, it helps us, but it's not a huge impact in the fourth quarter. So it's -- we'r
componenttext: Well, what I'd like to say is, right now we would be forecasting margin to probably be in the low 3.40s probably for -- throughout 2016. Our rate hike that we have in November, it helps us, but it's not a huge impact in the fourth quarter. So it's -- we're pretty much not assuming on any real rate rise of that. So we feel really good about our -- the mix. The mix is going in our favor, loan mix, funding mix and our spreads are coming in nicely. So our core margin has stabilized. So I feel GAAP margin in the 3.40s%, low 3.40s% is about right.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And we'll move next to Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding net interest income and your expectations going forward, you're modeling a rate hike. But how are you looking at the long end of the yield curve at the same time?
componenttext: Regarding net interest income and your expectations going forward, you're modeling a rate hike. But how are you looking at the long end of the yield curve at the same time?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Kevin. So the rate hike is in November, so it really doesn't have a huge impact on net interest income. If you look at the yield curve, we would keep our yield curve relatively constant to where it is today. We don't really think it's going
componenttext: Good question, Kevin. So the rate hike is in November, so it really doesn't have a huge impact on net interest income. If you look at the yield curve, we would keep our yield curve relatively constant to where it is today. We don't really think it's going to steepen up much in our forecast that we have. If you look at our balance sheet, our balance sheet is pretty balanced. About half of our assets are floating, right, half are fixed. And so when the curve actually came down some in the early part of 2016, the fixed portion got hurt a little bit from a net interest income perspective because those get priced off the yield curve. But -- and we did a great job with our funding cost, keeping that very stable. All that's very sticky. We're having huge growth in funding and wider margins in our deposit franchise right now.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned that Regional Acceptance had a net charge-off rate of 7.9% and the prime book is roughly 19 basis points, which is very good. How does that compare to the year-over-year numbers and then quarter-over-quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned that Regional Acceptance had a net charge-off rate of 7.9% and the prime book is roughly 19 basis points, which is very good. How does that compare to the year-over-year numbers and then quarter-over-quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, this is Clarke. Regional Acceptances losses are up year-over-year, so they're probably up 50 to 75 basis points or so. Our prime portfolio today is about 16 basis points, not 19 and it's relatively stable quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year.
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, this is Clarke. Regional Acceptances losses are up year-over-year, so they're probably up 50 to 75 basis points or so. Our prime portfolio today is about 16 basis points, not 19 and it's relatively stable quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So what we -- while it's very manageable, Regional Acceptance had experienced some higher loss severities, lower -- they primarily finance economy cars. If you look at Manheim over the last year or 18 months, that class of vehicles has been hit a little harder. We've adjusted for that over the last year or so. And we are actually forecasting, notwithstanding the view of car prices over the next -- remainder of the year, we expect losses to be down more in the 7% range or so by the end of the year at Regional.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What would cause that decline in charge-offs, given we're continuing to see pressure in used car prices?
componenttext: What would cause that decline in charge-offs, given we're continuing to see pressure in used car prices?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, absolutely, it's the adjustments we made, what we made 12 to 18 months ago on our advance rates. And as those burn through, we believe we'll be in a much better severity position, even with the decline of prices. We've been lending in to a lower advan
componenttext: No, absolutely, it's the adjustments we made, what we made 12 to 18 months ago on our advance rates. And as those burn through, we believe we'll be in a much better severity position, even with the decline of prices. We've been lending in to a lower advance rate, so we feel like we'll be -- we'll work through some of the older credits and we'll be in a better position.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll move next to Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Amanda on for Ken. Daryl, given your strong first quarter NII results and the NIM dynamics you discussed, the guide range that you guys gave at the end of last year for plus, I think, 12% to 14% year-over-year for NII growth, is the high side of t
componenttext: This is Amanda on for Ken. Daryl, given your strong first quarter NII results and the NIM dynamics you discussed, the guide range that you guys gave at the end of last year for plus, I think, 12% to 14% year-over-year for NII growth, is the high side of the range in play now?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On a year-over-year basis, Amanda, I think I feel very comfortable that we'll have 12-plus percent growth of NII on a year-over-year basis, from '16 to '15.
componenttext: On a year-over-year basis, Amanda, I think I feel very comfortable that we'll have 12-plus percent growth of NII on a year-over-year basis, from '16 to '15.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, are you expected to have some NPBC PAA in the second half?
componenttext: Okay. And then, are you expected to have some NPBC PAA in the second half?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you translate that for me a little bit, Amanda?
componenttext: Could you translate that for me a little bit, Amanda?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, do you expect to have some purchase accounting accretion from NPBC?
componenttext: I guess, do you expect to have some purchase accounting accretion from NPBC?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. So purchase accounting, so what I could tell you is, is that on the Susquehanna purchase accounting is starting to come off a little bit. But we have National Penn that's full -- we've had the first time for -- go on for this quarter. So purcha
componenttext: Okay, yes. So purchase accounting, so what I could tell you is, is that on the Susquehanna purchase accounting is starting to come off a little bit. But we have National Penn that's full -- we've had the first time for -- go on for this quarter. So purchase accounting is going to be pretty robust for most of this year. It will trend down over time. But '16, I feel very comfortable that GAAP margin will be in the low 3.40s, second, third, fourth quarters. And core margin, we feel has stabilized, starting to improve some. So that could actually get into the low 3.20s.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relatio
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Levi, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Levi, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today. We have with us today Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the second quarter of 2016 and give you some thoughts about next quarter. We also have other members of executive management who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; and Clarke Starnes, our Chief Risk Officer. We will be referencing a slide presentation during our comments. A copy of the presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on the BB&T website. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings predictions or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations. BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary statements regarding forward-looking information in our presentation and our SEC filings. Please also note that our presentation includes certain non-GAAP disclosures. Please refer to Page 2 and the Appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP. 
And now, I'll turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan and good morning, everybody and thanks for your interest in BB&T. We always appreciate you joining our call. So we had a very strong quarter from an organic performance perspective and a strategic perspective. Net income totaled $541 millio
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan and good morning, everybody and thanks for your interest in BB&T. We always appreciate you joining our call. 
So we had a very strong quarter from an organic performance perspective and a strategic perspective. Net income totaled $541 million, up 19.2% versus the second quarter of '15 and 10.7% versus first quarter '16. If you look at diluted EPS, it totaled $0.66, up from $0.62 on a like quarter but down $0.01 from the first quarter but that was due high merger-related and restructuring charges in this quarter as you would expect. Adjusted diluted EPS totaled $0.71, excluding merger-related and restructuring charges and the benefits from the special tax advanced asset, which I'll talk -- I'll cover in a minute. 
GAAP ROA was a strong 1.06% and return on tangible common was a 14.33%. And if you make the adjustments, we alluded to, our ROA adjusted would be 1.16% and adjusted return on tangible would be 15.76%, which is very good. 
For the record, FTE revenues totaled $2.8 billion, up 17.7% versus the second quarter of '15, 31% versus first quarter. Obviously, that was driven by 2 acquisitions in this quarter. We had record net interest income of $1.7 billion, which was up 22.9% versus the second -- 22.8% versus the first of '16. Margin did decline 2 basis points in line with what we projected and Daryl will give you a little color on that in a little bit. 
Efficiency was 59.3% compared to 59.2% in the second of '15 and 58.3% in the first of '16. It was up a bit but we had guided because we knew that timing of the acquisitions were related to the conversions cost savings would impact. 
Noninterest expense has increased $250 million versus the first quarter of '16, but that was led by the impact of National Penn, Swett & Crawford and the merger-related and restructuring charges. If ex out these items, we hit the number that we ha d projected and again, Daryl will give you more color on that when we go forward. 
Average loans and leases held investment totaled $141 billion in the second quarter, was an increase of 20.2% versus the first quarter. And if you exclude the impact of National Penn, growth was still a solid 2.6%. 
We do continue to have runoff in our residential mortgage portfolio by design and our prime other portfolio because of our design and structural change due to very strategic region position relative to the cost and the spreads in each one of these segments. If you exclude residential mortgage loans and National Penn, average loans held for investment grew a very respectable 4.7%, which, frankly, in an economy growing 2% to 2.5% is about right what we would expect to have happened. 
Loan quality is great. Net charge-offs were 0.28%, lowest levels since 2006. 
We did not an objection to our FRB CCAR plans. So as you see, we post a 7.1% increase in the quarterly dividend, $640 million in share repurchases. So if you recall over the years, we've said very clearly that our priorities would grow out [ph] our capital this position is number one, organic growth; number two, dividends; number three, M&A; and number four, buybacks. So we've also said when things change and the priorities change. So today, organic growth is somewhat slower. We are increasing our dividend at a a very nice rate. M&A is off the table for now, so buyback rise up to the higher level of importance and that's exactly what we have said. It's exactly what we plan to do. 
We did complete the conversion of National Penn just last week and it's going absolutely, absolutely great. We could not be more pleased about that. 
Yes, we're very, very excited about all of our acquisitions over the last 18 months, and we're really, really focused on an execution on the profit improvement that will come from them but we continue to not to be [indiscernible] M&A for a while as we said, we've got plenty to do and frankly, we owe it to our shareholders to execute on what we've already done. And that's what we are doing. 
If you're following on the slides, look at the Slide 4 in your deck, this is what I've related to before. So our margin-related restructuring charges were higher than we had expected, it's $92 million pretax and $58 million after-tax, which was $0.07 on a diluted EPS basis. Now that $92 million was made of $63 million on merger charges from Nat Penn, Susquehanna, Swett & Crawford. $29 million was in restructuring charges, which is including severance, [indiscernible] facility restructuring and other real estate write-downs. All of these will improve our run rate going forward. And so while that $92 million, is higher, the truth is we just [indiscernible] opportunities than we had expected to accelerate write-downs and therefore, make it easy to do asset dispositions and also reduce FTEs where we have to take some severance [indiscernible] going forward. So it's a good news story, it's a little higher, but it was powerful, very, very good reason. 
I do want to reinforce that we are intensely focused on expenses. We've been focusing for a number of years as you've heard me describe about reconceptualization of our business. That continues, but I would say to you, it continues at a much more intense rate. The economy is relatively slow. We project a relatively low flat yield curve for a period of time. And as a result, we are accelerating our focus on expense reductions. We still do it from a kind of top-down, bottom-up perspective focusing on allowing our people to help figure out the best way to restructure their businesses versus us trying to [indiscernible] and make the decision. We think that's just a better way. Our people are excited about the [indiscernible] and I think that we'll get really, really good results from that. 
If you're following along on Slide 5, just a couple of comments on the loan area. It was a really good quarter with regard to loans. Our average loans again, excluding Nat Penn, increased 2.6% primarily due to strong growth in C&I and CRE IPP. Now C&I on a linked-quarter basis was 9.4%, which was very, very strong and CRE IPP was 4.3%. So we feel very, very good about that. 
So if you exclude the residential mortgage rundown, which is by strategic design and Nat Penn, we had an annualized growth rate of 4.7%, which I frankly feel very, very good about. 
We did have our typical very strong seasonal performance in a number of our consumer-related businesses like Sheffield, which was up 33%; dealer floor plan was up 21%; premium finance, up 12%; and Regional Acceptance, up 11.2%. So those, remember, are our very good diversifying businesses and are performing very, very well; very, very good quality; and very, very good profitability. 
So looking forward, we expect about the same kind of loan growth in the third quarter as we had in the second, about 1 to 3. And there's just some dramatic change in the economy that what we would expect. 
Speaking of economy, we think the economy is okay, still growing about 2% to 2.5%. But it's interesting 6 months as we came out of the first of the year when everybody thought the world was coming on an end with changes in China and so forth. And then it settled down, net mortgage [indiscernible] got really, really excited about Brexit. We think the Brexit change is serious, but it's been over exaggerated in terms of its impact on the world and certainly on us. Our exports to the entire European Union is relatively small and it's just not going to have a material impact on us and probably not going to have a material impact on the world once the dust settles. 
And also as the political uncertainty wanes, we think businesses will have more confidence like confidence has been withholding back investment for several years, the way things seems to be developing on the political front. It looks like, I think, the business community will feel pretty good and certainly they'll feel more confident going forward. And they do need to invest but [indiscernible] a lot of active investments for the last several years and I think you're likely to see that as we head into '17. Nonetheless, we are planning on a continuation of the same, slow economy, 2% to 2.5%, low rates. If we get higher rates and more confidence, more investments, that's just good but that that's not what we are planning on in terms of running our businesses. 
If you look quickly at Slide 6, we continue to improve our mix and lower our overall deposit costs. Our total deposits had $160 billion, that was an increase of $10 billion, obviously, merger-related. If you exclude acquisitions, total deposits increased $3.9 billion, still a very strong 10.5%. And what I'm particularly pleased about is our mix improvement where our noninterest-bearing deposits, ex acquisitions, increased $1.4 billion or 12.1%, which is really, really strong. And we reduced our total cost to funds on deposits by another 2 basis points, which is really, really good down to 0.23%. So our deposit machine is working great. Our loan machine is working solid. And as Daryl will report to you, our overall fee income businesses and our expense management is really hitting on all cylinders. 
So let me turn now to Daryl for some more commentary.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Overall, we had a really strong quarter with regard t
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Overall, we had a really strong quarter with regard to credit quality. Net charge-offs totaled $97 million or 28 basis points, a decrease from 46 basis points last quarter. this is our lowest charge-off rates since 2006. We restated loans for 90 days or more past due because of our Gennie Mae buyback program. Given this change, loans 90 days past due were essentially flat from last quarter. Loans 30 to 89 days past due increased $89 million or 10.8%, mostly due to seasonality in our consumer-related portfolios. 
NPAs decreased 1.9% to 40 basis points with the majority of the loan portfolio showing improvement. If you look at the graph, excluding energy, NPAs have improved steadily in recent quarters. In the third quarter, we expect NPAs to remain at a similar range and net charge-offs to be in the range of 35 to 45 basis points, assuming no unexpected deterioration in the economy. 
Continuing on Slide 8. We had a stable and quiet quarter in our oil and gas portfolio, with lower nonaccruals and substantially lower charge-offs compared with last quarter. The balances decreased 6% and we will continue to have a good mix with less than 10% in oil field services. 
Our reserve coverage for oil and gas has risen to 9.3% and the coverage for coal, a very modest portfolio, has risen to 9.7%. Following the spring redeterminations, we reduced our average commitments. 
Turning to Slide 9. Our allowance coverage ratios remained strong at 3.88x for net charge-offs and 1.9x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loan ratio was 1.06% compared to 1.11% last quarter. Excluding the acquired portfolios, the allowance-to-loan ratio is 1.16%, so our effective allowance coverage is strong. 
Remember, our acquired loans have a combined mark of about $750 million. We recorded a provision of $111 million compared to net charge-offs of $97 million. Looking forward, our provision is expected to match charge-offs, plus loan growth. 
Turning to Slide 10. Compared to last quarter, net interest margin was 3.41%, down 2 basis points. Core margin was 3.16%, also down 2 basis points. Net interest margin decreased resulting from lower interest rate environment and higher security balances as a result of National Penn. 
Looking into the third quarter, we expect GAAP margin to decline a few basis points driven by lower rate, including a flatter yield curve and a reduction in benefits from purchase accounting. We expect core margin to remain relatively stable as lower rates will be offset by asset mix and funding costs and mix changes. We do not anticipate average earning assets to remain relatively stable next quarter. 
Asset sensitivity increased primarily due to changes in pre funds as well as investments in deposit mix changes. 
Continuing on Slide 11. Noninterest income totaled $1.1 billion, up $114 million compared to last quarter. The fee income ratio improved to 42.8%. 
Looking at a few of the changes in noninterest income. Insurance income increased $46 million driven by several factors. First, the acquisition of Swett & Crawford, which added $57 million in the second quarter. We also had $34 million seasonal increase in property/casualty commissions and a $13 million increase in other insurance revenues. This was offset by a seasonal decline in employee benefit commissions of $36 million and a decrease of $23 million, which is mostly due to lower bonus commissions. Excluding acquisitions, insurance income grew about 1% versus the same quarter last year. 
Mortgage banking income totaled $111 million, up $20 million, mostly due to higher gains on sale an increase in salable residential loan volume and seasonally higher commercial mortgage income. The other income increased $65 million due to a $65 million increase in income related to certain cost employment benefits. Looking ahead to the third quarter, total fee income is expected to be relatively flat due to a seasonal decrease in insurance revenues. 
Turning to Slide 12. Noninterest expenses totaled $1.8 billion, up $252 million versus last quarter. Personnel expense increased $124 million, driven by several factors. First, we had a $44 million increase in salary expense mostly due to the addition of approximately 1,900 FTEs from recent acquisitions. We also had a $40 million increase in postemployment benefits expense and a $36 million increase in incentives. This was due to the acquisition of  Swett & Crawford and higher overall volume. Excluding acquisitions, FTEs were lower by 276. 
Merger-related and restructuring charges increased $69 million. We also had $29 million in restructuring charges related to severance and real estate write-downs. In addition, other expense increased $33 million, mostly due to operating charge-offs, charitable contributions and travel expense. Our effective tax rate was 30%, slightly below expectations due to the tax benefits this quarter. We expect the third quarter effective tax rate to be about 31%. 
Going forward, our expenses will be -- will include an $11 million quarterly increase with the FDIC insurance premiums. Even with this increase, we expect expenses to decline 1% to 2%, mostly due to cost saves from recent acquisitions, excluding merger-related and restructuring charges. We are still targeting to generate positive operating leverage in the second half of 2016. 
Turning to Slide 13. Capital ratios remain very healthy with a fully phased-in common equity Tier 1 of 9.8%. Our LCR was 135% and our liquid asset buffer at the end of the quarter was very strong at 13.7%. 
Finally, we were pleased to receive an objection to our capital plan. As a result, we will seek board approval to increase our quarterly dividend $0.30 per quarter and initiate a share repurchase program in the third quarter, repurchasing up to $160 million of our shares.
Now let's look at segments beginning on Slide 14.  Before I walk through the Community Banking segment, I would note that National Penn is not included. Now that the conversion is complete, those results will become part of a segment recording next quarter. 
Net income totaled $294 million, a decrease of $7 million from last quarter and up $63 million from second quarter of last year. Net interest income increased $5 million from the first quarter and $188 million for the second quarter of 2015. A little more than half of the increase was driven by Susquehanna. 
Turning to Slide 15. Residential mortgage banking net income totaled $44 million, up $5 million from last quarter, driven by higher gains on residential mortgage loan production and sales. Production mix was 57% purchased and 43% refi, similar to last quarter. 
Looking to Slide 16. Dealer Financial Services totaled $51 million, up $9 million, mostly due to lower charge-offs and regional acceptance. Our subprime auto portfolio totals $3.4 billion and losses totaled 6% in the quarter, a significant improvement. Net charge-offs for the prime portfolio remained excellent at 15 basis points. 
Turning to Slide 17. Specialized Lending net income totaled $61 million, up $5 million from last quarter. This was driven mostly by loan and production growth in both Sheffield and equipment finance, as well as good strong production in Grandbridge, our commercial mortgage business. 
Looking at Slide 18. Insurance Services net income totaled $44 million, down $9 million from last quarter. Noninterest income totaled $465 million, up $44 million, mostly driven by the addition of Swett & Crawford and higher fee and commissions, partially offset by seasonally lower employment benefit commissions. Noninterest expense increased $58 million, mostly due to Swett & Crawford. Going forward, we will continue to focus on achieving both cost savings and revenue synergies from Swett & Crawford acquisition. 
Turning to Slide 19. Financial Services segment had $87 million in net income, up $60 million from last quarter. This was a largely driven by a provision decrease of $84 million related to charge-offs and increased reserves in the energy portfolio last quarter. 
Corporate Banking generated 24% loan growth and wealth had 14% loan and 16% transaction deposit growth. 
In summary, for the quarter, we achieved excellent credit quality, a relatively stable net interest margin, a successful restructuring of some of our corporate real estate and as Kelly mentioned earlier, successful conversion of National Penn. We are working hard to achieve synergies and efficiencies from our merger partners. With a steady outlook for loan growth and tight controls on our core expenses, we are set up to have a strong second half of 2016. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing thoughts and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daryl. So in summary, it was a solid quarter from an organic and a strategic perspective. We're pleased with earnings up 19%; record revenue, up 18%; loan growth was very good given the challenging 2005; deposits were excellent; National Penn has
componenttext:
Thanks, Daryl. So in summary, it was a solid quarter from an organic and a strategic perspective. We're pleased with earnings up 19%; record revenue, up 18%; loan growth was very good given the challenging 2005; deposits were excellent; National Penn has been converted and very, very excellent manner. We're executing on the cost saves from that end, continuing with Susquehanna. M&A, as we said, is off the track but we're -- I mean, off the table, so we're focusing on expense management. We're very pleased with our shareholder-friendly capital plan with a 7% increase in dividends and proposed buybacks. And so, in this type of environment, we think that's the most important thing to focus on is to execute with precision, generating all the revenue that we can generate out of our businesses, having made a number of investments over the past several years, we have a lot of opportunities in our various businesses, so a lot of opportunity there, huge opportunity to continue to focus on rationalizing our cost structure, which is our primary focus at this time. 
So let me turn it over to Alan now for Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Matt, it was about what we had planned. Early on, we said the second quarter, but then as we went along, we realized we'd get it done at the very first part. And so, yes, relative to the very beginning when we announced it, it was earlier and that did accelerate some of the cost saves. That's really good for us, but that's [indiscernible] that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my follow-up is on the underlying expense trends at kind of call it, core BB&T, maybe you can give us an update there. I know there had been some ramp-up maybe a year ago or so and then hope that some of those costs would run off maybe
componenttext: Okay. And then just my follow-up is on the underlying expense trends at kind of call it, core BB&T, maybe you can give us an update there. I know there had been some ramp-up maybe a year ago or so and then hope that some of those costs would run off maybe give us an update on how those are trending and the outlook there?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So generally, Matt, what's happening is actually what we had projected. If you go back to 2 or so years ago, again, just speaking into core area, we started a pretty major rebuild by our backroom with 3 major projects, our [indiscernible] new system, whic
componenttext: So generally, Matt, what's happening is actually what we had projected. If you go back to 2 or so years ago, again, just speaking into core area, we started a pretty major rebuild by our backroom with 3 major projects, our [indiscernible] new system, which is now completed; our new commercial loan system, which is about 75% completed; and our new state-of-the-art data center, which is completed and getting ready to open. So there had been substantial upfront expenses and time commitment with regard to all of those. We're now heading into the period of time over the next year or so as that will crest and then we'll begin to get the benefits on a relative basis. 2 counts of benefits. One, will be, you'll see relatively less expenses forward versus what we just invested in the previous periods. And then, we'll begin to, and this would take 2 or 3 years, but we'll begin to get to the efficiencies out of these new investments, which will be meaningful over the long-term point of view. So the core fundamental operating expenses of BB&T are poise to improve as we go forward. We're not making a grand big promises for the third quarter [indiscernible] that kind of thing not the way we operate. But in terms of our focus today with the major projects underway and substantially complete and with our intense focus on continuing [indiscernible], we feel good about expense management going forward.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the loan growth and a couple of questions here. One is you came in towards the higher end of your range just wanted to understand what's going on in C&I that drove some of that, it looks like maybe what else is going on? And just big
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the loan growth and a couple of questions here. One is you came in towards the higher end of your range just wanted to understand what's going on in C&I that drove some of that, it looks like maybe what else is going on? And just bigger picture, how you think about the growth in the specialized services relative to the rest of the portfolio? Are you comfortable with allowing the specialized services growth to be at such high delta relative to the rest of the portfolio? Does it matter for RWA? Does it matter for capital term, longer term?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] the C&I growth, that was centered primarily much like the industry in our large corporate lending area. We still have the low relative base to our peers and we continue to have expansion in our vertical, so that -- you saw a lot of growth
componenttext: [indiscernible] the C&I growth, that was centered primarily much like the industry in our large corporate lending area. We still have the low relative base to our peers and we continue to have expansion in our vertical, so that -- you saw a lot of growth there. This quarter, our mortgage lending rates [indiscernible], that certainly seasonally moved in the public finance area, in our dealer floor plan. So it wasn't any one area. It was pretty much across the board, but it was slanted toward more toward the corporate side. As far as far as our specialized lending area, we have said that other than subprime, we would expect those platforms to grow relatively faster than the core bank. Now we are purposely constrained in the growth in the subprime sector to make sure it doesn't grow any faster than the core bank, so we don't increase our relative exposure there. But we believe those Specialized Lending areas, even with the high RWAs, do represent with the yields a very strong risk return advantage for us. So we want to be sure we do that in a measured fashion but we certainly would expect those to grow relatively faster than the core.

[indiscernible] go on in accruals. So I would say there's really minimal impact. Low variability, high resiliency in those portfolios.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to our next question with Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital management.
componenttext: And we'll go to our next question with Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital management.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, you guys obviously put up a very good return on average tangible common equity number today of 14.3%. The return on average shareholders' equity was basically flat at 8.2%. Can you share with us how you expect to get that 8.2% higher? And if we ass
componenttext: Kelly, you guys obviously put up a very good return on average tangible common equity number today of 14.3%. The return on average shareholders' equity was basically flat at 8.2%. Can you share with us how you expect to get that 8.2% higher? And if we assume cost of equity capital around 9% to 10%, how do you surpass that in the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Gerard, as you know, that's the grand question for all of us in the industry today. Pre-crises, we and the other good banks were operating at about 15%. You've got to start from kind of the top. The way I think about is there's about 2% kind of run
componenttext: Well, Gerard, as you know, that's the grand question for all of us in the industry today. Pre-crises, we and the other good banks were operating at about 15%. You've got to start from kind of the top. The way I think about is there's about 2% kind of run off at the top called the higher capital. And then you've got about 1% to 1.5%, which is just the environment and economy, margins, et cetera. And then, the difference really is in the regulatory costs and some type of logical costs. So from the capital point of view, we're going to continue to try to manage our capital efficiently, but it's going to stay high compared to past periods. So that 2%, at least, in the short run, is kind of nonretrievable. But that gives you the [indiscernible] 13. So the 1% to 1.5% in terms of economy, obviously, can come back and come back quickly depending on the growth rates in the economy and the margins. We're not counting on that, but I personally think the flat rate scenario that everybody's projecting is overstated. The underlying strength of our economy is not good, but it's good. I said, I believe, clearly, knows they need to raise rates and I think they will the minutes they see a window, which can still easily happen at least one rate increase towards the fall. And then the whole thing about regulatory and technological cost is about becoming efficient, scale is a part of that and then, [indiscernible] settle in that we have to put into place. And then finally, Gerard, I would say, this is a brave New World. You can't run a bank today that way you did 5, 10, 15 years ago. Everything has to be reconceptualized. We have a very intense focus right now on looking at our businesses and here's kind of how our best people to approach it. I'm saying go back 20 years ago when things were pretty good and take a look at and what our structure was then and examine anything today that we're doing that we weren't doing 20 years ago. If it's something that we are doing that we are absolutely required to do by our regulation, then obviously, we have no choice. If it's something that has the [indiscernible] or creep into the structure, which can happen when times are fairly good, then it is suspect. And so we're going to examine every one of those in terms of the economic productivity and I suspect that we will find material changes. So we will be restructuring the business. We already have a number of things underway, I'm not quite ready to announce it this morning, but we have a number of things that we're working on, not going to be any big, grand announcements, not going to be any big announced cost-saving plan, that's not our style. But you could count on the fact that we are laser-focused on running our businesses as efficiently and getting those returns up. I frankly think in the bottom line, Gerard, that this material change in that is over the next couple of years, I certainly think we'll be in the 10% range over the next couple of years [indiscernible] in cost of capital, I don't have any concerns about that. From 10 to 12 and 13 is more difficult, as I described, and somewhat circumstantial based on what's going on in the world but we will be in that top tier of the performing banks based on the then existing circumstances.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And as a follow-up question to Daryl, you pointed out on Slide 10 that the interest rate sensitivity of the balance sheet has increased due to the acquisition. Do you expect to keep it at this level? Or do you think you'll bring it down in the seco
componenttext: Great. And as a follow-up question to Daryl, you pointed out on Slide 10 that the interest rate sensitivity of the balance sheet has increased due to the acquisition. Do you expect to keep it at this level? Or do you think you'll bring it down in the second half?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know me, Gerard, I've been doing this my whole career, asset liability management and really not a big believer in taking one big position one way or the other. We really want to be just slightly asset-sensitive and just try to invest the balance and
componenttext: You know me, Gerard, I've been doing this my whole career, asset liability management and really not a big believer in taking one big position one way or the other. We really want to be just slightly asset-sensitive and just try to invest the balance and diversify over time. You really can't project interest rates. And if you do, [indiscernible] interest rates write once, what are you go you going the next time around. You just can't do it. I mean, our job is to reduce predictable and repeatable earnings. So we will continue to invest our securities, derivatives and all very balanced approach. We'll try to stay slightly asset-sensitive and that number might move around a little bit but you're not going to see any big change out of us.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next with John Pancari with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll go next with John Pancari with Evercore ISI.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Steve Moss [ph] for John. I want to circle back to the efficiency and the expenses, your expense plans. Wondering if you could provide updated thoughts on efficiency ratio from 4Q '16 and also 2017?
componenttext: It's actually Steve Moss [ph] for John. I want to circle back to the efficiency and the expenses, your expense plans. Wondering if you could provide updated thoughts on efficiency ratio from 4Q '16 and also 2017?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, on the [indiscernible] before on these calls, I know everybody likes to be hyper focused on the efficiency ratio and we're willing talk about it. But remember that it is a ratio and so we have a lot of visibility in terms of the numerator. But if w
componenttext: Steve, on the [indiscernible] before on these calls, I know everybody likes to be hyper focused on the efficiency ratio and we're willing talk about it. But remember that it is a ratio and so we have a lot of visibility in terms of the numerator. But if we don't have as much visibility in terms of the denominator, that is revenues. Obviously, if we did nothing today with our expenses and the economy got better margins, got better efficiency ratios, it goes down. I mean, you wouldn't give us any credit for that but that's what would happen. Conversely, if you have a period where revenues go down, maybe you're doing a great job on expenses, then efficiency ratios go up, you're going to blame us for that. So I think that efficiency ratio is taken out of context. Having said that, we think we are generally on a downward trajectory with regard to the efficiency ratio. We're just not will be able to give you exactly what is quarter-by-quarter. We think for the rest of this year and into next year, it will be down. An immediate term, I'll call that 2- to 3-year once we get into the 56% to 57% range, assuming reasonableness with regard to revenues, which I think will happen. And that will be very good. That will be a top-performing level of efficiency. We're not trying to drive expenses, so low that we put revenues at risk. And so I'm very, very confident about our ability to execute on a very efficient organization. And I think that will show up as a very slow but methodical decline in the efficiency ratio.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good. And then with regard to commercial real estate, just wondering what your appetite for growth is there? And if there are any markets you maybe pulling back from?
componenttext: Okay. Good. And then with regard to commercial real estate, just wondering what your appetite for growth is there? And if there are any markets you maybe pulling back from?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Clarke. While we feel really good about the quality of the underwriting of what we're putting on our books today and have been doing, we saw some additional growth this quarter. A lot of that was we're not seeing projects go out across the
componenttext: Steve, this is Clarke. While we feel really good about the quality of the underwriting of what we're putting on our books today and have been doing, we saw some additional growth this quarter. A lot of that was we're not seeing projects go out across the industry quite as fast as the secondary markets. some of that was around the business of velocity of outflows, but we are trying to be a little bit more measured in certain segments. We think, for example, multifamily and hospitality might be peaking or have peaked and we don't want to get ahead of the market fundamentals and any asset class. So we're going -- we do not want to wake up with more concentration if there are issues in the future. So I think you will see us be a little more measured in those sectors and in CRE, in general, although certainly take care of good high-quality clients. So for us, we are a little concerned about some of those asset classes. And we are watching specific markets and submarkets very closely. So no particular market, per se individually but in general the fundamentals for each of the areas we operate in.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the next question from John McDonald with Bernstein.
componenttext: And we'll go to the next question from John McDonald with Bernstein.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was looking for a little perspective on the CCAR assets here, looking to do more on capital return due to the high on M&A and your approval reflects that. Just wondering on the actual numbers, how did your process land on the $640 million buyback and wh
componenttext: I was looking for a little perspective on the CCAR assets here, looking to do more on capital return due to the high on M&A and your approval reflects that. Just wondering on the actual numbers, how did your process land on the $640 million buyback and what looks like a total payout probably in the mid-60 range?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, when we went through the process, you go through and you really evaluate your risk in the company, you run your stress models. CCAR 2015, we actually used up over 100% of our capital, so our capital ratios came down a little bit. So when we did
componenttext: Yes, John, when we went through the process, you go through and you really evaluate your risk in the company, you run your stress models. CCAR 2015, we actually used up over 100% of our capital, so our capital ratios came down a little bit. So when we did CCAR '16, we wanted to make sure our capital ratios stayed above 10% intangible common Tier 1, which is really what we're targeting. So you will see us slowly accrete even with the repurchase and dividend increase a little bit more capital over this next 4 quarters, probably around 20 basis points or so, which is exactly what we plan for. You look at our asset in total, in '16 versus '15, it's basically 5% higher. Yes, I know we did an extra acquisition and all that, but the actual assets that we came in with came in a little bit higher overall if you don't count the acquisitions.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And Daryl on your NIM outlook, could you give little bit more color on the puts and takes on the core NIM holding flat? And then the purchase accounting drag on the reported NIM you mentioned for next quarter, how many more quarters band this
componenttext: Okay, great. And Daryl on your NIM outlook, could you give little bit more color on the puts and takes on the core NIM holding flat? And then the purchase accounting drag on the reported NIM you mentioned for next quarter, how many more quarters band this would you still have that?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At our slide we show you GAAP margin and we show you core margin. We feel very good that core margin has stabilized. Most of our assets for the most part have a great price. With the flatter curve you've seen a little bit of pressure on some longer asset-
componenttext: At our slide we show you GAAP margin and we show you core margin. We feel very good that core margin has stabilized. Most of our assets for the most part have a great price. With the flatter curve you've seen a little bit of pressure on some longer asset-light security investment there but we're also still bringing down our deposit cost a little bit. You saw those come down a couple basis points. So we feel pretty good that core margin will be pretty stable for the foreseeable future. On the GAAP side, it's basically, the difference is purchase accounting. And you're going to see [indiscernible] no acquisition whatsoever GAAP will converge to core over several years and there will be a trajectory down over time. I wouldn't say it's going to be steep but just by definition, it's got come in and collapse if you won't do any more acquisitions.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And just a clarification, did you say earning assets flat next quarter, so NII is growing a little bit? Or would you -- what would you...
componenttext: Okay. Great. And just a clarification, did you say earning assets flat next quarter, so NII is growing a little bit? Or would you -- what would you...

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, so earning assets are a little bit flat on a linked-quarter basis because when we purchased [indiscernible] and the we pre-bought their securities and sold their security portfolio, so we're a little bit big in the second quarter, so our securit
componenttext: Yes, yes, so earning assets are a little bit flat on a linked-quarter basis because when we purchased [indiscernible] and the we pre-bought their securities and sold their security portfolio, so we're a little bit big in the second quarter, so our securities will rightsize this quarter be around $46 billion, $47 billion in total. So that will come about down a little bit, but that will be more than offset in the loan growth side. We actually get a positive mix change there because you're getting higher yielding assets on the loan side versus what you're giving up on the security side.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
