headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relation
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, LeeAnn, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today.With me are Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the third
componenttext:
Thank you, LeeAnn, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today.
With me are Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the third quarter and provide some thoughts for next quarter.
We also have other members of our executive management team who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; Clarke Starnes, our Chief Risk Officer; and Ricky Brown, our Community Banking President.
We will be referencing a slide presentation during today's comments. A copy of the[ph] presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on our website.
Let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings predictions or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations.
BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements.
Please refer to the cautionary statements regarding forward-looking information in our presentation and our SEC filings. Please also note that our presentation includes certain non-GAAP disclosures.
Please refer to Page 2 and the appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP.
At this time, I'll turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining our call. So overall, I think we had a very strong performance quarter. We had a record quarterly earnings, and we did complete a few strategic agreements, which will benefit future quarters,
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining our call. 
So overall, I think we had a very strong performance quarter. We had a record quarterly earnings, and we did complete a few strategic agreements, which will benefit future quarters, which I'll describe. Net income of $599 million, which is up 21.7% versus third of '15 and 42.7% annualized versus second quarter '16. 
Diluted EPS was $0.73, up 14% versus the third and up 42% annualized versus the second. Now if you adjust, which I'll cover again, if you adjust EPS, it totaled $0.76, excluding merger-related and restructuring charges and a few other items on Slide 4. 
Our GAAP ROA, ROE and ROTCE were 1.15%, 8.87% and 15.20%, which I think were very strong in this environment. Taxable-equivalent revenues totaled $2.8 billion, up 13.1% versus third of '15 and 3.9% versus second quarter of '16 on an annualized basis. I'm very pleased that our net interest margin declined only 2 basis points to 3.39%, and our core net interest margin increased to 3.17%. Daryl will give you a lot more color on that in just a little bit. 
Our GAAP efficiency ratio improved to 61.7% versus 65.4% in the second quarter of '16. Our adjusted efficiency ratio improved to 58.7% versus 59.6% in the second quarter. [indiscernible] Noninterest expenses were $1.7 billion, a decrease of 19% versus the second quarter annualized. 
Average loans and leases held for investment totaled $141.3 billion in the third quarter, which was up just slightly compared to the second quarter. We do continue to have significant runoff in our Residential Mortgage portfolio and prime auto based on some very clear strategic decisions that we have made. 
Ex these, though, we had a respectable 3 -- 2.2% annual growth, which I think is pretty good consistent with the economic growth, and I'll talk a bit more about that in a minute. NPAs did continue, a slight decrease of 4.9%. 
We did settle a loss share agreement with the FDIC. Recall that we had a loss share agreement on that 2009 acquisition of Colonial. We incurred an $18 million charge this quarter, but it will result in future benefits with regard to earnings. We did settle a dated FHA insurance loan matter, and we made a $50 million charitable contribution, which will reduce expenses in future quarters. And as indicated, we did repurchase $160 million of outstanding shares. 
Now Slide 4, these selected items that I related to, the merger-related restructuring charges was $43 million pretax or $0.03 negative impact to diluted EPS. Charitable contribution is $50 million pretax, which was $0.04 dilution to EPS. On the other hand, we had a settlement of FHA insurance loan matters net of recoveries, which was a positive $73 million or $0.05 and then the termination of the FDIC loss share agreements, the $18 million I mentioned, was $0.01. So if you net those out, it was about [ph] $0.03 net negative impact on EPS because of those selected items. 
If you go to Slide 5, a few comments with regard to loans. As I've said, they were up slightly 0.3%, but for several quarters now, we have indicated to you that we have been allowing our Residential Mortgage portfolio to decline. That's a strategic decision because of the mix of our business, expectations with regard to rising rates and the spreads, frankly, in that business. So the risk-adjusted return is not at a level we would like to be on a marginal basis and so we're letting it run off. And in the sales finance in the prime portfolio, we did restructure some quarters ago to a flat program. That program transition's actually going very well. The old portfolio is running off today but, frankly, the new portfolio going off [ph] more profitable. So we feel good about that, but it does show a loan decline. So again, net adjusted 2.2%. 
We did have some key very strong performances on a seasonal basis, which we expect from some of our Specialized Lending businesses. Premium finance was up 57.1% annualized; Sheffield, up 21.3% annualized; Regional Acceptance, up 15.5% annualized; and revolving credit was up 9.6%. So you can see that while we're being very careful with regard to our basic growth [ph] portfolio, our Specialized Lending portfolio has continued to do very, very well. 
Now we, like probably others, did experience higher payoffs in our commercial area in the quarter. Frankly, a lot of good quality loans have just been refi-ed out into the market because of, I think, participants' expectations that rates are going up. So they're going [ph] out and taking advantage of long-term loan markets. That's not a long-term change in terms of the commercial lending productivity. It's just a temporary increase in payoffs. Production in the pipelines and all still looks solid. 
And I'll remind you that we are a very disciplined lender. We're just not doing cheap loans outside of our risk appetite. But quite frankly, I mean, we could be growing faster, but the risk-adjusted return on equity's just unacceptable. So we're getting all that the market will give us and we're not going to try to beat the market. That's not a good bet from a long-term point of view. 
On Page 6, our DDA growth continue to be very strong at 14.3%, feel really good about that. We are increasing market share in most of our markets, and we continue to hold our costs at a very low 0.3%. So our deposit business is doing extremely well and supporting the asset growth that we have. 
Let me turn it to Daryl now for some additional detail, and then we'll have questions.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Overall, we had a really good quarter with regard to
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Overall, we had a really good quarter with regard to credit quality. Net charge-offs totaled $130 million, up 9 basis points from last quarter. This was mostly driven by expected seasonality in our retail portfolios as well as returning to more normalized levels after a very low charge-off quarter. 
Loans 30 to 89 days past due increased $66 million or 7.2%, again, mostly due to seasonality in our consumer-related portfolios. NPAs decreased 4.9% to 38 basis points. Excluding energy, NPAs have improved steadily in recent quarters. 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect NPAs to remain at a similar range. We also expect net charge-offs to be in a range of 35 to 45 basis points assuming no unexpected deterioration in the economy. 
Continuing on Slide 8. Our energy portfolio totaled $1.3 billion, about 1% of total loans. Outstanding balances, total commitments and nonaccruals all decreased from last quarter, and all nonperforming borrowers are paying as agreed. 
Allocated reserves increased to 11.5%. This was mostly due to the implementation of guidance from the recent shared national credit review that was received in early October. We continue to have good quality mix, with less than 10% in oilfield services. Lastly, the reserve coverage for coal, a very modest portfolio, rose to 13.7%. 
Turning to Slide 9. Our allowance coverage ratios remained strong at 2.91x for net charge-offs and 2x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loan ratio was 1.06%, flat compared to last quarter. Excluding the acquired portfolio, the allowance-to-loan ratio was 1.15%. So our effective allowance coverage remains strong. 
As a reminder, our acquired loans have a combined mark of $670 million. We have recorded a provision of $148 million compared to net charge-offs of $130 million. Looking forward, our provision is expected to match charge-offs plus loan growth. 
Turning to Slide 10. Compared to last quarter, net interest margin was 3.39%, down 2 basis points. Core margin was 3.17%, up 1 basis point. The margin decrease mostly resulted from lower investment yields, which were down 15 basis points. 
Looking to the fourth quarter, we expect GAAP margin to decline 3 to 5 basis points, driven by a reduction in benefits from purchase accounting. We expect core margin to remain essentially flat as lower rates will be offset by asset mix, funding cost and mix changes and the possibility of a rate increase in December. 
Additionally, we expect average earning assets to decline by approximately $1 billion next quarter due to lower security balances. Asset sensitivity increased, mostly due to growth in favorable funding sources and positive growth in short -- shorter asset classes. 
Continuing on Slide 11. Noninterest income totaled $1.2 billion, up $34 million compared to last quarter. The fee income ratio improved to 41.9%. 
Looking at a few other changes in noninterest income. Insurance income decreased $55 million, mostly driven by a seasonal decline in property and casualty commissions. Mortgage banking income increased $43 million due to net MSR valuation adjustments and higher production volumes. Other income decreased $10 million due to a $14 million decrease in income related to assets for certain postemployment benefits. 
And finally, we terminated our FDIC loss share agreements associated with Colonial. As a result, $18 million of expense was recognized in the third quarter. Going forward, no FDIC loss share expense will be recognized. 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, total fee income is expected to be relatively flat as seasonally stronger insurance is expected to offset by the seasonal decline in mortgage banking income. 
Turning to Slide 12. We had an excellent quarter in terms of expense management. Noninterest expenses totaled $1.7 billion, down $86 million or 19% versus last quarter. Personnel expense decreased $33 million, driven by a $14 million decline in postemployment benefit expense and a $10 million decline in insurance incentive expense due to seasonality. Merger-related and restructuring charges decreased $49 million, largely due to lower acquisition-related charges and last quarter's restructuring charges related to real estate in the amount of $19 million. 
In addition, other expense decreased $34 million, mostly due to the $73 million net benefit related to the settlement of certain FHA-insured mortgages. This is partially offset by a charitable contribution of $50 million. Going forward, excluding merger-related restructuring charges and unusual items, we expect expenses to decrease slightly in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 13. Capital ratios remain very healthy with a fully phased-in common equity Tier 1 of 9.9%. Our LCR was 122%, and our liquid asset buffer was very strong at 13.6%. 
Finally, we will continue with our share repurchase program in the fourth quarter, repurchasing up to $160 million in our shares. 
Now let's look at our segments beginning on Slide 14. Community Bank net income totaled $338 million, an increase of $43 million from last quarter and up $78 million from third quarter of last year. Noninterest income increased $13 million, driven by higher service charges on deposits, letters of credit and bankcard fees. Majority of the growth experienced in the Community Bank was acquisition related. However, third quarter was our best commercial loan production for the year. 
Turning to Slide 15. Residential Mortgage Banking net income totaled $117 million, up $73 million from last quarter, driven by net MSR valuation adjustments and higher salable [ph] loan volume as well as a net recovery from the settlement of FHA-insured loan matters. Production mix was 57% purchase and 43% refi, similar to last quarter. Gain on sale margins were slightly down 3 basis points to 1.06% versus last quarter. 
Looking to Slide 16. Dealer Financial Services income totaled $40 million, a decrease of $11 million compared to prior quarter. The provision for credit losses increased $18 million, mostly driven by loan growth as well as seasonally higher net charge-offs in the Regional Acceptance portfolio. Net charge-offs are still well within risk appetite of approximately 7%. Net charge-offs for the prime portfolio remain excellent at 19 basis points. 
Turning to Slide 17. Specialized Lending net income totaled $64 million, up $3 million from last quarter. This was driven mostly by loan and production growth in both Sheffield and equipment finance as well as strong production in Grandbridge, our commercial mortgage business. 
Looking at Slide 18. Insurance Services net income totaled $23 million, down $21 million from last quarter. Noninterest income totaled $412 million, down $53 million, mostly driven by seasonality in commercial property and casualty insurance. Noninterest expense decreased $21 million, mostly due to lower personnel expense, operating charge-offs and business referral expense. 
Turning to Slide 19. The Financial Services segment had $83 million in net income, down slightly, mostly due to a modest decline in Corporate Banking loan growth. Wealth generated strong loan and deposit growth, 8.6% and 13.7%, respectively, compared to last quarter. 
Lastly, the provision increase of $26 million was largely driven by risk rate mix changes, partially offset by lower loan balances. 
In summary, for the quarter, we achieved solid growth in revenues, continued strong credit quality and a relatively stable net interest margin and excellent expense control. Looking forward, we expect to improve outlook for loan growth, continued benign credit and solid expense control. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing remarks and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daryl. So as you've heard, we believe the quarter was an overall strong performance quarter. I would point out that our mergers are working really well. Expenses are being rationalized. Market acceptance in all of our new markets is very, very goo
componenttext:
Thanks, Daryl. So as you've heard, we believe the quarter was an overall strong performance quarter. I would point out that our mergers are working really well. Expenses are being rationalized. Market acceptance in all of our new markets is very, very good, and our Community Bank teams are executing extremely well in expense reduction and revenue production. 
Our loan growth in today's market, to be honest, is just very, very challenging. Still, as Daryl indicated, we do expect our loan growth to be in the 1% to 3% range as we look forward to the fourth quarter. And that's going to be based on, we think, probably somewhat lower levels of payoffs. And we keep looking at possibilities of asset purchases from some other institutions that are rationalizing their balance sheet. So when you put it all together, we think that we'll be in the 1% to 3% range. 
And frankly, I expect not much of an impact on the fourth quarter, but as we head into next year, I think the market is likely to get better once we get through post elections. Part of what is going on in the third quarter in terms of this kind of a slowdown that everybody's talking about is there's just a lot of anxiety out. I saw a report a couple of days ago that 60% or slightly less, but about 60% of the market is just really, really anxious about the elections, and I personally quite understand that. And so I think when all this subsides, however it goes, there'll be less uncertainty and less anxiety. I think that will instill a bit more confidence and people will be a little bit more willing to invest and make acquisitions and borrow money. So I think that's a bit on the positive side. 
We did have several good strategic agreements that will help future earnings. We continue our systems investments, and I'd point out we did add 3 members to our executive management team. So we feel good about where we are, and we at BB&T are building for the future. 
Now I'll turn it to Alan.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes, so it is early, as you point out, in the budgeting process, but we're being very, very intense about our expectations for next year. headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question, Daryl, you mentioned an LCR of 122% and also that you're going to offset some natural margin pressure next quarter with asset remixing. Other than the $1 billion in securities offering next quarter, could you give us a little bi
componenttext: And my follow-up question, Daryl, you mentioned an LCR of 122% and also that you're going to offset some natural margin pressure next quarter with asset remixing. Other than the $1 billion in securities offering next quarter, could you give us a little bit better sense what those remixing strategies are?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just our normal strategies that's growing our loan book in the specialized area faster than the total loan book. So you have higher growth and higher earning assets from that side. On the funding side, we continue to get really strong growth in DDA,
componenttext: It's just our normal strategies that's growing our loan book in the specialized area faster than the total loan book. So you have higher growth and higher earning assets from that side. On the funding side, we continue to get really strong growth in DDA, which is a free funding source, which gets us positive. So I think we feel very confident that our core net interest margin will remain stable even with these low rates. The GAAP margin just has pressure coming down as our purchase accounting runs off over the next couple of years.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: So I would say you have the same number of days in the fourth quarter as you do in the third quarter. Net interest income dollars will be down from third quarter mainly due to a little smaller balance sheet as we reduce our securities portfolio, but we're really trying to optimize and get higher overall performance in the long run to set us up for 2017. We think we want to position us that'd be more optimal in '17. And as I say, dollars probably down in the $20 million to $30 million range on a linked-quarter basis.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and could you elaborate a little bit on the puts and takes for the outlook for core NIM to be flat? You mentioned the December hike. Do you assume that LIBOR will start to move up in anticipation you'll get some benefit in the fourth quarter from a
componenttext: Okay, and could you elaborate a little bit on the puts and takes for the outlook for core NIM to be flat? You mentioned the December hike. Do you assume that LIBOR will start to move up in anticipation you'll get some benefit in the fourth quarter from a December hike?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: LIBOR, as you know, moved up once the money market changed. It happened this month. LIBOR will continue to probably stay at a relatively high levels as we cross over year-end. So that benefits us as we have a lot of loans still tied to the LIBOR rate. We
componenttext: LIBOR, as you know, moved up once the money market changed. It happened this month. LIBOR will continue to probably stay at a relatively high levels as we cross over year-end. So that benefits us as we have a lot of loans still tied to the LIBOR rate. We have, I think, 3x more assets than we do funding and liability sources tied to LIBOR. So that should be a benefit for us. So I think we feel good -- yes, and in our forecast right now, we do have an increase in December. We aren't really forecasting anything out '17 right now, but we do have the increase in our forecasts in the December.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Got it, and the LIBOR sensitivities onto 1 month, I assume, 1 month LIBOR?

componenttext: Majority of our assets are tied to 1 month. Our liabilities are tied more towards 3 months than 1 month, but there's a mix.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Daryl, I was wondering if you could just elaborate a bit on why you expect securities to go down in 4Q. I guess, we've seen some tick up in long-term rates. So would have thought that maybe reinvestment yields are little more appealing now than say, 3, 6
componenttext: Daryl, I was wondering if you could just elaborate a bit on why you expect securities to go down in 4Q. I guess, we've seen some tick up in long-term rates. So would have thought that maybe reinvestment yields are little more appealing now than say, 3, 6 months ago.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say if we were to buy securities now, they still probably -- we're very conservative on what we buy. We buy treasuries, agencies, MBFs so all high quality. The yields are still no more than 2%, probably in the high 1s. We just feel that from a liq
componenttext: I would say if we were to buy securities now, they still probably -- we're very conservative on what we buy. We buy treasuries, agencies, MBFs so all high quality. The yields are still no more than 2%, probably in the high 1s. We just feel that from a liquidity perspective, our securities portfolio can shrink a little bit. We also feel very good that, that will set us up, I think, for a strong 2017, and we'll have an optimal opportunity to get higher performance numbers as things start to happen in '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a question for Kelly. Just you mentioned there might be some opportunities for asset purchases from other banks. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.
componenttext: Okay. And a question for Kelly. Just you mentioned there might be some opportunities for asset purchases from other banks. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Matt, I think what you're seeing is that everybody in this low environment are taking hard look at the structure of the balance sheets and their ability to accumulate capital. So like us, I think everybody's looking at risk-adjusted return on asse
componenttext: Yes. So Matt, I think what you're seeing is that everybody in this low environment are taking hard look at the structure of the balance sheets and their ability to accumulate capital. So like us, I think everybody's looking at risk-adjusted return on assets structures. And so if an institution has a relatively low capital base and not much growth opportunity, one of the best ways for them to improve their return on equity is to reduce certain assets. And so if they have a particular asset that does that maybe they're high in their mix in terms of their appetite with regard to that, they may choose to exit some of that. It's not a big deal out, to be honest, but you are all seeing some of it, and we are continuously looking into the market to take advantage of any of those that come about because as I said, our strategy is to grow from the organic market what makes sense and then to supplement that with other opportunities that allow us to get some additional growth. And that's one that we've had some success with during this year. We think we'll have some success going forward.

componenttext: Kevin, this is Daryl. I will answer that. We really aren't giving a whole lot of guidance for '17 right now. We'll give it much more better clarity as we get into January and finish our planning process. But with Erika's question, our banks right now is $1.691 billion. We expect that to be down a little bit this next quarter, call it around 1%. And what Kelly said in '17 is we're going to try to hold that expense rate flat, maybe down a little bit, but we're going to do our best with all the competing priorities to keep our expenses relatively flat for '17. But we'll give you more color as things get finalized from our operating plan.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then a follow-up on your strong Mortgage Banking quarter. How much of that -- of the markup in your MSR was hedged out? And what was the net result of your higher MSR [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Right. And then a follow-up on your strong Mortgage Banking quarter. How much of that -- of the markup in your MSR was hedged out? And what was the net result of your higher MSR [indiscernible]?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Kevin. So we had 7 -- or $33 million in MSR valuation income. $18 million was that valuation adjustment to the MSR, and every now and then, you have to update and tune your prepayment models, and basically, our asset valuation was lagg
componenttext: Yes, good question, Kevin. So we had 7 -- or $33 million in MSR valuation income. $18 million was that valuation adjustment to the MSR, and every now and then, you have to update and tune your prepayment models, and basically, our asset valuation was lagging peers that we index and looking again. So we had to adjust our prepayment models, which allowed us to take that $18 million in as a valuation adjustment. So if you take that out, we had good hedge performance of $15 million, and that was just good performance in the that we had that we're hedging.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Does that have to do that with the fact that the tenure was slightly higher on the quarter even though 30-year [ph] mortgage rates went down in the third quarter?

componenttext: Just wanted to see if you can give us a little bit more commentary around the loan growth expectation as you look into 2017. I know you're not giving a lot of guidance there. But just I know you indicated the guidance for fourth quarter, and Kelly, I know you cautioned a little bit around some lax demand, midmarket commercial borrowers, et cetera. So how do you think that plays out for '17? And what type of general level of growth could we expect?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Clarke Starnes. So I'll take that. So basically, as Kelly mentioned, our production was actually pretty good for the third quarter, not substantially different than what we had seen year-to-date. The big challenge headwinds were the payoffs.
componenttext: John, this is Clarke Starnes. So I'll take that. So basically, as Kelly mentioned, our production was actually pretty good for the third quarter, not substantially different than what we had seen year-to-date. The big challenge headwinds were the payoffs. So assuming those pipelines continue to stay strong and to Kelly's point, if we see some more clarity around the political side of things, we may see more activity as we go into next year. But our view is we believe we can produce reasonable growth within our risk appetite around GDP plus 1% or 2%. So given whatever you think the economy is going to grow, we think that we can grow a little bit faster than that, but we don't certainly believe we can it's prudent us to well go beyond that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then my follow-up is around the efficiency ratio. Again, I know you're somewhat guarded on what type of expense guidance you give us, but how can we think about the efficiency ratio for 2017 barring any moves by the Fed? I know y
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then my follow-up is around the efficiency ratio. Again, I know you're somewhat guarded on what type of expense guidance you give us, but how can we think about the efficiency ratio for 2017 barring any moves by the Fed? I know you're around 60% [ph] currently. Is it fair to assume that we can get to the high 50s without a move from the Fed?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we got through our planning process, we always had our business lines plan positive operating leverage. We wanted to stay within the risk appetite of what they're trying to accomplish. So we're going to have a plan that puts the other positive operat
componenttext: When we got through our planning process, we always had our business lines plan positive operating leverage. We wanted to stay within the risk appetite of what they're trying to accomplish. So we're going to have a plan that puts the other positive operating leverage. So hopefully, we will be able to generate and get improvement on efficiency, but we really aren't guiding to any specific number. That's really going to depend on the execution and what the market will allow us and what we can grow from a revenue perspective. We can control expenses, as Kelly said. We will be very tough on expenses and do what we think is right for the long-term benefit of our company and our shareholders.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe ask a question on a different topic. Kelly, maybe you can talk about the recent speech, does it all change the way you think about excess capital? And, I guess, in addition, at this point, you're under 2 50 and hence, no longer subject to the qualit
componenttext: Maybe ask a question on a different topic. Kelly, maybe you can talk about the recent speech, does it all change the way you think about excess capital? And, I guess, in addition, at this point, you're under 2 50 and hence, no longer subject to the qualitative component. However, over the next 2 [ph] years, you would likely pass this. So does this at all change the way you thought about surpassing 2 50. I know historically, you talked about a large strategic action would probably be likely, but you obviously made a comment that's off the table for now. So just interested in what you thought of this speech and how you're thinking about excess -- how you're thinking about passing 2 50.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, I think speech was very consistent with what he's been saying really for the last 2 or 3 years. He's been, I think, appropriately moving to adjust some of the initial Fed criteria around CCAR. He clearly, I think, believes that a CCAR process needs
componenttext: Ryan, I think speech was very consistent with what he's been saying really for the last 2 or 3 years. He's been, I think, appropriately moving to adjust some of the initial Fed criteria around CCAR. He clearly, I think, believes that a CCAR process needs to be much tougher on the large [indiscernible] versus large regionals like BB&T. And so I think his speech simply is, to some degree, codified his movement in that direction. But from our point of view, frankly, it does not change a lot because we have a robust CCAR process. We're not going to dismantle it just because we want the 2 50 making incentives. Number one, the way we're doing CCAR today, we actually benefit from it. We think it's a healthy process, and so we would continue basically as it is anyway even if the Fed dropped the whole requirements. But certainly, we wouldn't drop it and then have to pick it back up if we did a strategic deal to put us over 2 50. So it was encouraging that I think it signals that the intensity of change with regard to really banks under, I think, $500 billion is just not going to increase. In fact, it's kind of stable. And as he said, the intensity of additional increased scrutiny is on [indiscernible] so that relatively is good news for us.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Maybe just quickly longer theme. Can you just maybe give us some comments around what you're seeing in commercial real estate, particularly in multifamily and office, where we've heard some cautious comments from some of your peers and what are yo
componenttext: Got it. Maybe just quickly longer theme. Can you just maybe give us some comments around what you're seeing in commercial real estate, particularly in multifamily and office, where we've heard some cautious comments from some of your peers and what are your expectations for growth there going forward?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is Clarke again. Certainly, we are being more cautious in the CRE sector. The 2 areas that we're more was cautious in right now is multifamily because we believe that market may have peaked or is peaking. There's a lot of projects in the pipeli
componenttext: Ryan, this is Clarke again. Certainly, we are being more cautious in the CRE sector. The 2 areas that we're more was cautious in right now is multifamily because we believe that market may have peaked or is peaking. There's a lot of projects in the pipeline that are going to affect potentially absorption and vacancy and those sorts of things. So we're very careful to make sure we don't create an undue concentration there, and we'll see some issues market by market. There, you see some of those symptoms. The other area is hospitality. We think that's also at a peaked and likely to potentially have some overcapacity as we move forward. So what I am seeing is others sensing the same thing, and it is the underwriting is clearly tightened and pricing increased for those that are still active in that space, but I think all the banks are being more cautious.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on your long-term debt and your FHLB book. You have a $4-and-change billion in pretty high-cost stuff underneath. I'm just wondering in terms of as you kind of cleaning up some of the income statement and look out, is there any opportunity to d
componenttext: A question on your long-term debt and your FHLB book. You have a $4-and-change billion in pretty high-cost stuff underneath. I'm just wondering in terms of as you kind of cleaning up some of the income statement and look out, is there any opportunity to do some calls there? And what would that entail if you were able to do that? Would it be stable to be retired? Or could you just not take a charge move on that type of thing?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken, we are looking at our balance sheet and always try to optimize our balance sheet, and we are aware of what we have on our balance sheet on that long-term debt side and potentially there could be some that we would evaluate as we enter into '17.
componenttext: Yes, Ken, we are looking at our balance sheet and always try to optimize our balance sheet, and we are aware of what we have on our balance sheet on that long-term debt side and potentially there could be some that we would evaluate as we enter into '17. No decision has been made. Nothing's final, but obviously, there is potential opportunity there to maybe improve run rate and improve efficiency and returns.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And second, just in terms of now that the Swett is in the numbers, I saw in the business line that there really wasn't much organic growth. Could you give us an update on the insurance business and help us understand the new kind of run rate
componenttext: Okay, got it. And second, just in terms of now that the Swett is in the numbers, I saw in the business line that there really wasn't much organic growth. Could you give us an update on the insurance business and help us understand the new kind of run rate seasonality and just kind of what the organic growth outlook is for the insurance business?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken, it's Chris. Yes, I think Swett, first of all, is going very, very well. We're getting all the expense saves, the synergies that we thought we would. We're probably halfway through that process, and the conversion will occur in February. But you
componenttext: Sure, Ken, it's Chris. Yes, I think Swett, first of all, is going very, very well. We're getting all the expense saves, the synergies that we thought we would. We're probably halfway through that process, and the conversion will occur in February. But your point is right on in that the organic growth, primarily due to the pricing and excess capital in the market, is generally in the 1% range. If I could -- if you look at is year-to-date, we would be growing right on 1%, and there are several factors. Pricing is one. And if you look at the mix of businesses that we are in, the pure property and casualty business is probably down in the 1% to 2%, but the CAT property, which is through our business is probably down in the 15% to 20%. So on balance, we're probably down 4% to 5%. Existing client growth, however, is up. We actually saw a new business growth in the third quarter, which I would assume would be abnormal in the industry today. I think that speaks well to the revenue machine that we've built over the years. And then you're likely to see our performance-based payments, which isn't really based on kind of how you perform with your underwriters. The recent storm is really not large enough to create increases in pricing because there is some excess capital. On the other hand, it does hurt us just a little bit. It won't be significant on our performance. Run rate going forward, I think as we really kind of put the business together, we've got chance to continue to be positive and potentially accelerate if we get any kind of economic pickup, but I'd say it's in that sort of 1% to 2% kind of range looking forward.

componenttext: This is Jason Harbes from Matt's team. So, I guess, I just had a question on the expense guidance. So the 1% decline I think you quantified it sounds like that will roughly offset the anticipate a decline in the spread income this quarter. And then with fees relatively flat, should be relatively kind of flat EPS in Q4, I guess, is what the outlook is telling us. But just had a question on the credit guidance. So with the relatively stable net charge-offs and the expectation that you'll need to start provisioning for growth, is there just mechanically any kind of guidance, I guess, you can give us on how to think about the rate of reserve build for the anticipated loan growth?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, this is Clarke Starnes. I think we put it in our deck we believe our reserves rate were pretty much more or less at the bottom, given where we are at this stage of the cycle as we come to the prices and rebuilt the portfolios. They're now seasoning
componenttext: Jason, this is Clarke Starnes. I think we put it in our deck we believe our reserves rate were pretty much more or less at the bottom, given where we are at this stage of the cycle as we come to the prices and rebuilt the portfolios. They're now seasoning. We've been in a benign economy. So we would not anticipate our reserve rate to go lower. So the way we think about it is the likely impact on provision is NCOs plus enough reserve build to maintain -- in dollars to maintain that reserve rate that we have today. So that's how we're thinking about it at this point.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so keeping reserve rate relatively stable over the next few quarters, I guess, will be the expectation there? Okay. And then just a question on the core NIM expectation. I guess, that should be relatively stable in Q4 assuming we get a rate hike in
componenttext: Okay, so keeping reserve rate relatively stable over the next few quarters, I guess, will be the expectation there? Okay. And then just a question on the core NIM expectation. I guess, that should be relatively stable in Q4 assuming we get a rate hike in December. What will be the expectation if we didn't get a rate hike?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The rate hike is late in December. It's not going to have a big material impact. We're getting the LIBOR benefit just crossing over year-end. So I wouldn't view that as material. I mean, we might be off a basis point, but we could be up a basis point in c
componenttext: The rate hike is late in December. It's not going to have a big material impact. We're getting the LIBOR benefit just crossing over year-end. So I wouldn't view that as material. I mean, we might be off a basis point, but we could be up a basis point in core margin. So it's pretty much a nonissue for fourth quarter.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the question for Kelly. Could you just talk about the strategy and optimal size of BB&T in Texas? Your energy portfolio stabilized last quarter as did many in the industry, and we've seen a recovery in many of the Texas bank stocks. So are you co
componenttext: I guess, the question for Kelly. Could you just talk about the strategy and optimal size of BB&T in Texas? Your energy portfolio stabilized last quarter as did many in the industry, and we've seen a recovery in many of the Texas bank stocks. So are you comfortable with the size today and how are you looking to grow it if M&A is off the table? Is it more of a de novo strategy?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the energy portfolio is really just a very small portion of our strategy in Texas. We view the energy portfolio as more of a national kind of a strategy, and I would expect it to continue to grow modestly as the overall industry continues to recov
componenttext: Yes. So the energy portfolio is really just a very small portion of our strategy in Texas. We view the energy portfolio as more of a national kind of a strategy, and I would expect it to continue to grow modestly as the overall industry continues to recover from the lower rates. With regard to Texas in general, our acquisitions of branches, our de novo branches are going extremely well. The Texas market overall is doing very well. We begin to see a little bit of softness in Houston around some multifamily and others, which you might expect, nothing dramatic, but you should begin to see the effect of that it, nowhere else really across Texas. So we're gaining momentum substantially. We have about $7 billion  or $8 billion operation in Texas at this point, which is strong 14th [ph] in market share, up from 53rd in market share when we started in 2009. So Texas is still growing about 1,000 people a day. So we'll continue to grow faster than the market in Texas, and we continue to build out our franchise with de novo types of branch expansions. We will certainly in the long term be interested in acquisitions, but that's not a part of our strategy today. And our organic strategy is to play very well. We love Texas and Texas loves us, and so we have a lot of fun in Texas.

componenttext: Yes. I would say our merger-related costs will probably be in the $20 million to $30 million. I mean, it's pretty much phasing down. This might be in the last quarter of any substance. headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relation
componenttext: Greetings, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the BB&T Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this event is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Greer of Investor Relations for BB&T Corporation.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, LeeAnn, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today.With me are Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the third
componenttext:
Thank you, LeeAnn, and good morning, everyone. Thanks to all of our listeners for joining us today.
With me are Kelly King, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Daryl Bible, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the results for the third quarter and provide some thoughts for next quarter.
We also have other members of our executive management team who are with us to participate in the Q&A session: Chris Henson, our Chief Operating Officer; Clarke Starnes, our Chief Risk Officer; and Ricky Brown, our Community Banking President.
We will be referencing a slide presentation during today's comments. A copy of the[ph] presentation as well as our earnings release and supplemental financial information are available on our website.
Let me remind you that BB&T does not provide public earnings predictions or forecasts. However, there may be statements made during the course of this call that express management's intentions, beliefs or expectations.
BB&T's actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements.
Please refer to the cautionary statements regarding forward-looking information in our presentation and our SEC filings. Please also note that our presentation includes certain non-GAAP disclosures.
Please refer to Page 2 and the appendix of our presentation for the appropriate reconciliations to GAAP.
At this time, I'll turn it over to Kelly.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining our call. So overall, I think we had a very strong performance quarter. We had a record quarterly earnings, and we did complete a few strategic agreements, which will benefit future quarters,
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining our call. 
So overall, I think we had a very strong performance quarter. We had a record quarterly earnings, and we did complete a few strategic agreements, which will benefit future quarters, which I'll describe. Net income of $599 million, which is up 21.7% versus third of '15 and 42.7% annualized versus second quarter '16. 
Diluted EPS was $0.73, up 14% versus the third and up 42% annualized versus the second. Now if you adjust, which I'll cover again, if you adjust EPS, it totaled $0.76, excluding merger-related and restructuring charges and a few other items on Slide 4. 
Our GAAP ROA, ROE and ROTCE were 1.15%, 8.87% and 15.20%, which I think were very strong in this environment. Taxable-equivalent revenues totaled $2.8 billion, up 13.1% versus third of '15 and 3.9% versus second quarter of '16 on an annualized basis. I'm very pleased that our net interest margin declined only 2 basis points to 3.39%, and our core net interest margin increased to 3.17%. Daryl will give you a lot more color on that in just a little bit. 
Our GAAP efficiency ratio improved to 61.7% versus 65.4% in the second quarter of '16. Our adjusted efficiency ratio improved to 58.7% versus 59.6% in the second quarter. Improvement on -- noninterest expenses were $1.7 billion, a decrease of 19% versus the second quarter annualized. 
Average loans and leases held for investment totaled $141.3 billion in the third quarter, which was up just slightly compared to the second quarter. We do continue to have significant runoff in our Residential Mortgage portfolio and prime auto based on some very clear strategic decisions that we have made. 
Ex these, though, we had a respectable 3 -- 2.2% annual growth, which I think is pretty good consistent with the economic growth, and I'll talk a bit more about that in a minute. NPAs did continue, a slight decrease of 4.9%. 
We did settle a loss share agreement with the FDIC. Recall that we had a loss share agreement on that 2009 acquisition of Colonial. We incurred an $18 million charge this quarter, but it will result in future benefits with regard to earnings. We did settle a dated FHA insurance loan matter, and we made a $50 million charitable contribution, which will reduce expenses in future quarters. And as indicated, we did repurchase $160 million of outstanding shares. 
Now Slide 4, these selected items that I related to, the merger-related restructuring charges was $43 million pretax or $0.03 negative impact to diluted EPS. Charitable contribution is $50 million pretax, which was $0.04 dilution to EPS. On the other hand, we had a settlement of FHA insurance loan matters net of recoveries, which was a positive $73 million or $0.05 and then the termination of the FDIC loss share agreements, the $18 million I mentioned, was $0.01. So if you net those out, it was $0.03 net negative impact on EPS because of those selected items. 
If you go to Slide 5, a few comments with regard to loans. As I've said, they were up slightly 0.3%, but for several quarters now, we have indicated to you that we have been allowing our Residential Mortgage portfolio to decline. That's a strategic decision because of the mix of our business, expectations with regard to rising rates and the spreads, frankly, in that business. So the risk-adjusted return is not at a level we would like to be on a marginal basis and so we're letting it run off. And in the sales finance in the prime portfolio, we did restructure some quarters ago to a flat program. That program transition's actually going very well. The old portfolio is running off today but, frankly, the new portfolio going on is more profitable. So we feel good about that, but it does show a loan decline. So again, net adjusted 2.2%. 
We did have some key very strong performances on a seasonal basis, which we expect from some of our Specialized Lending businesses. Premium finance was up 57.1% annualized; Sheffield, up 21.3% annualized; Regional Acceptance, up 15.5% annualized; and revolving credit was up 9.6%. So you can see that while we're being very careful with regard to our basic growth portfolio, our Specialized Lending portfolio has continued to do very, very well. 
Now we, like probably others, did experience higher payoffs in our commercial area in the quarter. Frankly, a lot of good quality loans have just been refi-ed out into the market because of, I think, participants' expectations that rates are going up. So they're going on out and taking advantage of long-term loan markets. That's not a long-term change in terms of the commercial lending productivity. It's just a temporary increase in payoffs. Production in the pipelines and all still looks solid. 
And I'll remind you that we are a very disciplined lender. We're just not doing cheap loans outside of our risk appetite. But quite frankly, I mean, we could be growing faster, but the risk-adjusted return on equity's just unacceptable. So we're getting all that the market will give us and we're not going to try to beat the market. That's not a good bet from a long-term point of view. 
On Page 6, our DDA growth continue to be very strong at 14.3%, feel really good about that. We are increasing market share in most of our markets, and we continue to hold our costs at a very low 0.3%. So our deposit business is doing extremely well and supporting the asset growth that we have. 
Let me turn it to Daryl now for some additional detail, and then we'll have questions.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. Turning to Slide 7. Overall, we had a really good quarter with regard to
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to talk about credit quality, net interest margin, fee income, noninterest expense, capital and our segment results. 
Turning to Slide 7. Overall, we had a really good quarter with regard to credit quality. Net charge-offs totaled $130 million, up 9 basis points from last quarter. This was mostly driven by expected seasonality in our retail portfolios as well as returning to more normalized levels after a very low charge-off quarter. 
Loans 30 to 89 days past due increased $66 million or 7.2%, again, mostly due to seasonality in our consumer-related portfolios. NPAs decreased 4.9% to 38 basis points. Excluding energy, NPAs have improved steadily in recent quarters. 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect NPAs to remain at a similar range. We also expect net charge-offs to be in a range of 35 to 45 basis points assuming no unexpected deterioration in the economy. 
Continuing on Slide 8. Our energy portfolio totaled $1.3 billion, about 1% of total loans. Outstanding balances, total commitments and nonaccruals all decreased from last quarter, and all nonperforming borrowers are paying as agreed. 
Allocated reserves increased to 11.5%. This was mostly due to the implementation of guidance from the recent shared national credit review that was received in early October. We continue to have good quality mix, with less than 10% in oilfield services. Lastly, the reserve coverage for coal, a very modest portfolio, rose to 13.7%. 
Turning to Slide 9. Our allowance coverage ratios remained strong at 2.91x for net charge-offs and 2x for NPLs. The allowance-to-loan ratio was 1.06%, flat compared to last quarter. Excluding the acquired portfolio, the allowance-to-loan ratio was 1.15%. So our effective allowance coverage remains strong. 
As a reminder, our acquired loans have a combined mark of $670 million. We have recorded a provision of $148 million compared to net charge-offs of $130 million. Looking forward, our provision is expected to match charge-offs plus loan growth. 
Turning to Slide 10. Compared to last quarter, net interest margin was 3.39%, down 2 basis points. Core margin was 3.17%, up 1 basis point. The margin decrease mostly resulted from lower investment yields, which were down 15 basis points. 
Looking to the fourth quarter, we expect GAAP margin to decline 3 to 5 basis points, driven by a reduction in benefits from purchase accounting. We expect core margin to remain essentially flat as lower rates will be offset by asset mix, funding cost and mix changes and the possibility of a rate increase in December. 
Additionally, we expect average earning assets to decline by approximately $1 billion next quarter due to lower security balances. Asset sensitivity increased, mostly due to growth in favorable funding sources and positive growth in short -- shorter asset classes. 
Continuing on Slide 11. Noninterest income totaled $1.2 billion, up $34 million compared to last quarter. The fee income ratio improved to 41.9%. 
Looking at a few other changes in noninterest income. Insurance income decreased $55 million, mostly driven by a seasonal decline in property and casualty commissions. Mortgage banking income increased $43 million due to net MSR valuation adjustments and higher production volumes. Other income decreased $10 million due to a $14 million decrease in income related to assets for certain postemployment benefits. 
And finally, we terminated our FDIC loss share agreements associated with Colonial. As a result, $18 million of expense was recognized in the third quarter. Going forward, no FDIC loss share expense will be recognized. 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, total fee income is expected to be relatively flat as seasonally stronger insurance is expected to offset by the seasonal decline in mortgage banking income. 
Turning to Slide 12. We had an excellent quarter in terms of expense management. Noninterest expenses totaled $1.7 billion, down $86 million or 19% versus last quarter. Personnel expense decreased $33 million, driven by a $14 million decline in postemployment benefit expense and a $10 million decline in insurance incentive expense due to seasonality. Merger-related and restructuring charges decreased $49 million, largely due to lower acquisition-related charges and last quarter's restructuring charges related to real estate in the amount of $19 million. 
In addition, other expense decreased $34 million, mostly due to the $73 million net benefit related to the settlement of certain FHA-insured mortgages. This is partially offset by a charitable contribution of $50 million. Going forward, excluding merger-related restructuring charges and unusual items, we expect expenses to decrease slightly in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 13. Capital ratios remain very healthy with a fully phased-in common equity Tier 1 of 9.9%. Our LCR was 122%, and our liquid asset buffer was very strong at 13.6%. 
Finally, we will continue with our share repurchase program in the fourth quarter, repurchasing up to $160 million in our shares. 
Now let's look at our segments beginning on Slide 14. Community Bank net income totaled $338 million, an increase of $43 million from last quarter and up $78 million from third quarter of last year. Noninterest income increased $13 million, driven by higher service charges on deposits, letters of credit and bankcard fees. Majority of the growth experienced in the Community Bank was acquisition related. However, third quarter was our best commercial loan production for the year. 
Turning to Slide 15. Residential Mortgage Banking net income totaled $117 million, up $73 million from last quarter, driven by net MSR valuation adjustments and higher saleable loan volume as well as a net recovery from the settlement of FHA-insured loan matters. Production mix was 57% purchase and 43% refi, similar to last quarter. Gain on sale margins were slightly down 3 basis points to 1.06% versus last quarter. 
Looking to Slide 16. Dealer Financial Services income totaled $40 million, a decrease of $11 million compared to prior quarter. The provision for credit losses increased $18 million, mostly driven by loan growth as well as seasonally higher net charge-offs in the Regional Acceptance portfolio. Net charge-offs are still well within risk appetite of approximately 7%. Net charge-offs for the prime portfolio remain excellent at 19 basis points. 
Turning to Slide 17. Specialized Lending net income totaled $64 million, up $3 million from last quarter. This was driven mostly by loan and production growth in both Sheffield and equipment finance as well as strong production in Grandbridge, our commercial mortgage business. 
Looking at Slide 18. Insurance Services net income totaled $23 million, down $21 million from last quarter. Noninterest income totaled $412 million, down $53 million, mostly driven by seasonality in commercial property and casualty insurance. Noninterest expense decreased $21 million, mostly due to lower personnel expense, operating charge-offs and business referral expense. 
Turning to Slide 19. The Financial Services segment had $83 million in net income, down slightly, mostly due to a modest decline in Corporate Banking loan growth. Wealth generated strong loan and deposit growth, 8.6% and 13.7%, respectively, compared to last quarter. 
Lastly, the provision increase of $26 million was largely driven by risk rate mix changes, partially offset by lower loan balances. 
In summary, for the quarter, we achieved solid growth in revenues, continued strong credit quality and a relatively stable net interest margin and excellent expense control. Looking forward, we expect to improve outlook for loan growth, continued benign credit and solid expense control. 
Now let me turn it back over to Kelly for closing remarks and Q&A.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daryl. So as you've heard, we believe the quarter was an overall strong performance quarter. I would point out that our mergers are working really well. Expenses are being rationalized. Market acceptance in all of our new markets is very, very goo
componenttext:
Thanks, Daryl. So as you've heard, we believe the quarter was an overall strong performance quarter. I would point out that our mergers are working really well. Expenses are being rationalized. Market acceptance in all of our new markets is very, very good, and our Community Bank teams are executing extremely well in expense reduction and revenue production. 
Our loan growth in today's market, to be honest, is just very, very challenging. Still, as Daryl indicated, we do expect our loan growth to be in the 1% to 3% range as we look forward to the fourth quarter. And that's going to be based on, we think, probably somewhat lower levels of payoffs. And we keep looking at possibilities of asset purchases from some other institutions that are rationalizing their balance sheet. So when you put it all together, we think that we'll be in the 1% to 3% range. 
And frankly, I expect not much of an impact on the fourth quarter, but as we head into next year, I think the market is likely to get better once we get through post elections. Part of what is going on in the third quarter in terms of this kind of a slowdown that everybody's talking about is there's just a lot of anxiety out. I saw a report a couple of days ago that 60% or slightly less, but about 60% of the market is just really, really anxious about the elections, and I personally quite understand that. And so I think when all this subsides, however it goes, there'll be less uncertainty and less anxiety. I think that will instill a bit more confidence and people will be a little bit more willing to invest and make acquisitions and borrow money. So I think that's a bit on the positive side. 
We did have several good strategic agreements that will help future earnings. We continue our systems investments, and I'd point out we did add 3 members to our executive management team. So we feel good about where we are, and we at BB&T are building for the future. 
Now I'll turn it to Alan.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly. LeeAnn, at this time, if you would come back on the line and explain how our listeners may participate in the Q&A session.
componenttext: Thank you, Kelly. LeeAnn, at this time, if you would come back on the line and explain how our listeners may participate in the Q&A session.

Then some opportunities had a slight decrease.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question, Daryl, you mentioned an LCR of 122% and also that you're going to offset some natural margin pressure next quarter with asset remixing. Other than the $1 billion in securities rural offering next quarter, could you give us a lit
componenttext: And my follow-up question, Daryl, you mentioned an LCR of 122% and also that you're going to offset some natural margin pressure next quarter with asset remixing. Other than the $1 billion in securities rural offering next quarter, could you give us a little bit better sense on what those remixing strategies are?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just our normal strategies of growing our loan book in the specialized area faster than the total loan book. So you have higher growth and higher earning assets from that side. On the funding side, we continue to get really strong growth in DDA, whic
componenttext: It's just our normal strategies of growing our loan book in the specialized area faster than the total loan book. So you have higher growth and higher earning assets from that side. On the funding side, we continue to get really strong growth in DDA, which is a free funding source, which gets us positive. So I think we feel very confident that our core net interest margin will remain stable even with these low rates. The GAAP margin just has pressure coming down as our purchase accounting runs off over the next couple of years.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Daryl, just a follow-up on that. What's your outlook on, in terms of NII dollars, your ability to grow all-in reported NII dollars in the fourth quarter when you think about what's happening in the balance sheet and NIM?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say you have the same number of days in the fourth quarter as you do in the third quarter. Net interest income dollars will be down from third quarter mainly due to a little smaller balance sheet as we reduce our securities portfolio, but we're
componenttext: So I would say you have the same number of days in the fourth quarter as you do in the third quarter. Net interest income dollars will be down from third quarter mainly due to a little smaller balance sheet as we reduce our securities portfolio, but we're really trying to optimize and get higher overall performance in the long run to set us up for 2017. We think where we want to position us, that'd be more optimal in '17. And so I'd say dollars probably down in the $20 million to $30 million range on a linked-quarter basis.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you elaborate a little bit on the puts and takes for the outlook for core NIM to be flat? You mentioned the December hike. Do you assume that LIBOR will start to move up in anticipation and you'll get some benefit in the fourth quarter fro
componenttext: Okay. And could you elaborate a little bit on the puts and takes for the outlook for core NIM to be flat? You mentioned the December hike. Do you assume that LIBOR will start to move up in anticipation and you'll get some benefit in the fourth quarter from a December hike?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: LIBOR, as you know, moved up with the money market change that happened this month. LIBOR will continue to probably stay at relatively high levels as we cross over year-end. So that benefits us as we have a lot of loans still tied to the LIBOR rate. We ha
componenttext: LIBOR, as you know, moved up with the money market change that happened this month. LIBOR will continue to probably stay at relatively high levels as we cross over year-end. So that benefits us as we have a lot of loans still tied to the LIBOR rate. We have, I think, 3x more assets than we do funding and liability sources tied to LIBOR. So that should be a benefit for us. So I think we feel good -- yes, and in our forecast right now, we do have an increase in December. We aren't really forecasting anything out '17 right now, but we do have the increase in our forecasts in the December.

componenttext: Majority of our assets are tied to 1 month. Our liabilities are tied more towards 3 months than 1 month, but there's a mix.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Daryl, I was wondering if you could just elaborate a bit on why you expect securities to go down in 4Q. I guess, we've seen some tick-up in long-term rates. So I would have thought that maybe reinvestment yields are a little more appealing now than say, 3
componenttext: Daryl, I was wondering if you could just elaborate a bit on why you expect securities to go down in 4Q. I guess, we've seen some tick-up in long-term rates. So I would have thought that maybe reinvestment yields are a little more appealing now than say, 3, 6 months ago.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say if we were to buy securities now, they'd still probably -- we're very conservative on what we buy. We buy treasuries, agencies, MBFs so all high quality. The yields are still no more than 2%, probably in the high 1s. We just feel that from a l
componenttext: I would say if we were to buy securities now, they'd still probably -- we're very conservative on what we buy. We buy treasuries, agencies, MBFs so all high quality. The yields are still no more than 2%, probably in the high 1s. We just feel that from a liquidity perspective, our securities portfolio can shrink a little bit. We also feel very good that, that will set us up, I think, for a strong 2017, and we'll have an optimal opportunity to get higher performance numbers as things start to happen in '17.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a question for Kelly. Just you mentioned there might be some opportunities for asset purchases from other banks. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.
componenttext: Okay. And then a question for Kelly. Just you mentioned there might be some opportunities for asset purchases from other banks. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Matt, I think what you're seeing is that everybody in this low environment are taking a hard look at the structure of the balance sheets and their ability to accumulate capital. And so like us, I think everybody's looking at risk-adjusted return o
componenttext: Yes. So Matt, I think what you're seeing is that everybody in this low environment are taking a hard look at the structure of the balance sheets and their ability to accumulate capital. And so like us, I think everybody's looking at risk-adjusted return on asset structures. And so if an institution has a relatively low capital base and not much growth opportunity, one of the best ways for them to improve their return on equity is to reduce certain assets. And so if they have a particular asset that does -- that maybe they're high and are mixed in terms of their appetite with regard to that, they may choose to exit. We've seen some of that. It's not a big deal out there, Matt, to be honest, but you are seeing some of it, and we are continuously looking into the market to take advantage of any of those that come about because, as I said, our strategy is to grow from the organic market what makes sense and then to supplement that with other opportunities that allow us to get some additional growth. And that's one that we've had some success with during this year. We think we'll have some success going forward.

componenttext: I just want to follow up with regards to your comments regarding the forward expenses. Kelly, I believe you mentioned that you expect them to be flattish going into 2017. Is that on an operating number? Or is that on a total after taking into account the merger and restructuring charges starting 2016?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, this is Daryl. I'll answer that. We really aren't giving a whole lot of guidance for '17 right now. We'll give much more better clarity as we get into January and finish our planning process. But with Erika's question, our banks right now is $
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, this is Daryl. I'll answer that. We really aren't giving a whole lot of guidance for '17 right now. We'll give much more better clarity as we get into January and finish our planning process. But with Erika's question, our banks right now is $1.691 billion. We expect that to be down a little bit this next quarter, call it, around 1%. And what Kelly said in '17 is we're going to try to hold that expense rate flat, maybe down a little bit, but we're going to do our best with all the competing priorities to keep our expenses relatively flat for '17. But we'll give you more color as things get finalized from our operating plan.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then a follow-up on your strong Mortgage Banking quarter. How much of that -- of the markup in your MSR was hedged out? And what was the net result of your higher MSR [indiscernible] value markup?
componenttext: Right. And then a follow-up on your strong Mortgage Banking quarter. How much of that -- of the markup in your MSR was hedged out? And what was the net result of your higher MSR [indiscernible] value markup?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Kevin. So look, we had 7 -- or $33 million in MSR valuation income. $18 million was that valuation adjustment to the MSR, and every now and then, you have to update and tune your prepayment models and, basically, our asset valuation wa
componenttext: Yes, good question, Kevin. So look, we had 7 -- or $33 million in MSR valuation income. $18 million was that valuation adjustment to the MSR, and every now and then, you have to update and tune your prepayment models and, basically, our asset valuation was lagging peers that we indexed and looking against. So we had to adjust our prepayment models, which allowed us to take that $18 million in as a valuation adjustment. So if you take that out, we had good hedge performance of $15 million, and that was just good performance in the TBAs that we had that we're hedging.

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Did that have to do with the fact that the 10-year moved slightly higher on the quarter even though 30-year mortgage rates went down in the third quarter?

headline: BB&T Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
